name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on Making relocation happen (2017/2685(RSP)).  Before I give the floor to Commission Avramopoulos, and good morning to you, Commissioner, I just want to announce that the Council has excused itself from this morning’s debate.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to express my thanks for this timely debate on relocation just a few hours before we adopt the 12th report on resettlement and relocation. There is no doubt that relocation is vital for the success of our policy. The success of our migration and asylum policy is based on solidarity and responsibility. We have said this many times before in this Chamber. This is why it is so essential that relocation works, in all its aspects, and is implemented by everyone. One element remains critical for the success of this scheme: political will, political determination and mutual cooperation and trust between the Member States offering relocation and the beneficiary Member States. This is not for the benefit just of Italy or Greece. This is for the benefit of the entire European Union and our European asylum system because a properly functioning relocation scheme is also essential to prevent secondary movements and preserve the integrity of the free—borders Schengen area. Member States have so far relocated, in total, more than 18 000 persons, and we have to acknowledge the tangible and important progress made on relocation, especially during the past five months. However, further efforts are needed and Member States should therefore deploy additional effort and flexibility to make the relocation of all eligible applicants currently in Italy and Greece happen. But this cannot be the responsibility of just a few Member States: it has to be shared by all Member States. Our common goal is for all Member States to contribute fairly and proportionately to relocation. Right now 12 500 eligible applicants in Greece and around 4 000 in Italy are registered and ready to be relocated. If all Member States step up the number of relocations, it is entirely possible to achieve this goal by September. It is time – as I said before – to show political will and determination. Member States should also fully implement the recommendations that we put forward in our regular reports. Most importantly, Member States should increase their monthly pledges in proportion to their relocations and increase their capacity to process application requests. While many Member States have increased their contributions, there are regrettably still a few Member States that have not relocated a single person. I want to be clear that this is in breach of their obligations. More generally, Member States should also avoid overly restrictive or arbitrary preferences, should limit requirements causing delays in the transfer procedure and should give priority to applications concerning vulnerable applicants, in particular unaccompanied minors. In addition, the Commission urges Italy to speed up the procedures to identify and register for relocation all eligible applicants and to find mutually acceptable solutions on security interviews with relocating Member States. All those eligible for relocation arriving in Italy need to be channelled in an orderly manner to specifically designated relocation hubs. All Member States should relocate more unaccompanied minors, in particular from Italy. I am glad to see that Parliament’s draft resolution includes many of these recommendations and I really count on your support, honourable Members, to convince Member States – or rather governments – to implement them fully and strictly. Relocation is a joint effort that requires all Member States to contribute. Relocation is both an obligation and a moral duty. Thank you for your attention and I thank Parliament for its continued support.  (Applause)

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Thank you, chairman. Thanks also to Commissioner Avramopoulos for his contribution this morning and for the many updates we have received over the past year and a half. I do not believe there has ever been a subject where we have had so close contact with the Commission. At the same time, it is a pity that the Council is not here today. After all, many of the questions we have should be put to the Council. I therefore deeply regret that the Council is not here today. It was two years ago in September that the Council took these decisions. That happened at a time of crisis: 180,000 people came in every month. It was political hassle. It took a long time. That is why I am again calling here today for the creation of a permanent system to be able to prevent such crises in the future under the Dublin Regulation. I agree with the Commissioner that the last few months have given cause for cautious optimism. We see that more people are actually being redistributed. But at the same time it is also a bit too little, too late. Given the reduced influx, that number of 160,000 is indeed no longer relevant. However, we must ensure that all eligible candidates actually get a place. Then I wonder how in God's name it is possible that some countries have done nothing at all, but also how it is possible that in a country like Italy only eight thousand people have actually been registered in the past eighteen months. Something has to be done on both sides. Finally, I would like to point out that I have never been in favor of mandatory quotas. But we have seen in September 2015 and over the last year and a half that it does not work on a voluntary basis. So let's do something about that.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, solidarity is not a mechanism that applies á la carte, it is not a choice dictated by compassion towards those fleeing war and persecution, it is not a commitment that can be postponed over time. Solidarity and full sharing of responsibilities are cardinal principles of our legal system and not tools to be used voluntarily if certain conditions are met, if the nationality of the beneficiaries is, for example, to our liking, if age and gender seem to us more appropriate. This restrictive and discriminatory system of preferences is punishable as much as the absolute lack of commitments. Choosing the path of denial of the right violates the human dignity of thousands of women, men and especially children, we deny them fundamental rights, we distance them from legality, we deprive them of a future. Rejoicing in an effort made by the Member States is a bit like considering a glass filled with a few drops of water full. 11% of the beneficiaries of international protection actually relocated is certainly not an achievement to be proud of. Only two Member States out of 28 that respect their commitments, two Member States that really do not want to know about welcoming asylum seekers in their territories, many others instead of words promise but in fact deny. There are only a few who, with great difficulty and slowness, are doing their part. And what will happen after September 26, 2017? What guarantees will we have that the obligations do not run out after that date? Commissioner, the stick raised in the air of the infringement procedure alone will not oblige the Member States to take on the obligations of solidarity. A sustainable migration policy is needed to ensure legal and safe access routes, create legal migration channels, as well as integration policies in host countries.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - 160,000 people should be transferred from Greece and Italy to the other Member States, including Belgium, Germany and Sweden. It is accused that it is difficult to fill these places because the Member States would not cooperate sufficiently, but reports from the Commission show that Greece and Italy are not succeeding in organizing the flow. For example, there is a huge registration backlog in Italy. So it is unfair to just point the finger north. Moreover, it is not at all true that hardly any asylum seekers were relocated. Most of the asylum seekers who entered Europe traveled further to Northern and Western Europe themselves. Relocation is therefore already a fact in practice, because the Dublin rules on reception and registration in the first Member State of arrival, from which one can subsequently be relocated, are hardly respected in practice. In any case, the N-VA insists that the external borders must first be closed, otherwise it is mopping with the tap open. In concrete terms, we must return any asylum seeker who arrives illegally in the EU with the help of people smugglers to a safe place in the region of origin. As long as the EU continues to reward illegal arrivals with papers, families will continue to risk their lives along the way. We must therefore move towards a system of legal entry, linked to a strict maximum limit.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President! The decision on the relocation of refugees was taken by the Member States as an urgent and also necessary solidarity measure. However - and I would like to emphasize this very clearly here - without an associated EU asylum system, which is based on a shared sense of responsibility. Because that is precisely what is still missing at European level today. To this day, the only answer from the European side to refugees coming to Europe is mainly one: close borders and control borders. There are still 62,300 asylum seekers and migrants in Greece, waiting to be accepted into one of the 28 member states, while countries like Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq and Turkey have had millions since the beginning of the Syrian conflict five years ago Have taken in refugees. With this in mind, I would also like to remind the European Council that the relocation decision was a decision by the Council itself and was adopted by it. During this plenary session, we will be voting on a resolution on Syria, the EU strategy on Syria and relations with the Middle East. So I ask myself: how can we remain credible at international level if we are unable to implement small solidarity measures within our own borders, if our own heads of state and government do not fulfill the commitments they have made and which they themselves have made made mandatory for all Member States? To date, the Member States have actually and actually implemented only a small part of the redistribution that they themselves promised. This is not due to the ability, but the willingness, because the capacities are there. I think that is clear to us all. I would therefore like to appeal to those responsible here today: It is the highest Time for the Member States to fulfill their self-imposed obligations.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this is not the first time that this Parliament has asked the Member States to respect their commitments and the Commission to stop the optimism it has long enjoyed. We also ask the Member States to avoid subterfuges, I am thinking of the refusal to relocate migrants who arrived in Greece after 20 March 2016, in the aftermath of the agreement with Turkey, an illegal refusal, according to the Court of Auditors. For my part I add a consideration. Relocation risks being a deception if combined with the hotspot approach and the decision to relocate migrants who have traveled to other countries to Greece and Italy, based on the Dublin system. Taken together, these measures undermine the ability of Greece and Italy to manage the flows of refugees and migrants. As for Italy, in 2015-2016 there were 5 049 Dublin transfers and 3 936 relocations, i.e. more people were sent back to Italy than were transferred from Italy. Relocation, therefore, is necessary but not enough. The truth is that the Commission often goes to great lengths to help Italy and Greece perfect a wrong system, generating situations that have become unsustainable. Thank you, Commissioner, I would like an answer.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the colleagues who have been working together with us, across the whole House, on making this resolution work. It shows how united Parliament is in calling for solidarity both among Member States and also with refugees. I would also like to thank the Commission, and the Commissioner especially, for again and again emphasising the fact that this solidarity needs to be shown: that this relocation needs to be made to happen. Relocation is a very important tool for solidarity, but it is also a very important humanitarian tool. It obviously helps Members States which have received a lot of refugees, and it helps the refugees finally to find a place of safety and a place where they can build a new future. But I would go so far as to say it gives a great opportunity to Member States which have not yet had much experience with refugees. They will get support from the Commission, they will gain experience and, in terms of accommodation, it will be a situation in which they know when the refugees are coming, and which refugees are coming – which is not the situation that any Member State could face at some point in the future. Therefore, it is very disappointing that the Council is not present here today because the problem, obviously, is not with the people speaking here today: the problem lies with the Member States and, as colleagues have pointed out, the problem is not one of capacity, the problem is not one of how we shall do this, it is purely a problem of political will. There is a scandalous lack of political will. We are talking here about people who are fleeing from war and persecution, and we are talking about unaccompanied minors: those are the people who are mainly stuck in Italy and Greece. How horrible can that be: to leave unaccompanied children alone, in overcrowded conditions without any possibility of a safe future? I very much welcome the fact that the Commission has said it will take action, insofar as possible, against those Member States which are doing nothing. Yes, relocation does not solve all the problems in the world. Yes, we still need a good Dublin system that puts solidarity in place. Yes, we do need common rules, legal access, etcetera, but relocation is a first step: a first step that will show how serious we are about our business.

name: Raymond Finch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this question is an existential one for the EU. Your answer to this will define the future of your project. It will say whether the EU is to be a collective of freely cooperating peoples, based on friendship and enlightened self-interest, or a centralised coercive structure feared and hated in equal parts by its constituents, and bound one day to explode in a welter of vituperation and vindictiveness. I urge you to look to the self-interest of your project, your peoples and your nations. However, my experience of the direction of your mentality leads me to the sad conclusion that you will continue along the path of self-destruction, both in terms of encouraging destructive economic migration from those poor benighted countries and in terms of sowing discord amongst your constituent nations.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - NGOs work together with people smugglers. They have each other's phone numbers. Together they provide an endless stream of illegal immigrants. The boats are waiting for each other off the Libyan coast. Frontex has confirmed this, but of course that does nothing to it. The cooperation with the people smugglers goes so far that last week there was even almost a collision between the Sea Watch sailing under the Dutch flag and the Libyan coastguard. In addition, the coast guard was even fired at. In a normal world, Italy would not allow these emigrants at all. But the EU obliges Italy to do this. The UN has meanwhile announced that no more than 3% of these people would ever be eligible for recognition. That means that 97% of those hundreds of thousands are not only illegal, but also hopeless, unwanted. They should be returned, but it is not. Therefore, the following must be done: First, no redistribution of these migrants. After all, that is rewarding criminal behavior. Second, illegal entry into an EU country must automatically mean exclusion from any residence permit, because then the whole route is immediately unattractive. Finally, any cooperation with the NGOs should be ended and, where possible, prosecuted for aid to human trafficking. I hereby call on the Dutch government to work on this, starting with that ship from last week. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: question "blue card".- I'll be very short.I would like to ask my colleague, but anyone who talks about NGOs as a danger and a 'pool factor', to provide proof of what they say, because NGOs are under attack in a very dishonest manner.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer.- In this case, my sympathy lies with Italy, which is so desperate that it is now even providing boats to the Libyan coast guard in order to bring some order into this.I just look at the figures of the UN: 3% may be eligible for a residence permit as a refugee and the rest are not.However you turn or turn it, the NGOs help to bring that other 97% to the other side.These NGOs are rightly under fire for this.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Ms. President!Since 2015, the European Union has had to face the biggest challenge ever: migration, which threatens Europe's culture, Europe's identity.And in this situation, the Commission still holds that the only important issue for it is the compulsory distribution of refugees between Member States.Who is the refugee?By adopting a report, this Parliament has made it clear that it is as legitimate to receive migrants who come in the hope of a better life as they flee political persecution.How do they want to prevent illegal migration?That?They want to expand legal migration.In this situation, it is natural that there are countries like Hungary that do not accept this, do not want to follow the path of building so-called societies in parallel, and reject the quota, which I myself agree with.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE).
text: - As a joint effort, we must carry out relocation wisely and responsibly, taking into account the varying degree of preparedness of societies for accepting refugees, in order to ensure the safety of Europeans, not to expose people with the right of asylum to attacks of aggression, and not to give populists a pretext to criticize Brussels. Therefore, participation in relocations should be voluntary for member states, but states must fulfill their voluntary obligations: prepare infrastructure, staff, and properly educate their communities. This is what the municipalities of Sicily do, basing relocation on two principles: voluntary and proportionate. Member States should fulfill early voluntary commitments, so I do not understand why the government in Poland has not accepted 7,000 refugees, including children. The previous government of Ewa Kopacz undertook to admit so many people. A country of 40 million can really afford it. That is why I am proud of the initiative of the authorities of many Polish cities and towns, which expressed their willingness to accept refugees, even if it concerned five or six people. If a small community is ready to look after one family, let them make this gesture. It is a scandal that the government does not support this. So not everyone in my country is immune to the misfortune and suffering of others. Our civil society is still doing well, although the PiS government is trying to limit its freedoms. Caritas and the episcopate also offer help by organizing humanitarian corridors. The PiS government, which wields Catholic values, does not even take it into account. Finally, let us not forget that relocations should not be seen as the key to resolving the immigration crisis. This is just one of the instruments that Europe has more.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Ms. President! The need to protect people fleeing war and persecution is an international legal obligation for Member States. That is why the relocation of refugees is not only an expression of European solidarity but also of shared responsibility. This is not being forced on the countries by Brussels, but by the Member States themselves. We cannot shift the responsibility to the Member States at the external borders alone. If they have to bear the burden alone, their asylum system could collapse in an emergency. The result is human suffering and political turmoil. If we want order and security, we need a strong and solidarity-based European asylum system. If we do not create this, Schengen and the whole European project will be jeopardized. It is possible, of course, to lie for political gain that the Union wants to let everyone in without control, but we know that is not true. The resettlement system also helps to ensure that only those asylum seekers who really need international protection enter Europe. Reality, of course, does not interest those who want to gain or retain power by inciting hatred and fear. They have no solutions, but they do everything they can to prevent others from implementing the solutions. Lying demagogues, however, are doomed to defeat. We expect all Member States to live up to their responsibilities and to support this solution without reservation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Commissioner, Mr Avramopoulos, again "spectators in the same work", huge refugee and migration flows to Italy and Greece. Thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants have been trapped in the Aegean islands, clashes between various immigrants and all this now, in the summer, when there must be calm, in order for the tourist season to develop. Of the famous 66,400 relocations from Greece, according to what your report says, only 11,339 have been made, ie 17% of the relocations, when the program will end in four months. A number of countries are refusing to relocate, but the Commission has not taken action against them. Even Germany has not done what it owes. Only 12% of relocations have taken place in this country. In France only 22% of the relocations agreed. Finally, what will happen? Will the relocation process proceed? Neither Italy nor Greece can stand it anymore. There are now a large number of refugees who have to be relocated from these countries to the rest of the European Union.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the refugee issue obliges us, because it concerns lives, hopes and destinies. You recalled this in your conclusion, it is both an obligation and a moral duty. This moral duty and obligation oblige us to be correct, which quite simply means, from a legal point of view as well, that we must honor our commitments. All states must stick to it and it is not tolerable that some will simply decide not to participate in the decisions they themselves have made and made themselves. There are two absolute urgencies: addressing bottlenecks and reducing wait times for decisions. This is extremely important, not just for Italy and Greece, but for our European policies. Second, in the face of this situation, we also have a moral duty to vulnerable people. Priority must be given to children. In Europe, we cannot leave these children in court, prey to smugglers, smuggling and human trafficking. I have learned from reports that some states outright refuse to relocate these unaccompanied minors. This question of refugees raises questions about who we are. We have to live up to it.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the European Union's decisions on a refugee resettlement program have remained largely unenforceable due to the reluctance of some Member States to comply with them. According to the European Commission, less than one-fifth of the target of relocating refugees from Italy and Greece has been achieved. It must be understood that solidarity is a single thing enshrined in European treaties and is a commitment to the conduct of all Member States without exception and not an option. Although the Council decision on refugees defines the common position and cooperation of the Member States, in practice we do not see the solidarity required. These data, combined with allegations against some Member States of discrimination in the reception of refugees on the basis of their nationality or religion, do not respect the principles and values ​​of the Union and call into question its coherence. Accelerating the rate of refugee relocation is necessary while, at the same time, we need to create a fairer and, above all, more efficient framework for the reception and distribution of refugees for the coming years. We need immediate action, not excuses.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: - 160,000 people would be relocated from Greece and Italy to other Member States. It was an exercise in solidarity. Solidarity with refugees, solidarity among Member States. We are now two years later and of those 160,000, not much has come to fruition. To make matters worse, a new definition has also crept in somewhere. Any refugees who arrived in Greece after the deal with Turkey entered into on March 20, 2016 should not be resettled. Why not? Who came up with that? This Parliament has approved this relocation system three times and there was no clause in it. The deal with Turkey is a press statement. The agreement not to resettle has nowhere been put on paper and yet it is being carried out. Member states are not sticking to their numbers and are now being rewarded because they have to take in a lot less refugees. But they are still there. They are still people entitled to a new life. You can change the definition, you don't take people away with it.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let's face it, this situation is indeed a great shame. 160 000 people who had to be relocated and so far only 18 400 have been relocated. This means that 142 097 will have to be relocated by September. This is the solidarity of the European Union and, while everyone is talking about populism, intervening and a stronger European Union, we still see these situations. Italy and Greece have been chosen as refugee camps for the whole of Europe, I come from a region, Sicily, which is totally collapsing, in which politics speculates on the management of migrants. Yesterday around sixty people were arrested in Calabria who had to do with the 'Ndrangheta, with organized crime, who speculated on migrants and we continue to talk. So, the thing that needs to be done in this case is to move from words to deeds, to cut structural funds on the states that refuse to help. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8).))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Besides the moral duty of the Member States, as mentioned here by the Commissioner, do you not think that the Member States should also meet their legal obligations to accept migrants, and that perhaps it is time for the European institutions to think about imposing sanctions on the countries that do not accept immigrants?

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: answer to a "blue card" question.- Thank you for your question, Mr Frunzulicǎ, that is exactly what I was trying to say, running at the end of my speech.Unfortunately, with words, calling for solidarity and calling for legal obligations, we were unable to achieve anything, so we must probably change our attitude.Let's cut the European structural funds to those States that have not respected their commitments, that have not accepted to take the migrants who were relocated to their country.It can be done, let's do it.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, but look, I am a bit perplexed because, for heaven's sake, the subject is relocation and it seems to me that it is clear that up to now it has not worked much, but in reality we are talking about a small piece of a much bigger problem, which if it were only that of relocations would be a very positive thing, almost. It should be borne in mind that 180 000 people landed in Italy last year. Of these, there will probably be 5 percent who actually flee the war and who will manage to have the status of political refugee, so eventually it will be this 5 percent who will be relocated. The real problem is all the others. Is there a European plan to bring them home? What are we going to do? To leave them all in Italy? Is this the big problem nobody talks about and what are these people going to do in the end? Those who are illegal workers go to fatten up, they go to fatten the shirts of crime. Just this week people were arrested in my city who had applied for a political refugee but were going to steal, who were dealing drugs. So, let's face it clearly, it is a slave trade that we are seeing right now and unfortunately there is someone who is complicit, there are many people who do business and there is someone who is complicit, even those who do nothing to resolve this situation.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we know that the deadline for the implementation of the relocation decisions expires on 26 September. Nevertheless, we know that, despite the efforts that have been made, the program is underperforming. And it is underperforming for three main reasons: for those Member States that do not accept any refugees, for those Member States that selectively accept applications based on the refugee profile, for those Member States that take two or four months to respond to applications. In practice, we see that the results do not justify us. Only twelve and a half thousand have relocated from Greece and the target deviates significantly. At the same time, Commissioner, you know very well that the EU-Turkey agreement also has problems. Since last March 2016, when this agreement was signed, 23,000 new refugees and immigrants have come to Greece, while respectively only 1,000 have returned to Turkey. The problem is big and can only be tackled with very important decisions. Decisions that will be harsh to the detriment of the Member States that do not implement our own decisions and act completely out of control when they try them, and decisions, perhaps, that should extend the program so that it can be implemented, but also run smoothly in the permanent relocation mechanism, the one that will be able to provide effective and sustainable solutions to the problem.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of the 160 000 relocations promised in two years by Italy and Greece to other European countries, only 17 900 have been made. A shame, like the absence of the Council today from this debate. All while Canada, last year, resettled 35,000 Syrians in four months, with an ocean in between, demonstrating that Europe is not a problem of numbers or means, but only of national selfishness and lack of will. policy. Governments have not respected the commitments made, some have referred to the Court of Justice, others have tried to cast the applicants on the basis of discriminatory criteria or to put forward unspecified security needs to avoid welcoming them. To these Member States I would like to say that wanting the benefits of being part of a Union without ever wanting to share its responsibilities is childish. To this we must add that it is absurd not to have suspended the transfers to Italy and Greece of other applicants under the hypocritical criterion of the first country of access on which the Dublin regulation is based, which we hope to finally cancel in the ongoing review, just as it is absurd to relocate only nationalities with an average recognition of protection above 75, because it has produced real discrimination in the field contrary to the Geneva Convention. With all these limits that must be corrected, relocations must not stop, a new Council decision is needed to continue until a Dublin reform that makes a centralized and permanent mechanism for sharing responsibilities structural.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the relocation scheme has been a failure because Member States are reluctant to implement it, for reasons that are very understandable. This kind of immigration is extremely costly to their societies both economically and socially. We should abandon the concept of relocation and we should also abandon the idea that mass immigration to Europe is a solution to the problems of the Third World. What we need is a strict, Australian-style ‘push back’ policy at our external borders to stem the chaotic, illegal flow to Europe. Then, we need to give more support to the countries of origin, the countries of transit and the people in refugee camps.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, the Council has excused its presence, because it does not want to listen to us. They know that the European Parliament is going to spoil their attitude in the refugee crisis. They pledged to host 160,000 people by September 2017 and the global figure does not reach 11% nearing the deadline. Only Finland welcomes unaccompanied minors. The vast majority of countries, including my own - I sadly say so - are delayed while tens of thousands of human beings suffer a thousand atrocities every day or thousands die trying to reach Europe. Hungary has gone further, daring to say that she does not want to spend and that the sovereignty of her country is in danger if she accepts a quota system. Well, in 1948, after surviving the Buchenwald camp, Léon Blum expressed with terrible lucidity that considering the sovereignty of States as something indisputable and irrevocable led to war; that, in the name of that dogma, the League of Nations was deprived of all executive power. The dogma of competition and unlimited national sovereignty annuls, even today, ethics, destroys the authority of the European institutions and undoes us. They are not words. Sanctions are required for those who fail to comply.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, we already said that the quota system was not going to work and it was also unfair and insufficient. But we are seeing that it is not only unfair and insufficient: it is that not even the Member States comply with it. We are seeing how almost no member state has complied with something that UNHCR itself said was no longer enough. In fact, it is said that this year we would have to host a million refugees in the world ... and Europe does not comply, and that non-compliance is the clearest example of the political crisis of the European project. Spain, I think it is a paradigmatic example: of almost 19,000 people - 19,000 refugees - that we would have to host, we have not taken in almost 5%. This cannot be allowed and action must be taken. And I think you have to be clear in this regard. Here, in these European institutions, we have been told that austerity was mandatory and whoever does not comply with it is punished. We say why don't we change that rule, why don't we say that austerity is optional and compliance with human rights is mandatory; and whoever does not comply, may be penalized That could start to change things.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President! Thanks so much. In the autumn of 2015, a few countries in Europe received an extremely large number of refugees in a very short time. And reception systems collapsed, borders were closed and solidarity between member states was completely absent, and the whole EU construction began to shake. I live in two countries: Sweden and Spain. Two countries with diametrically different views regarding refugee reception. In Sweden, we received 163,000 refugees in 2015 against an estimated 80,000. We did not need to receive the entire quota of redistribution that was decided, because we had already received very many. But in Spain, where we have already heard what is happening - not many people are accepted there. But at the same time, we also know that the autonomous regions - several of which have prepared well - have said they want to receive refugees for a long time, but the Spanish Government says a resounding no. This is not how we can have it. That it is actually the case that the regions want, and governments say no. We must listen to the Spanish Government!

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: - Madam President! Redistribution, shared responsibility and solidarity - it sounds beautiful. But like almost everything in this building, it is built on dreams and hopes that will never come true. No matter what relocation solution there is in the future - because you really want to make all countries in Europe multicultural - it will fail. Sweden has had a gigantic migration for many years, and we are slowly but surely learning the lesson. Each relocation process will take many years, given that people stay, and deviate after they have been refused an already long process. The rejection itself will certainly be appealed and protested against. The tens of thousands who through fraudulent behavior will illegally linger in our countries are called by you "undocumented". Some will commit terrorist acts that took place in April in Sweden. Some commit acts of assault and violence, and in principle all will work illegally. What do they have to lose? They are already living in violation of applicable law. If you can not relocate more than 18,000 in two years, what are you going to do with the eight to nine million people who are expected to come from Libya in the near future?

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Madam President, in the European Newspeak, we refuse to call a spade a spade. The Union is modestly demanding relocations. In reality, it has decided on a settlement policy: 50 million migrants by 2060, according to Commissioner Avramopoulos' admission on June 8, 2015. The objective is twofold: it is, on the one hand, to bring in a low-cost workforce to enable companies to increase their profits and, on the other hand, to shatter national identities to turn citizens into docile consumers. The spearhead of this crazy policy is the Juncker Plan of September 2015, which requires the States of the Union to relocate 160,000 migrants who have arrived in Greece and Italy. This is obviously only the beginning and States have understood this; that is why many are resisting, like Hungary and Poland. I encourage them to continue their resistance, because each nation has the right to defend its identity against migratory submersion.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, we talk a lot about European solidarity, but we are not consistent. In two years more than one and a half million people arrived at our borders and the Member States agreed to relocate less than one hundred thousand during the same period, which is already a laughable number, and almost two years later, only 16% of that commitment was fulfilled, with unaccompanied children being particularly affected. There are even states that want to exclude themselves from this effort. Allow me, Madam President, to mention my country. Portugal expressed its willingness to receive more than 5 800 people than initially agreed. In total, the Prime Minister announced on a visit to the German Chancellor, Portugal is ready to receive 10,000 asylum seekers. Even before, civil society and the so-called third sector mobilized in an impressive and generous way. Now, Portugal hosted only 1,228 people, about a tenth of the goal set by ourselves. Once and for all, who is failing? Is it the Portuguese Government? Is it the European Commission? Or is it the fault of others? This Parliament has done everything in its power to reverse this course. We quickly approved the urgency mechanisms and budgetary reinforcements and present ourselves today, here, with a positive approach. The theme of this debate is, moreover, to make the relocation work. Let us be pragmatic in the diagnosis, see what is wrong once and for all and take resolutely all the necessary measures, all without exception. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Question under the 'blue card' procedure.Dear colleague, I listened carefully to what you said and, at least, I understood that you consider the transfer and relocation project to be perfect.I do not agree and I ask you: do you think that the success of this project does not require better communication from the Commission to the Member States?In order for the acceptability of the citizens to increase, we cannot say that, as the Commissioner said here, we must take care of the security of the Schengen area.And what should other states do: accept only refugees?Thanks.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- Mrs Grapini, I agree with you that better communication and better communication is better, but the problem is not there.The problem is with political will.There are Member States that do not want to collaborate with the relocation effort.There are Member States that do not want to do their part and this does not work.We cannot appeal to European solidarity and then it does not work.I agree with those who say that, in the absence of goodwill, perhaps, we really need a binding system, a mandatory quota system, a permanent relocation system.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, my colleagues have very carefully analyzed the responsibilities of the Member States and the Commission for the slowness of its relocation. Today I want to submit a specific proposal. In Greece at the moment, we host a little more than two thousand unaccompanied children: half in special accommodation structures, and the rest in safe zones inside the camps. Some of them, less than a third, are eligible for relocation as they are refugees from Syria, Iraq and elsewhere, and it is a shame that a Union of five hundred million people could not find a safe and permanent place for a few hundred children who have fled. from war zones. I am not referring to the promises for the relocation of the 160 thousand refugees or to the tens of thousands that are waiting, with all the papers ready, for the invitation that is coming late. I'm talking about a few hundred children, very few, who need to have security and stability in their lives. I would therefore propose to this House, in the context of the refugee conference which, as President Tajani stated, be held on 21 June in Brussels, that we commit ourselves to a statement: 'Children first, today!' and to demand from the Member States a small but important step: when autumn comes, no minor who is entitled to relocate is in Greece and Italy. A small step for the relocation, but a big step for the lives of these children. Commissioner, I would like your help to give this humanitarian message in practice: "children first, now!".

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: - Madam President, relocation and the system of redistribution of refugees to individual Member States do not work, that is probably clear. Of the 160,000 migrants under mandatory quotas, just over 10% have so far been accepted by Member States. The Slovak Republic, together with Hungary, brought an action, which was decided by the European Court of Justice. The refugee quotas were adopted in contravention of the recommendations of the representatives of the Member States. The decision was to be taken unanimously, but instead the majority declared a minority. On such a sensitive issue, and in a heated atmosphere, this has only contributed to an increase in support for extremist, anti-European and political forces in Europe. If it is confirmed that decisions can be taken without the consent of those concerned, this will result in the division of Europe and the frustration of the population of the smaller EU Member States. We cannot divide the EU into west and east, into disobedient and responsible ones, and ultimately we cannot circumvent the decisions of democratically elected governments and the will of the citizens. I would like to appreciate that the EU has set up hotspots, given the powers of the newly established European Border and Coast Guard and that great efforts have been made.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: - I am very pleased that this topic is being discussed today in plenary in Strasbourg.I just think it is a great pity that the Council is not here today.We have to look at the situation of the people on the ground.In the camps in Italy and Greece, 23,000 unaccompanied children live in inhumane conditions.I have visited such camps.There is no water, no access to healthcare, no school.These children are victims, not perpetrators.Europol said last year that 10 000 children in Europe go missing when they cross the border.Where are they?In prostitution?In another country?Were they killed for their organs?I want to make one plea here today.Each Member State must fulfill its obligations.Let's give priority to the unaccompanied minors.They deserve our protection.That's Europe.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner. From the outset, Hungary has taken the position that relocation cannot be mandatory, which is why it has challenged this in the European Court of Justice. However, 23 Member States have today voted in favor of a mandatory quota. Nevertheless, in just one and a half years, only 18,000 of the 160,000 migrants have been relocated. This demonstrates the inadequacy of mandatory quotas and confirms that any distribution can only be voluntary. The migrant resettlement program currently under negotiation and the prospect of punishment are also unacceptable. This is not the only way to enforce the principle of solidarity between Member States. Solidarity can also be expressed through border protection, law enforcement cooperation and humanitarian programs. Hungary has so far spent about 900 million euros on border protection and the Hungarian government is constantly expanding its humanitarian role in the Middle East. Mandatory resettlement is interpreted as an invitation for migrants and is also an encouragement to human traffickers. Therefore, as long as we allow hundreds of thousands of people to enter Europe without control, as long as we do not separate economic migrants from real refugees outside the Union's borders, any mandatory migrant quota or future mechanism on a similar basis will be counterproductive and unsuitable.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, it is a shame that the Council is not here, but a much greater shame is that every time the Council has acted little, late and badly in the wrong direction, meeting until the wee hours of the morning to make decisions We have said here, in all the official languages ​​of the Union: "What difference does it make if they don't want to comply?" They make decisions and vociferously breach them. There is a moral problem. Italy, abandoned to her fate. Thousands of deaths at sea, 180,000 people in accommodation camps in the receiving countries, with a Dublin Regulation that needs to be reformed. There is a political problem. It is not technical, it is a lack of political will, on the part of the Member States, to comply with European law. A legal problem, lack of legal means to enter the European Union without abandoning the mafias that traffic in people, lack of humanitarian visas. But also the absence of sanctions for non-compliant countries. Sorry to say. Spain, a country with host capacity, which flagrantly fails to comply with the figures committed by the Council itself, decisions later denied time and again by the Council. Therefore, the answer can only be one. And it has to be legal, on the part of the Commission: sanctions. Sanctions, at once, to non-compliant countries. Not infringement proceedings that last for two years, of purely moral content - a reprimand, a warning. No. Economic sanctions for non-compliant countries, which cannot enjoy European aid until they understand that the solidarity mandate is not a good wish; it is a binding legal mandate. It is in the Lisbon Treaty and the States have to comply with it. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Madam President!Mr mister!You have rightly pointed out, as have many of the speakers, that the countries of Europe are simply not agreeing - some openly, some practically - to this mechanism of compulsory sending of immigrants around Europe.The Lord says that solidarity is compulsion.Do you really think that in order to replace the idea of the European Union with the idea of the Euromaghreb Union it is worth initiating another crisis in Europe?

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: "blue card" response.- Mr Jurek ... How many times and in how many official languages have we had to explain that the countries that acceded to the European Union, ratified the Lisbon Treaty and committed to its entry into force, were accepting a binding commitment of solidarity inthe management of the external borders of the Union and the assurance of free movement within the Union.Solidarity is not a good wish, no;solidarity is a binding mandate.And this means that when there are immigrants who enter through a border and are in accommodation camps, in reception camps, a European response is needed, led by the Commission and compulsorily complied with by all Member States.And for non-compliant States, sanctions.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Again today, we must discuss the EU's proposal on the forced redistribution of migrants in Europe, and let us now, for the first time, be honest in this House and acknowledge that it has been a great failure. We have not succeeded in redistributing a fraction of the very few who were initially voted through the Council, and the only thing we have achieved is a huge division of the European Union. Greece and Italy say quite logically that they will not end up with all migrants crossing into Europe illegally. Northwestern Europe logically says that we do not want to be the final destination for all migrants who want to come to the richest and most rewarding countries if one is a migrant, and Eastern and Central Europe says that they do not want to repeat the mistakes that is committed in Western Europe. Let us now find a real solution to the migration problem. Let us implement an Australian push back model when we nevertheless have to acknowledge that there is neither the will nor the realism to receive millions of migrants and refugees here on the continent.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - First of all, let me react a little to my speakers. Ladies and gentlemen, do you think that if you tell someone to do something, it works in life? I have 4 small children. When I tell them they have to clean up, believe me, they never clean up. When I use the word must, coercion, sanctions, the child reacts by trying even harder to fight those sanctions, and I think that is the debate. Ordering someone to do something against their will is simply nonsense. I have already said, Commissioner, several times at this point that the whole relocation mechanism is simply one big utopian project. If this project worked, it would be that in fact only 30% of states refuse to accept refugees or submit to this relocation mechanism. Thus, according to my calculations, some 120,000 refugees would be divided, but simply 120,000 refugees or needy people are not divided. We have been talking about this system for 2 years. I think that this system is unnecessarily tight and we are clinging to it as the only solution to the migration crisis, but it is not the only solution to the migration crisis. Let's face it, let's face it, this system will never work. Solidarity, which is forced in the form of threats, will simply never work.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Madam President! I would like to remind you that the temporary relocation mechanism has not been supported by all Member States. The relocation was established by the Home Affairs Council to circumvent the unanimity rule of the Member States in the European Council. This is the original sin of this decision. The governments of Slovakia and Hungary submitted a complaint to the Court of Justice of the European Union, citing the principle of proportionality and institutional balance, and we in the European Parliament do not even wait for the judgment of the Court, as if it had already been passed. Perhaps we should be more respectful of the Court. Relocation is also rejected by a significant proportion of the societies of those countries that supported it. It is based on coercion both against the relocated persons and against those who are to receive them, and who also have their rights, which the Union seems to be forgetting. Therefore, the relocation mechanism is not and will not work.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Parliament, the Commission and the Council, and Europe as a whole, are playing a large part in their credibility on the issue of immigration. Parliament had hoped, pending the Dublin 3 amendment which will finally materialize shortly from now, that a solidarity principle would be applied between all the Member States, not leaving Italy and Greece alone in dealing with a migratory flow that does not has precedents in the history of our continent. We had welcomed the relocation plan with great enthusiasm, but today it is really embarrassing to comment on these figures: 18 000 relocations carried out, 11% of the project that was put forward by the Commission, the Council and Parliament. Italy was asked to make an additional effort on the issue of identifications, and this was promptly done. Italy was asked to create new hotspots, and this was done on time, but to comment today on the 5 413 relocations from Italy I think it is a really embarrassing figure. This cannot be allowed, the Member States have to respect the commitments they have made and, if this does not happen, infringement procedures must be started and extensive measures must also be found, Commissioner, to reach 160,000 relocations by 26 September 2017.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: - Madam President! The migration crisis tragically shows that some things are no longer working in the EU. We are really seeing these problems very closely here, and unfortunately it is being carried out on the back of poor people. Whatever the reason for migrating, they all have a reason. The EU started as a project of the citizens, and what did the majority groups in this Parliament do with it? You made a head project out of it! Theory solutions are being invented that do not work in practice because they are not accepted by the citizens and in some Member States. That is why we have to stop inventing theoretical solutions that just don't work. We have to rely on voluntariness, we have to rely on the fact that cooperation is found and that the agreements that have been made are then adhered to. I think it is extremely populist that some people in this House are now saying that penalties should be pronounced here if one does not keep to the agreements. Where are these penalties pronounced when it comes to the euro crisis? Everyone says: no, no penalties. We have to go back to what has been agreed.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - The refugee wave, which was strongest in 2015 and 2016, brought more than a million migrants and refugees to Europe.The European Union has set itself the goal of reallocating 160,000 refugees, and as we can see, only a good tenth of them have landed in the countries where they are supposed to go.We have problems on both sides, both countries that do not want to accept refugees and refugees that aim at six or eight of Europe's richest countries.All in all, it points to a particular problem and requires thorough reflection.There is also a general uprising among the people against the refugees from the country I come from, but the government has managed to bring a larger share into the country than the share of quotas fulfilled within the European Union.It was different when there was a crisis in Bosnia, when we admitted 70,000 people to Slovenia, that is, a reflection on whether the model is correct, and greater political will is needed to better implement this program.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the migratory crisis which by its size has turned out to be a real humanitarian crisis has registered, as we know, a deficit of solidarity and a failure to share the principle of responsibility, which not only puts The political stability of the Union is at risk, but which, unfortunately, is the main cause of the failure of the relocation program. Without the participation of all states, we will certainly not be able to achieve the objectives set by the program by September. I therefore believe it is essential not only to extend the relocation program, but to make it compulsory. And I really hope that sanction mechanisms should not be used because it would be really sad for all of us to witness this continuing lack of solidarity on the part of European countries. However, a European response needs to be given to the migration crisis. The financial support recently granted to Italy is an important signal of the recognition of the work done by my country, but we also need to speed up the approval of legislative instruments such as the asylum package and the Dublin regulation necessary for this.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, last week the Basque Lehendakari, in his visit to the President of the European Commission, recalled the willingness of the Government he presides and the society he represents to collaborate in the construction of the European project. It made proposals to reinforce social policy and, among them, one on humanitarian corridors for refugees that completes the plan adopted in its day in the Basque Country to welcome people who suffer and need help, but who do not arrive because, in this case , Spain does not host those it owes, while cities and regions - those who really provide services to these groups - have plans and disposition. For this reason, I ask the commissioner how this knowledge and attitude are integrated when planning policies, making decisions and executing programs related to these matters, because the attitude of many citizens and in the institutions closest to them has very little to do with it. with the lack of solidarity with which the States, from above, face this challenge. That is why the Council is not here. And for this reason, states that do not comply with the agreements already deserve sanctions.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, it hurts my soul to see how the Council, the Commission and even we talk about numbers - absolutely ridiculous, in any case, given the real dimension of what is happening - when we should talk about people.Who are we to deny a future to Saled or Denis, whom I met on Friday in the Mineo field?The Council adopted a system knowing it was not going to comply, a system that actually looks for who to expel, not who to receive.And in the meantime, all the people who arrived after March 20 are condemned to limbo, at least those who manage to survive the hell of the crossing, because many more people are dying than we think.Ladies and gentlemen, it is our past, and who knows if one day it might not be our future again.But do we really need to suffer in order to feel the suffering of these people?Ladies and gentlemen, they are not numbers, they are people.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, having held the debate today without the Council can frankly be described simply as a real shame, because on top of not fulfilling its commitments, it does not even show its face. Look, we have a very serious problem with the application of the mechanism. Of the 160,000 people who had to be relocated, only 12,000 from Greece and 5,000 from Italy. And, above all, the number of arrivals keeps increasing. I want to remember that, in Italy, in 2016 arrivals increased by 18% compared to 2015. And the option of starting to make agreements at the border and ignore what is happening with our refugees is not a viable option. You have to meet those quotas. And I am writing to the European Commission: faced with the flagrant non-compliance of the member countries, such as Spain, for example, which has only fulfilled 5.5% of what it had promised, you have two options: assume your failure and continue with the indignation of many people who do not understand this situation, or really, put their feet on the wall, be brave and start applying - as our Resolution will say - infringement procedures and sanctions to those States that do not comply.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, perhaps the Commissioner for Immigration Avramopoulos is concerned about his political survival, because only complacency is caused by the complacent attempt to show that the relocation program is working and being successful. The initial target of 160,000 people for relocation was reduced to 98,000, while it is very likely that it will not exceed 34,000, with a deadline of the end of September. In this way, the relocation of about 18,000 people in almost two years will be presented as a success. Proof of the absurd planning of the program of unsatisfactory deterrent measures and the doomed supposed control of migration flows, is the increase of illegal immigration by 36% in Italy in 2017, with a minimum percentage of illegal immigrants meeting the criteria for relocation. Those who accuse Europe of becoming a continent fortress, I would say they wish it were. Maybe then NGOs would not be allowed to cooperate with smugglers, but mainly Europe is being blackmailed by Erdogan's Turkey. In the end, those who accuse the Union of inaction may be right. Europe will soon become a colony of African and Asian illegal immigrants.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - The Commissioner has stated that redistribution does not work, but unfortunately it has not been said why.In May 2017, the Commission issued a table showing a very different approach.After all, the United Kingdom has decided on a consistent solution and is leaving the Union, and it is no secret that illegal migration and fears have been one of the main arguments for Brexit.Solidarity is the principle on which the EU stands.Refugees who need help, who are entitled to help, we need to help them and we have the capacity to do so.The Czech Republic has signed up to accept its capacity - less than 3,000 refugees - even though it has been outvoted.To date, unfortunately, this capacity has not been filled and I have information from the Ministry of the Interior that it is not just the reluctance of the Czech Republic, but the unpreparedness of refugees for this reallocation.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, two years have passed since your proposal to set up a relocation program. At that time, we welcomed her as a sign of solidarity. We hoped that, finally, the Member States and the Commission understood that refugee management was not limited to the countries of the region. Despite your good intentions, the result is not what is expected. Only 12,700 of the 63,000 refugees, as originally planned, have currently been transferred from Greece to other EU countries. At the same time, out of the 62,000 who are trapped in Greece, 50,000 are on the mainland and the rest on the islands of the eastern Aegean. I want to ask you, what will finally happen to the countries that refuse to participate in this program? Will they be punished accordingly? Also, after the summer when the decisions expire, what are your plans? What will happen to the countries at the external borders? Finally, this debate is taking place while reports have come to light that say that we have an increase in cases of sexual exploitation of refugees. That is why I co-sign the proposal of my colleague Miltiadis Kyrkou to give immediate priority to the new refugees for relocation.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, honorable Members, let me start by expressing my thanks for this very interesting debate. I would like to repeat what Ms Kyenge said, that there is no solidarity à la carte. We have said it many times; and as Ms Ska Keller said, solidarity is one of the tools and ways for showing unity in practice. Madame Griesbeck, you's avez, you's aussi, you are very much in tune with the moral aspect of relocation. Let me say that I share many of your views and I count on your continued support, as I said in my introductory remarks. Relocation is often reduced in numbers, but we should not forget that we are talking about people who are in need of protection. Our shared duty, moral and political, is to make sure that they get this protection as soon as possible and in a manageable way for the European Union. This is the essence of emergency relocation schemes. That is why our focus right now is to make sure that everyone eligible is relocated to all Member States before September. Member States that have not yet relocated anyone, or have not relocated for more than a year, should make progress immediately. If no action is taken within a month, we will specify our position on making use of our powers under the Treaties, and in particular on the opening of infringement procedures: I am very clear on that. Let me also say that I understand your concerns and remarks on the deadline and the future, but these relocation schemes have not been set up as an intermediary step in view of the reform of the Dublin system: they are an emergency measure. Of course, as we very clearly said, Member States ’legal obligations do not stop after September 2017: if you have an outstanding bill, you have to pay it. I also took note of your views on the opportunity to revise the scope of the relocation decisions. But, as I said, our priority at the moment is to relocate all migrants in need of protection who are currently eligible. We need to focus on that objective. If all Member States actively contribute, this is perfectly possible and feasible - and I count on you to help us make it happen. Let me now shift to Greek since my compatriots have asked me some questions. Dear Greek MEPs, give me the opportunity to say a few words in our language on this very important issue for Greece, which, as we said earlier, is at the forefront together with Italy, with the result that these two countries accept the greater pressure. Regarding the situation in Greece, I would like to emphasize that, if the Member States finally meet their obligations, it is entirely possible, as I said earlier, to relocate, by September, all the candidates in Greece, about 12,400 people. I would like to emphasize here that Greece has completed all the procedures and, if this good cooperation continues, we will achieve our goals. As I said, some Member States are not cooperating and, at this point, I would like to say that tolerance and patience are now running out. I firmly believe in the value of understanding, dialogue and persuasion. So we had to start and that's what we did. But now we have reached a tipping point. The proof that this strategy is yielding end results is that relocation rates have increased significantly in recent months. But, as I said at the beginning, if there is no compliance, the Commission's next step will be, and you have no doubt about it, to support its policy both politically and legally. As for the European Union-Turkey statement now, I would like to tell you, because some comments were heard earlier, that it works and operated even under stressful and difficult conditions, with significant results and, as some of your colleagues referred to figures, I want to tell you that about a year and two months ago, there were up to 12,000 crossings a day, while this number has now dropped to an average of 50 to 60 people and we must keep this agreement, this conciliation, alive. Returns, on the other hand, to Turkey continue. Yesterday I was in Athens and had a meeting with the competent ministers of the Greek government and, I do not hide from you, that I was pleased to be informed about the acceleration of these procedures as well. And finally, as Mr. Kyrkos rightly pointed out: yes, unaccompanied minors are indeed our priority. This message must be sent to all Member States because, especially from Italy - I think some of your Italian colleagues have touched on it - not enough minor relocations are taking place. Finally, I would like to note that there is progress on this point as well. In any case, the debate that is taking place here today has shown that the European Parliament supports the relocation policy and the efforts of the Commission, and at this point I would like to commend the work of the Greek MEPs, but also to express publicly the My thanks to the European Parliament for supporting our policy. From the very first moment you have been the main supporters and finally the success of our policy will be judged by your contribution, which fully corresponds to the spirit of the Treaties and to the deeper moral and political content of the decisions and policies that we have jointly adopted. .

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing.- There is no doubt that a global strategy on the issue of migrants is needed.To try to stem the crisis, in the summer of 2015 we took two emergency decisions to relocate thousands of refugees.Frontline states such as Italy, Malta and Greece have already done their homework in terms of hospitality.My country has rescued more than 625,000 migrants since the beginning of the exodus.In 2016, the number increased eightfold compared to the last three years.Now it is up to the other states that are part of the Union to participate in a solution in line with a welcoming duty.Four Member States are accepting very limited numbers of migrants, while two are refusing to participate in the redeployment.The concrete application of the principle of solidarity, evoked by the Treaties is decisive!If we do not know how to respond to this emergency we will have failed the primary task of our Union.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: signed up. - Relocation and relocation are necessary policies to resolve the refugee crisis, but we must also consider prevention. When there is a safe fire we act to put out the fire, but then the cause and who is to blame must be verified. The fact that we need to protect 23,000 unaccompanied minors cannot be called into question. Children must be protected! But did anyone analyze how the unaccompanied children ended up? What do we do to stop appearing? Then the process of migrant transfer does not have to be one-way. The Commission must clearly establish how asylum seekers will be repatriated. And then, Commissioner, you need to clearly communicate a common policy on the security of European citizens. You cannot continue to ask all states to accept migrants, but to talk about ensuring the security of the Schengen area alone. My country is not unjustly part of the Schengen area. What can I explain to my fellow citizens about the obligations to receive migrants, but at the same time about their exclusion from security measures? I think as a humanist that the rights and obligations must be the same for any European citizen.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: in writing. - The head of the Catholic Church, Pope Francis, has been appealing for active help to refugees for months. He calls on all Catholics to show support to those who escaped the cruelty of war and not to turn from their tragic fate. Poland is an overwhelmingly Catholic country. 87% of Poles consider themselves believers. The ruling party, led by the PiS president, Jarosław Kaczyński, very often refers to Christian values ​​and flaunts its religiousness. Meanwhile, their attitude to the refugee issue is filled with hateful rhetoric calculated for cheap applause, thus promoting xenophobic or even racist attitudes. How to interpret the words of Jarosław Kaczyński saying that refugees spread worms and other diseases? The same hypocrisy and cynicism are presented by the most important PiS politicians, incl. Prime Minister Beata Szydło, Minister of the Interior Mariusz Błaszczak and President Andrzej Duda. Like other PSL MPs, I do not agree to fixed relocation quotas for refugees. At the same time, I do not agree to refuse to help mothers with children, orphans, and minors who are in Greece and Italy. Of course, you cannot force anyone to come to a given country, but I believe that Poland, in the name of human and European solidarity, is able and should accept people who need our help the most.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Commission celebrates in its latest report on the record number of refugees relocated in March. And he considers the 16,000 relocations that have taken place to date a success, even though the original goal was to relocate 160,000 refugees. How long will states continue to refuse to host refugees, thus violating fundamental EU principles while reinforcing the forces of xenophobia and racism in the Union? How long will their racist criteria be tolerated? Amnesty International warns of inhumane conditions for refugees. But the EU is proving to be inferior to showing practical solidarity and humanity! If we are to deal with the refugee crisis, equal responsibilities must be shared. Repeal the Dublin 2 Regulation. Immediately terminate the refugee exchange agreement with Turkey. Take action against states that do not live up to their commitments and establish a permanent and equitable refugee resettlement system. And most importantly, the Union should stop supporting wars and foreign interventions because they create waves of refugees.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on capitalizing on the globalization process to 2025 (2017/2655 (RSP)).

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, on the subject of globalisation and trade links with Beijing, I got back from there only a few hours ago, and if I look tired it is because of the long flight from Beijing. Today we are discussing the reflection paper on harnessing or shaping globalisation. We are not passive in this regard, but rather an active operator in shaping or harnessing globalisation. This is the second of five planned reflection papers to steer the broad debate on the future of the EU further, following publication of the White Paper on 1 March. It takes an honest look at what globalisation has brought to the EU. The fact is that, even if the EU has greatly benefited from globalisation, this means little to our citizens if the benefits are not shared fairly and more evenly. The benefits of globalisation are numerous. People travel, work, learn and live in different countries. They interact with each other on the web, sharing their ideas, cultures and experiences. Students have online access to courses run by leading universities across the world. Countries can produce more for less by specialising in what they do best and exploiting economies of scale. International competition and scientific cooperation have accelerated innovation. European exports have grown as customers worldwide demand the high—quality goods and services we supply. Eighty percent of our exporters are small and medium—sized companies so the beneficiaries of global value chains are those European SMEs and their workers. Actually, EUR 1 billion of exports supports 14 000 jobs in the EU. Imports are equally important as 80% of them consist of raw materials, capital goods and components necessary for the EU economy to function. Globalisation has also helped lift hundreds of millions of people out of poverty and has enabled poorer countries to catch up.  But globalisation also brings challenges. The benefits of globalisation are not shared evenly between regions and people. Many Europeans are concerned that globalisation is leading to inequality, job losses and social injustice or to a lowering of environmental health and privacy standards. For instance, countries with lower wages, environmental standards or taxes have increasingly competed with Europe in low-skill and low-value-added segments of industry, leading to factory closures, job losses or downward pressure on our workers’ pay and conditions. Some foreign companies and governments have engaged in unfair trade practices, such as dumping, tax evasion or subsidisation, that can lead to overcapacity and unfair advantages. These strategies deprive EU governments of tax revenues and contribute to unfairness. Many citizens consider that globalisation and uncontrolled migration directly threaten their identity and way of life. Citizens are anxious about not being able to control their own future, let alone the future of their children. These concerns must be recognised and addressed. However, the solution lies neither in isolationism, which has led to disastrous outcomes in the past, nor in laissez-faire politics.  The evidence presented in the reflection paper shows clearly that globalisation can be beneficial where it is properly harnessed. The EU must ensure a better distribution of the benefits of globalisation by working together with Member States and regions, as well as with international partners and other stakeholders. Together we should seize the opportunity to shape globalisation, in line with our own values and interests, in order to respond to its opportunities and challenges.  The question is how to do so, and it is vital to have an open and wide-ranging debate about that. The reflection paper offers some ideas in this respect. On the external front, the paper focuses on the need to shape a truly sustainable global order, based on shared values and a common agenda. The EU has always stood for a strong and effective multilateral global rulebook, and it should continue to develop this. For example, the EU could push for new rules and higher standards to create a level playing field by addressing harmful and unfair behaviour such as tax evasion, government subsidies or social dumping. Effective trade-defence instruments and better enforcement of domestic and international rules could also help the EU to act decisively against countries or companies that engage in unfair practices. The EU’s progressive trade and investment agreements should continue not only to open markets in a reciprocal way but also to enhance global governance on issues including human rights, working conditions, food safety and environmental protection. On the domestic front, the paper insists on the need to protect and empower citizens through robust social policies and to provide the necessary education and training support throughout their lives.
