This will equip people for the future and will redistribute wealth more fairly. The paper also underlines the importance of ensuring that Europe remains a competitive and innovative economy that will allow it to maintain its leading role in the world. This requires a vision for the future, in order to modernise our economy by embracing digitalisation, technological and social innovations, decarbonisation and the circular economy. It also requires smart specialisation, smart digital, industrial, tax or innovation policies and an improvement in the business environment. The EU cannot achieve all of this by itself. It is a shared responsibility, not only of the EU and the Member States but also of regions and municipalities throughout Europe. The main word we have to assess carefully is ‘resilience’. What are the policies needed in order to strength the resilience of our people – our citizens – and also our Member States?

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, the concern of our fellow citizens about globalization is very great and it is this concern that feeds populism of all kinds in Europe. We saw this again recently in France, during the campaign leading up to the presidential election, where extremes totaled 40% of the vote in the first round. I therefore congratulate the Commission, which seeks to provide education on Europe’s place in the world and on the concrete responses to be implemented. The European Union must live with globalization, but it must master it and it is essential not to turn in on ourselves. However, the European Union must actively defend itself to avoid suffering the harmful consequences of globalization which is sometimes savage. Furthermore - you said this, Commissioner - fairness in the sharing of benefits is essential. We must therefore urgently speed up the modernization of the Union, our economy and trade defense instruments so that the case of steel, for example, is not isolated. We need to be more ambitious on reciprocal access to public markets and support our industry rather than buying what we produce in Europe elsewhere. Our companies must be able to compete on an equal footing internationally, our jobs depend on it. By 2050, no single European country will be one of the ten largest economies on its own. The European Union therefore finds there a major reason for existing. How do you negotiate a trade agreement when you have a derisory economic weight against countries like China, India or the United States? This is where European competence in this area is very essential. That's why I would have liked us to be more ambitious, because your concept paper is a good thing, but it does not go far enough. I will have We wanted a concrete action plan on subjects as essential as the control of foreign investment in strategic areas - this is what guarantees jobs - because employment is indeed the only social response for our fellow citizens.Globalization will only be happy if the European Union is not fearful of the challenges facing it.

name: Jeppe Kofod
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group, I would like to congratulate Vice-President Katainen and First Vice-President Timmermans. With this reflection paper, the Commission is putting its finger squarely on perhaps the greatest challenge facing EU citizens: harnessing globalisation. Former UN Secretary-General Mr Kofi Annan captured the challenge before us when he said if globalisation is to succeed, it must succeed for poor and rich alike. It must deliver rights no less than riches. It must provide social justice and equality no less than economic prosperity and enhanced communication.  Globalisation has created enormous wealth. However, it has not been fairly shared. Instead, it has been enjoyed by a privileged few. Globalisation has spread industries, trade and services but it has also put established rights, standards, values, wages and even jobs under enormous pressure. When 45% of Europeans feel threatened by globalisation, this is not a challenge. It is a problem. And let us be honest. Unmanaged globalisation creates real problems for ordinary citizens. Real wages for middle class Europeans have stagnated or even decreased, and youth unemployment remains close to 20% in the euro area. While citizens bear the burden of austerity-only policies and reduced welfare, the world’s richest companies and individuals pay as little as 0.005% in tax, as was the case with Apple in Ireland. Since 2015, the richest one per cent of the world’s population has owned more wealth than the remaining 99%. This is not harnessing globalisation. This is globalisation run amok.  The latest Eurobarometer shows that 74% of Europeans want more EU action against tax fraud. Let us take our cue from them. Let us act now. Therefore, I propose that the Commission develop a public ‘harnessing globalisation’ scoreboard. Let us make it crystal clear what the EU is doing to harness globalisation. When we adopt the EU blacklist on tax havens with strong sanctions, when real wages across Europe stop rising, then we will see real change. So I hope you will establish this scoreboard and I think you should do it right now.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Katainen! You are of course right: globalization is a blessing for humanity. The countries that cut themselves off from it are far worse economically than the countries that take part. We see this in Cuba, for example, or North Korea or, more recently, Venezuela. Let's not forget that globalization brings not only goods, capital and services around the world, but also values, ideas, human rights and democracy. That's right! The supposed losers of globalization, such as countries in Africa, suffer because globalization passes them by; they do not suffer from globalization. That is why I think that we should stop looking at the European navel in this Parliament and look at the whole world. A beautiful Portuguese song has just won the European Song Contest, but not a European one. Our companies in Europe have long been thinking nationally and globally, but not European. Have you heard of a European car market? I do not know him. There is a Japanese car market, a German, an American, a British. So let's stop further deepening the European Union, let's strive for the completion and expansion of the internal market, and let's invite Great Britain to do so right from the start!

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, how to make globalisation a win-win and avoid a race to the bottom is the billion euro question. In recent years, trade agreements have been hotly debated and I remain convinced that the EU should lead in promoting rules-based trade as a frame around globalisation. This frame of rules must always be based on our fundamental principles and high standards, and take off the sharp edges that globalisation can indeed exacerbate.  The Commission’s Trade for All strategy and the globalisation paper published last week map out what this leadership should look like. We must be rule makers, not rule takers. I believe there is room for more focus on the impact of technology on jobs and inequality. As much focus as there has been on trade, we hear little about the future of work, as well as the significance of maintaining the rule of law in a hyper-connected world. Here, too, the EU must be a global leader, especially as the US retracts, including when it comes to setting norms in the digital economy and digital trade.  But that is only part of the picture. The EU Member States should take much more responsibility for redistributing the macroeconomic benefits of access to third country markets more evenly at home, to re—school, redistribute and innovate as much as possible. Why do we not see a white paper from them? Indeed, let us not overlook how globalisation and interconnectedness around the world has lifted hundreds of millions out of poverty and creates mutual dependence, which contributes to greater stability. Europeans benefit from globalisation. Our smartphones, clothes and many different foods would not be in our homes and lives without it. Let us make sure we look at the impact of globalisation and the technological revolution in a comprehensive way and avoid a race to the bottom. Let us meet the challenges by finding solutions, not in isolation or protectionism, but by taking this a step forward.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen! The term globalization describes a production method in which very large companies define the end product and set up internationally optimized production and value chains for it. Let us be aware: It is people whose fates are linked in these work processes. 150 years ago Karl Marx wrote in Capital about the necessary adjustment of the relations of production to the development of the productive forces. We must ensure the quality of life for everyone along the value chain and create the regulatory framework for it. This applies to employee rights, to human rights, to the protection of nature in production. This also applies to taxes and thus the fair contribution to the common good from an economic chain. We need to introduce a broad duty of care for products that enter the EU market. Whoever wants to achieve the greatest profit at the end of a chain must be made responsible for the production conditions. I particularly appreciate that the Commission emphasizes the new objectives for sustainable development in its paper as a benchmark. We have to define this in our legislation and standards. Sustainable development defines the framework for economic development - everywhere.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Commissioner, Mr President, you have just discovered that globalization generates losers. Bravo for your lucidity. You have just discovered that globalization is twice the size of the planet, that there is twice as much predation on resources, twice as much pollution. Bravo for your foresight! You have just discovered at your expense, thanks to the Court of Justice of the European Union, that one cannot make a trade policy against the citizens who had mobilized through petitions against TAFTA and against CETA. You have just learned the hard way, thanks to the Court of Justice, that one cannot make a trade policy against national parliaments. But what you propose is always the same thing: either globalization, that is to say to continue - by doing a little better, by communicating a little better - to put the territories, the employees and the choice of society and, thus, to build the extreme rights, that is to say isolationism and the extreme rights which, moreover, in Great Britain today, want only free trade. There is a third way. It is to subject trade policies to climate policies like the Paris Agreement, to health issues, social rights and democracy. So there, Europe will protect the ... (The President cuts the speaker off)

name: Rolandas Paksas
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group.- Mr President, colleagues.It seems to me that we are debating an issue that is wrong in a sense.If globalization creates prosperity for society, there should be no negative consequences.If we are going to acknowledge otherwise in advance and discuss the negative consequences of globalization today, then we must a priori accept that European and world politicians at the appropriate level fail, have failed and are unclear whether they will be able to protect society from the negative effects of globalization in the future.So it could be much more interesting today not to discuss the harm of globalization, but to consider a global referendum on the approval or disapproval of Community members' methods and monopolies on transatlantic companies, on global companies at least as much as small and medium-sized businesses.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group.- Mr President, Commissioner, you are showing absolute cynicism.You have deliberately thrown the peoples of Europe into the most dizzying, the most dangerous globalization with your absolute free trade policy and the myriad of treaties you have imposed, with your policy of migratory submersion which aims at the collapse of Europe.identity of our nations and of European civilization, with your submission to diplomatic and strategic interests which are not those of nations or continents, from the Atlantic to the Urals.So when you hear about the ravages of globalization, do your mea-culpa first.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, the Commission has turned a blind eye for more than 20 years to the harmful consequences of globalization. She was one of the active craftsmen, performing it extremely zealously, and she admits today that there can be problems. This is good, but very insufficient. If I read the concept paper published last week, I see it only as a reaffirmation of the inevitability of globalization, its mainly beneficial character analyzed in a purely accounting way. The future actions that we are designing, apart from an increased steering of national policies, are above all the continuation of current policies. As long as you remain in the system of the World Trade Organization, in the system of a generalized free trade of free movement without control of people, goods and capital, you will not be able to protect Europeans from the harmful effects. globalization, starting with those resulting from unfair competition from low wages and slavery jobs outside the European Union.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Globalization is taking place, and you can either really go along with it or leave it right. We experience a country in the world that does not participate, namely North Korea. The fact that the people in North Korea are so dirty is due, on the one hand, to the despicable dictator, but also to the fact that the country is completely sealed off and people have no access to the international flow of goods and the advantages thereof. So if we want to participate in globalization, then we have to shape globalization. That is exactly what we as the European Union have been doing for a long time. Our companies benefit: cars, champagne, vegetables, fashion, we sell all kinds of products from European production all over the world, and on the other hand our citizens, our consumers, benefit from a huge range of products from all over the world. Anyone who briefly thinks about what they have bought in the last few days and weeks and where it comes from knows very well that globalization is something that, if done correctly, can have huge advantages. What we de facto need is orderly globalization. We should consider together how we can get away from some of the misdirections that we have about our concepts. We mostly call our agreements free trade agreements. But the issue of opening up markets is only a tiny part of our agreements these days. As a rule, our agreements are agreements to regulate globalization, to regulate trade relations, to enforce our standards and precisely address the concerns and needs of our citizens. With that in mind, I would like us to work with the Commission to further develop our trade policy.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: - The reflection paper of the European Commission contains interesting starting points.The Commission is often wrongly, but often also rightly accused of only being concerned with liberal ideas.It is very important that limits are set now.Interestingly, social and environmental standards should be placed on an equal footing with economic principles.It is also interesting that in the European Union we need to invest much more to make our people resilient and to enable a fair distribution of wealth.However, dear Commission, we must be careful not to write just interesting notes.Recent research shows that the population remains pro-European but has serious doubts about the solutions that Europe offers.Butter must be added to the fish.In other words, we need to rethink our trade agreements, investment policy and tax policy within the European Union in a completely different way.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for this paper, but it is not before time. Often, the debate on globalisation is polarised. On one side we have the gung-ho supporters of free trade, regardless, and on the other we have the protectionists, for whom no trade deal is ever right. For me, this is the challenge of our generation: to manage globalisation so that free trade is fair trade. As you said, Commissioner, this must ensure that the benefits of trade are distributed fairly among our citizens. But in the last decade this has not happened in the EU. While our economy has grown overall, real incomes of middle-class households have largely stagnated. Commissioner, some of the messages to be sent to our citizens are contradictory. We, for example, have extra-judicial courts to enforce investors’ rights but no binding mechanism to enforce environmental standards, health and safety standards and decent work conditions. However, I do welcome this paper and the work done by Commissioner Vestager in trying to ensure that large corporations pay their fair share of tax, a crucial element for fair globalisation. At EU level, investment in universal broadband access allied to lifelong learning will be essential if EU citizens are to benefit from globalisation. Finally, as rapporteur for the Globalisation Fund, I believe it has a role to play in providing a safety net, but it must be adequately resourced and sufficiently flexible so that it is available to workers in the SME sector. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much for taking the question. It was an excellent speech, if I may say so: a lot better than we normally get around here. You actually mentioned large corporations paying their share of tax. What do you think of the way that the Government of Luxembourg has handled this issue over the past 10 to 15 years? I just wonder if you have an opinion about that.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – This is a global issue and probably can only be solved at a global level, and the OECD is doing some excellent work there with their BEPS project. Commissioner Vestager is pushing out the boat at European level and that needs to be done. A number of governments in the EU need to look at this issue to ensure that the mismatches between tax systems cannot be exploited by large corporations. I think all governments have a responsibility, but some more than others. I am not going to mention names.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL).
text: -  Sir. Chairman! Globalization has great advantages and great disadvantages. There is no doubt that a great many people have gained more freedom and more wealth from the great changes, but we must not be blind to the shadowy sides of globalization. We have groups of people who have really lost at crucial points: they have lost their jobs, they have lost the opportunity to support their families, and not least, they have lost faith in a better future. This does not mean that globalization in itself is a bad thing, but it does mean that we must restrain it far better today than we have done so far. In this context, it must be said that the EU's economic policy has helped to pull developments in the wrong direction. We must strengthen the trade unions, we must not break their right to bargain, as we have done in Greece. We must strengthen the social safety net and not undermine what the EU has demanded through recommendations in a large number of countries, and we must create new jobs by investing and not by cutting back and down, as the Fiscal Compact requires. When citizens lose faith in a better future, we seafarers must take it very, very seriously.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: - Commissioner Katainen has presented here plans on how the European Commission wants to manage globalization by 2025. In my opinion, this is essentially a nonsensical idea.We can adapt to globalization, trade, the contracts that individual companies, individual people make with each other, but not fight it.When I heard the Commissioner define himself against the laissez-faire of the free market and how other speakers defined themselves towards the free market, I feel that I am probably the only one here who upholds the principle of laissez-faire free market.When I listened, Mr Scholz even quoted Karl Marx here, others called for blacklists of low-tax countries, etc. So I have a feeling that, regardless of the political party, only the Socialist itself, the Communist, only the Commission, are sitting side by side.there is an exception, there are the socialists themselves side by side.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: Economists, multinationals, bankers, politicians and the media have for years overestimated and exaggerated the benefits of globalization while putting the drawbacks into perspective. The Commission now acknowledges half a page that globalization also has negative effects, but then nevertheless concludes that there is no going back. What in the meantime is going wrong in European industry, is being filled with yet another Globalization Fund to camouflage the pain of the most controversial factory closures. In this global world there is always someone who somewhere wants or has to sell his labor for less money and less social protection. Hyper-globalization leads to an economy in which products are made by children's hands in the East and consumed by supporters in the West. The result: starvation wages in low-wage countries, unemployment in the west and environmental pollution from transport. We need a new economy that exploits the opportunities of the free market without isolationism but also without naivete. In short, an economy for our own European population.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, quite unexpectedly the countries of the European Union have come under strong attack from globalization and the peoples have realized that their national, social, economic, religious and cultural existence is in danger of being destroyed. So we have to react. First of all, states must strengthen their internal cohesion, preserving the principles and values ​​of their history and culture. The European Union must also change the way it is today. The union of peoples and nations must be re-established, so that it can care with love for the citizen, deal with his problems and protect him. The countries of the European Union must work together in equality and solidarity, so that the European Union can formulate an economic policy that will allow it to conclude beneficial agreements with other states. It must work with the other world powers to stop wars, to stop illegal immigration, to develop third countries and, finally, to enable the European Union to uphold its values. We must, in order to tame and curb globalization, accept any of its positive aspects and control them, because as the ancient Greeks used to say, "no evil is pure good".

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Dear Colleagues, the European Union needs to be united to seize the opportunities and simultaneously overcome the challenges arising from globalization. Only together, in a coordinated, concerted manner, will we be able to model, control and regulate globalization. Proudly alone, the protectionism defended by radicals on the left and right is not a solution, it breaks solidarity and increases poverty. The European Union must act together and in solidarity to impose reciprocity and fair and fair competition. In the European Union, we must invest in knowledge, innovation and research, in the fight against poverty and inequality. At the same time, we must export the values ​​of democracy, respect for human rights, the defense of social and environmental rights. We cannot be afraid. Together we will be able to leave a better world for generations to come and modeled globalization will allow for more quality of life for all the inhabitants of the planet and, evenly, it must always be on top. Avoiding social dumping, avoiding inequality is something we can achieve and we have an obligation to achieve it, all united.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! It is very clear that we are at the beginning of a debate about globalization - how we can manage globalization fairly. I think it is good that the Commission is also adopting an integrated approach, taking into account the external and internal dimensions, although I still see an imbalance between points three and four, with the external being given greater focus and the internal ones certainly being focused again could evolve a bit. Of course, external trade policy is one of them! And the question that we are not just tearing down trade barriers and then letting the world take its course, but wanting to set rules, that is explicitly formulated, and I think that is right and good. It is also correct that the European Court of Justice said today in its judgment on the Singapore Agreement that sustainable development, workers' rights and environmental standards are an integral part of trade policy and that compliance with them must also be used as a yardstick for further steps must have consequences for future trade agreements.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, we have known for a long time that the so-called globalization, made possible by the acquisition of science and technology, is not neutral from a political point of view. This globalization corresponded to the expansion and consolidation of capitalist production relations and to the affirmation of capitalism as the dominant economic and social formation on a planetary scale. The effects of this globalization are the effects of the system that produced it. Its contradictions are also the contradictions of the system that produced it: the contradiction between the social character of production and the private appropriation of the means of production, the contradiction between a system that either grows and accumulates or dies and the limits of a land that, being generous, it is finite. The increasing concentration of wealth in the hands of a tiny minority has, on the other side of the coin, the globalization of the exploitation of man and nature, poverty, exclusion, illiteracy, disease and war. The European Union is an agent of this globalization. Socialism is the only way out.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, reading between the lines, the Vice—President of the Commission seems to think that the EU can, like a kind of King Canute, roll back the tide of globalisation. Well this is of course not only not true, but also absurd. Now my new great friend as of the last four years, the Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström, was at one time apparently a psychiatric nurse, and it would seem that these psychiatric skills are badly needed within the Commission. I hope that Cecilia Malmström will have a moment to administer to her colleagues.  At every voting session here in the European Parliament, colleagues vote for rules, laws and regulations that inhibit innovation and destroy jobs, and the direct consequence is low growth, or zero growth, or even minus growth such as that which exists in Greece and Italy. I can see that the Vice-Commissioner finds that very amusing. This is not the way to deal with globalisation. You should think again.

name: President. –
text: I hope that if the Commissioner accepts your suggestion she will have an assured place of work in Europe!

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the reflection document presented by the Commission last week comes at the right time to feed our overall reflection on the future of Europe by 2025. Globalization is a necessary fact. of course integrate into our analysis as a potential opportunity to be exploited, rather than presenting it as the source of all the ills of our society. Of course, to say that globalization is the source of all evil is a mistake. This causes withdrawal into oneself, the rise of populism of all kinds and the return of protectionism which - this is the paradox - does not protect enough and is an illusion. To talk about protectionism today is really a bit lacking in reason. To take full advantage of this opportunity offered by globalization, Europe must invent a special identity for itself and, from the point of view of foreign affairs - which I deal with on a daily basis - that means promoting enhanced international cooperation. to establish an international order based on rules and high standards. The opening of markets and technological advances do not contradict the protection of human rights and the protection of well-being. This is our philosophy. I believe that the European Union is a successful example of economic openness based on rules and on this protection of rights. We have a duty to take the leadership role and continue to champion this combination of open markets and rights. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: question "blue card".- Mr President, dear colleagues, my dear colleague, you have spoken out against protectionism.Do you admit, however, that, in accordance with secular custom, customs duties - which have never completely prevented trade - can, for example, offset the advantage that would result, for an exporter, from the low wages he practicesinternally?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: answer "blue card".- I think your question stems from a misunderstanding of what the market is.As Mr Henkel, my colleague from the Conservative Group, said earlier, the market is the movement of goods, people or ideas and everyone benefits from the best they have.Sometimes it is interesting for a worker to accept a lower salary than where you live, if he comes from Bulgaria or Romania, for example.Sometimes it's a Frenchman who wants to promote an idea that has not yet been invented in Poland or Latvia.The result is this complex reality that we call the market.They are goods, people, and everyone benefits from the best they have - a capacity for work, for thought, for invention.This is the deal.That's not what you want to do by isolating one country or another.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: - I have read with great interest the piece “Managing globalization” because there is indeed a tension between the winners and the losers of globalization. So, as far as I am concerned, we can really see the Commission's reflection paper as a turning point. No longer are merely emphasizing the benefits of free trade and globalization. The Commission is now putting forward proposals for fair trade and for protection against unfair competition. As far as I am concerned, we must also achieve enforceable social and environmental standards in future. At the same time, we must also be clear: the Commission is not in the Member States' seats. The Member States, in particular, have many instruments at their disposal to ensure that we arrive at a fair distribution of the burdens and benefits of trade in the world. Increased wealth is redistributed through taxes, benefits and allowances. So I would say tribute to the Commission for initiating the debate, but also call on the Member States to strengthen their prosperity, because that is what needs to be done now.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, over the last decade we have talked mostly about unheralded crises and emergencies, but we cannot use these words when coping with globalisation because it is a long-term challenge and opportunity. We must look at the big picture when working on the future of Europe. Today our duty is to persuade European citizens that we must resist our own European backlash against international trade and international trade agreements and be involved in shaping globalisation. A lot of answers to the globalisation challenge are to be given at national level. I am thinking here of education and training and of coping with inequalities and exclusion. Industries based on the new drivers of growth must go global to be competitive, but we also need an educated discussion on our role as Europe in shaping globalisation. Only then can Europe deliver as the best possible vehicle to make globalisation work for us. A big question is whether a future EU—US global leadership on rules—based, open, fair trade in a multilateral framework is still possible. We must work on it. But of course, globalisation is much more than trade. Neither Europe nor the US can profit from global uncertainty or instability or weak global governance that is not relevant, efficient, transparent and accountable. Let me conclude by saying that sustainable globalisation can happen only through cooperation among outward—looking partners.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to thank the Commission for this document on globalization, a process which is in fact the reality in which we live and which must undoubtedly be governed, we have finally realized this. In the meantime, it is good to understand, when we talk about globalization today we are increasingly dealing with a global competition based on the capacity for technological innovation to face the challenges of a linear economy that no longer holds up the current consumption of the planet's resources and is able to to market products and services that can better respond to consumer needs. In short, in order to return to growth and to continue to guarantee our precious welfare system, we must therefore position ourselves in the key high-tech sectors. To do this, we must firmly focus on investments, fresh resources in research and innovation and help businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, the heart of our system, to renew themselves and on the other hand, however, implement social protection policies for those excluded from this process and policies that know how to redistribute the benefits to the entire segment of the population. Europe has the dimension and the capacity to be a protagonist in this scenario if, however, we immediately begin to implement concrete actions.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Vice-President, controlling globalization means above all creating fair and fair competition. All economic players must respect the same rules. We no longer want this naive Europe which opens up its markets for nothing. The Commission is finally starting, but timidly, to talk about reciprocity. It is high time it made it a pillar of its trade policy, as we have been calling for for many years. Our unity must be our strength and we must demonstrate this by acting in concert. We must also fight against all forms of dumping, be it social, environmental or fiscal, and therefore I hope that discussions on the modernization of trade defense instruments will soon be concluded and will allow them to be strengthened. Finally, I would like to remind you that it is with this in mind to master globalization that we, along with my colleagues in the PPE Group, have called on the Commission to legislate on foreign investment. We cannot let foreign investors take control of strategic sectors in Europe any longer. The Commission absolutely must follow up on this approach as quickly as possible.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Commission paper on harnessing globalisation says that the EU must pursue a progressive trade and investment agenda which not only opens markets but enhances governance on issues like human rights, working conditions and environmental protection. Many of us have been vocal in opposing certain EU trade proposals like EPAs, ISDS and TTIP, CETA and others. However, we need to recognise that the EU is the only large international actor, which makes it a stated priority to advance on progressive social values. This is an agenda that we must defend and strengthen by emphasising, for example, the decent work agenda and the alternative trade mandate. In the meantime, my own government in the UK is desperately trying to strike up shameful trade deals and arms deals at all costs with various serial human rights violators, such as Saudi Arabia. I am very afraid that a Brexit led by Tory Britain would not be a progressive force in this world. Britain must continue to work with the EU regardless of Brexit to advance progressive social and benign globalisation for the good of all of us on this planet.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE).
text: - Mr President, globalization brings opportunities but, no doubt, it also brings challenges. It is the reality that has brought progress for all, but also difficulties for many, difficulties that populism exploits: it takes advantage of those who wonder what the use of having an iPhone if they cannot have a job. Europe, on the contrary, gives them answers. I'm talking about the Adaptation Fund, which helps those who lose their jobs; I am talking about cohesion policy, which works so that no one is left behind. But this is not enough. Cohesion policy must continue to be Europe's glue because it constitutes Europe's solidarity, and the rest of the tools used must have added value. Globalization must be reconfigured based on social policies, as was stated in the Rome Declaration last March. So let's get going without wasting a single second. For this reason, I believe that the Commission is correct with this reflection, because globalization cannot serve only to have an iPhone; it should also serve to ensure that our regions have work.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: - Mr President, we are faced with the challenge of saving globalization from itself.The wave of nativism - protectionism with authoritarian overtones - that has swept the West during the last year and a half is directly related to the discomforts caused by globalization.International trade has lifted hundreds of millions of people out of poverty - it is undeniable - but, at the same time, it delves into inequalities that are tearing us apart and generates not a few losers: the losers of globalization.If we want to continue enjoying open societies, it is necessary: one, to impose clear, sustainable and demanding rules on globalization, at the same time as restoring the compensation mechanisms to distribute its benefits.To protect the political liberal dimension of the Enlightenment, which is currently in check, the only way is to restore our social model.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Vice-President Katainen, ladies and gentlemen, we are here today to discuss how we can share the benefits of globalization, but, above all, we must respond to the fear of those excluded from globalization. The figures in the Commission's reflection paper show the dimensions of the great challenge of globalization. One billion euros in transactions, 14,000 jobs. At the same time, however, 45% of Europeans consider globalization to be a threat, while 53% see it as a threat to their homeland's identity. In my opinion, we must move forward immediately. First of all, in the regulation of the European Union's relations with its international partners and in the strengthening of the regime of control and sanctions of the illegal activity of foreign companies in our territory and internationally. Secondly, the substantive exchange of good practice between Member States in new sectors of the economy, such as e-commerce, the circular economy, new materials, in order to increase overall competitiveness. Third, education should be done with a view to the future, with an emphasis on the internationalized activity of our pupils and students. And fourth, to have specific indicators for Member States that use funds to tackle unemployment, to see how the unemployed are integrated into production and how sustainable jobs are created. Only then will we be able to push citizens to overcome their fear of a future they cannot plan for.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: - Mr President, after so many years of blindness and naivety, the European Commission finally recognizes that liberal globalization can also have negative effects and contributes to creating strong inequalities between those who earn a lot and those who suffer from it. phenomenon. It is the first time, finally, that it has emphasized the need for reciprocity in public procurement and investment, but also on trade defense instruments. In my opinion, we must now move from words to deeds. Yes, it is possible to have progressive trade agreements, but that requires more rules, more environmental standards, more social standards and more democratic oversight. Yes, it is possible to protect European industries, but for that, you have to be bold enough to introduce a "Buy European Act", as all great nations do to protect their businesses. Finally, if we are to truly regulate globalization, we must tackle the root of the problem, which is tax optimization and tax evasion. To do this, we must include tax conditionality in our trade agreements to create a more just world. Therefore, it is time to take action.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Commission for this important reflection paper that represents food for thought for all of us considering the future of the European Union. Many Europeans, particularly young ones, see how being connected with people in other countries and continents can improve their lives. They are right to do so. Around a third of national income in the European Union comes from trade with the rest of the world. But, at the same time, many Europeans are also apprehensive. They see globalisation as synonymous with job losses, social injustice and low environmental health and privacy standards. Now is therefore the time to consider what the European Union can do to shape globalisation in line with our shared interests and values, to ask what we can do to protect, defend and empower European citizens, especially the most vulnerable, and to agree on how the European Union, from its institutions to Member States, regions, municipalities, social partners, wider civil society, businesses, universities and its international partners, can come together to harness globalisation.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I believe that no one questions the benefits of globalization, but to combat the malaise that is occurring in our societies I suggest three things that seem important to me. In the first place, I think that a protection system is necessary for the economic sectors most vulnerable to global competition; I think our trade agreements have not done it enough to date. Secondly, I believe that it is essential to protect the least qualified work, which is the one that suffers the most from social dumping, from globalized competition. Unskilled work needs legal protection - minimum wages, minimum income. This is a measure that must be incorporated into European policies. And, thirdly, I believe that Europe has to be the head of international movements to extend human rights, as a minimum floor for expansion into productive globalization; that all the countries of the world have a minimum production floor with minimum labor rights.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - President! Globalization is a historical process that cannot be stopped, but can be controlled, even regulated. What is needed is not a meaningless anti-globalization, but an adaptation based on and based on European values. There is no doubt that globalization has many winners. But let's talk about the losers now. Those who feel they are losing everything that was important to them in this changed world, their jobs, their social esteem, their place in the world. That is why we need to shape globalization in such a way that it is an opportunity not just for individuals but for everyone. The situation of people who have already been disadvantaged and have lost their jobs must be actively helped, for example through targeted support, training and social care. And above all, we must resolutely and clearly confront the populist policy that, taking advantage of people's fears, wants to put Europe back at the dead end of nationalism, economic protectionism.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, first of all let me also say that I very much welcome that the Commission has come up with such a reflection paper. This is because I think it is the first time that the Commission is actually also acknowledging there are problems around globalisation. I think that is a very good thing. It is a very good start. Unfortunately, we see little action, let us say, in the paper. There are a lot of very important words, like realising concerns and pointing out the right problems. That is all very nice and very fair, but I think – as colleagues have also said – that we should move forward to action. We need concrete things. In other reflection papers there was more concrete action – we would say not enough, but there was some – but I think here, on globalisation, concrete action is missing. Let me mention some areas where I think we can move to direct action. Firstly, to end the race to the bottom between Member States when it comes to workers’ rights. Let us think about posted workers. I think it is very important that we safeguard the rights of all workers inside the European Union. Let us also review trade agreements. It is possible to do them in such a way that benefits European Union citizens as well as the citizens in our partner countries, but for that we really need to change the way in which we do trade agreements at the moment. We also need to lead the fight against climate change. We should not wait for others to follow the path or maybe also do something, but we need to be more ambitious in targeting the reduction of CO2 emissions, because we have no time to waste. If we lose our planet, there is not a second one we can go to. We also need to get serious about fighting tax avoidance and tax evasion – because I think those are key issues when it comes to social justice – by making sure that big companies which greatly profit from globalisation pay their due share and making sure that we can also afford investment, for example in education, good social services and sustainable jobs. I think here the European Union can really do something, because no nation state can deal with those issues alone. We need the European Union, but we also need to make sure that we do concrete things.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the benefits of globalisation in both rich and poor countries are often invisible, easily taken for granted and easily forgotten in times when people are feeling distressed about it. As is rightly pointed out in the reflection paper, globalisation is an overall positive force for change in Europe for wide groups – exporters, consumers, students, researchers and so on – and it has also lifted hundreds of millions of people out of poverty across the globe.  Globalisation is a fact, and there is no magic on-off switch to it. Even if we closed borders to trade, capital and people, it would not solve economic inequalities. Instead, it would definitely cause more harm. Eastern Europeans with experience of Communism know that better than most. What we should do, however, is to upgrade our policies, which have not kept pace with the opening of markets and technological disruption. We have done far too little up to now to make globalisation work for everybody. It is time to change that.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I am glad that the Commission has taken the step of presenting this document and putting this debate on the table, because obviously globalization is a reality, protectionism is not the solution and what is an option is how we want to be. And, of course, if globalization is not fair, if it is not inclusive, if it does not distribute equal opportunities, if it does not distribute the benefits for all and if it leaves someone behind, what will be is the end of a future for the many millions of people who see their situation threatened, because they do not see employment capacity in that future. And globalization, as the name suggests, requires global politics. I agree with the Commission's position that a position by the European Union is not enough. All national, regional and local governments have to be involved, but all the Commission's policies as well. If industrial policy, innovation policy and social policy do not work hand in hand to provide employment opportunities and protection for people, I am afraid that we will not win this battle.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, globalization processes have brought a number of positive things, but they also have certain negative manifestations such as job losses in Western countries.Unfortunately, I am afraid that European countries, as well as companies, have not always reacted appropriately in an attempt to protect their prosperity.We must not fight the economy with cheap manual labor by restricting the flow of goods or the freedom of our citizens, but by introducing more technologically complex production processes and producing more sophisticated, ie better, products.Workers must also be invested in.This is the task of employers, but also of the workers themselves, who must understand that today it is almost impossible to enter and leave the labor market with the same occupation and competencies after several decades.Member States can and must help by facilitating retraining, but also by reducing the tax burden in order to give workers and employers more money to invest in knowledge and skills.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: - Mr. president. I thank them for the study, because they face the hallmark of the 21st century, which is globalization. However, they point to the need for multilateral rules with executive force. But wich ones? How? Because, indeed, we must act on the social and we must act on human rights worldwide. But there is another question: not to lose the European rules with executive force. The Council has not come today, because it has failed on the issue of its own agreements on relocation issues. And it seems to me that the study is missing a section that is very, very important: democracy and geostrategy in a globalized world; also a historical map on democratic regimes, and a qualitative one on caudillismo or how democratic regimes formally accepted as such are degenerating. And there is another issue that also seems to me to be missing: multinationals in the digital revolution and their tension on executive power in small countries, and on taxation and tax evasion. We need all these issues in order to better assess what you are pointing out, which is a bit naive.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - The issue is indeed so global that it cannot be addressed in all aspects.I would only focus on two in my post.In a globalized world, I see the issue of reciprocity as crucial for trade relations.Indeed, it is very important that third parties, if they gain access to the European market, so that the EU and its Member States receive some specifically measurable benefits in return.Even in the field of human rights, if we are talking about a wide range of issues, human rights violations in neighboring states, it is important that we can enforce our vision of human rights precisely in connection with, for example, access to our market or disadvantage.One thing concerning dumping.I would really like to call for this, if we insist on very strict criteria for certain products admitted to our market, so that we also insist on these criteria for third parties.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: - Mr President, in 2011, an OECD study indicated that globalization created inequalities. Today, in 2017, I thank the Commission for effectively recognizing these inequalities. However, the concrete response of the Commission does not go in the direction of a better control of globalization. On the contrary, it gives a boost to a dozen free trade agreements built on the global model of the years before the 2008 crisis. There is a certain form of inconsistency between your thoughts and your actions. . The Commission, it seems to me, is trapped in the ideology of maximum openness while others here in this chamber are reclusive in total closure. In my opinion, these two paths are dangerous because they destroy well-being. However, there are methods to master this globalization. If you are short of ideas, I will give you some: for example, tax conditionality, the fight against dumping, with the mandatory sustainable development chapter accompanied by sanctions, or the protection of investors, but not against the forces public. Today, not all of these ideas are concretely supported by the Commission and, therefore, we are disappointed.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, it is too late for the Commission to wake up to the adverse effects of neoliberal globalization, which has literally dismantled the state economy, led to armies of the poor and unemployed, and increased the socially excluded. It led to the relocation of companies, to outsourcing, it made the rich richer, it led to the formation of triangular relationships, tax evasion and tax avoidance. Because that is the reality. And you have to understand that you have to go back to the principle of Community preference, which was the basic principle on which the EEC and then the European Union were built. European industry should be supported, as well as the agricultural sector. We should also fight for fair trade and not have this impunity with the TTIP and CETA you insist on. Tackle unfair practices. There are countries, such as China, where prisoners also work. There is child labor and we tolerate this process of liberal trade. This situation must finally end.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, I think you will like what I am just saying now. I liked the sincerity with which you presented globalization, opportunities and challenges, dangers. It is an analysis that I see as very sincere, but it obliges you, Commissioner, to convince the Commission that the internal market of the European Union is suffering. I have said it before and I say it today: trade agreements must be made on a win-win basis. If we have this imbalance in the trade agreement, SMEs will first be shattered, European Union producers will suffer and, ultimately, consumers, because high European standards are good for consumer protection. But let's check the market entry by the same standards and not let counterfeiting, counterfeiting three times, on price, structure, composition, brand, which in fact leads to job destruction and consumer unprotection. Please, Commissioner, convince the Commission that trade agreements must be made in this spirit.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members very much for a very wide—ranging discussion. It was good that Members brought many different dimensions to the discussion.  First, let me say a couple of words about the nature of the paper. This is not an action plan. This is a reflection paper, one of five reflection papers intended to promote wide discussion, not only here but also in Member States, amongst the stakeholders – national parliaments, governments and also NGOs and various organisations. We need to give direction to our policies on how to shape globalisation. My second point is that the EU itself is an example of rules—based globalisation. We are a product of globalisation. We deliberately decided to create a borderless Europe where people – students, the labour force, whoever – can travel across borders without any difficulty. We have created Erasmus, the single market – which is, by the way, a free-trade agreement – and common action towards climate policy, and we are about to create the circular economy regulatory environment. So this is what globalisation is in Europe, and we should take this elsewhere as well, shaping globalisation so that it is rules-based and based on values we believe in. Many Members rightly stated that we should not send out the message that the EU, Parliament or the Commission can address all the negative effects. In fact, many of the tools which need to be used are in the hands of the Member States. Education and social policies, for instance, are in the hands of Member States. I will give you a couple of concrete examples of what Member States can do. We have to strengthen the resilience of individuals and societies. There, for instance, the quality of education and the quality of teacher training is of the utmost importance. The better quality education we have, the better prepared our citizens are for changes. I like the word ‘resilience’ because it means that, whatever happens, we are resilient in facing challenges and we are strong enough and innovative enough to harness the negative effects of globalisation. Many Members, quite rightly, raised the issue of trade policy. This is part of globalisation. Globalisation is not only about trade, but trade is part of it. For instance, the EU—Korea trade agreement was agreed some five or six years ago, and since then our trade has increased by EUR 15 billion euros. As we know that EUR 1 billion of additional trade or exports support roughly 14 000 new jobs, increasing trade to Korea has supported some 200 000 jobs in Europe. I will put this figure in a local context. The country I know best is typically considered to have a Nordic high—cost welfare society. Regardless of high costs and a welfare-society structure, a well—known European car manufacturer established a factory in Finland. This was possible because of robotisation. I do not know which part of the world the robots’ components came from, but nevertheless robots made it possible to produce cars in a high—cost welfare society. The town in which the factory is situated is the town with the highest number of robots per capita, and it is the very same town that has the highest number of vacancies per capita. So this is another example of globalisation. Also, thanks to our trade agreement between the EU and Korea, those cars manufactured in a high—cost welfare society can be sold to Korea. That is just one example. Another example come from Sweden. You may remember that when the car manufacturer Saab went bankrupt, some five years ago, it was a big shock to the town of Trollhättan, where roughly 3 000 people lost their jobs. Since then, labour unions, together with employers’ organisations, public authorities and the private sector have worked together, and today three out of four people who lost their jobs have found a new job and the unemployment rate is lower than it was before the bankruptcy. Thanks to active policies and action at local level, they have managed to create new opportunities for citizens. My final point is that we must be a shaper of globalisation. I very much liked it when some colleagues said that we should be not a rule-taker but a rule-maker. That is why the Commission has proposed an external investment plan, because we want to influence sustainable development in our developing partner countries, for instance in African countries. The better we manage to support inclusive economic growth in Africa, the less reason there is for irregular migration and, of course, quality of life and fairness will increase in those countries. I hope that you will bring this discussion to your constituencies, promote a forward—looking discussion on globalisation and try to identify which policies are in the hands of the Member States or local authorities and which policies are in our hands here, as European legislators and decision makers, which should be taken forward in order to shape globalisation in a positive manner.

name: Președinte. –
text: The debate was closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: written. - Europe has one of the most open economies in the world, and trade with our partners has generated much wealth and jobs. But elsewhere in the world, our companies all too often encounter limits. We should be less naive. The time has come to stop the excesses of wild free trade and one-way traffic: not with closed borders, but above all through a fair playing field and the protection of our crown jewels. We must not just let our power plants, airports and telephone networks fall into the hands of aggressive state-owned companies from outside the EU. The EU must pursue plans, supported by Germany, France and Italy, to monitor and, if necessary, halt any possible outside investment in European strategic sectors. Globalization also means shipping merchandise from one continent to another (and sometimes back again). That may be cheaper now, but is it still if we take the environmental costs into account in full? In contrast to Europe (via ETS and non-ETS), this impact is much less or not settled in other continents. This must be brought up urgently, even if others in the World Trade Organization do not want to participate.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - As socialists, we have long insisted on the need for the Union to place among its main priorities a more courageous and ambitious management of globalization in order to ensure that the benefits of this phenomenon are for all and not just for a minority. Therefore, we welcome the presentation of the Commission document that serves to open a period of reflection and that, as an essential step to reach a solution, recognizes the negative impacts that globalization has on our societies. However, in its analysis, the Commission puts too much emphasis on markets and not enough on people. The Union can, and must, protect European workers against unfair competition and social dumping. There must be no victims of globalization, neither in Europe nor in the rest of the world. To do this, we must ensure that our values, principles, rules and standards shape globalization and not the other way around. Only from a strong Union will we manage to harness and harness globalization, reaping the benefits of closer ties between countries and continents, while protecting our citizens and their jobs, and promoting sustainable global growth.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – Developed countries have led the way in many of the new technologies. However, competition will increasingly come from emerging economies that are rapidly moving up the value chain. The divide between more technologically advanced regions and those that are less advanced risks widening unless governments invest in education, equip their citizens with the right skills, encourage innovation, ensure fair competition and regulate smartly where needed.  If globalisation is to succeed, it must succeed for poor and rich alike. It must deliver rights no less than it delivers riches. It must provide social justice and equality as much as economic prosperity and enhanced communication.  A more interconnected world will bring new opportunities as well as increased threats, so there should be an upgrade of our policies, which have not kept pace with the opening of markets and technological disruption. We have done far too little up to now to make globalisation work for everybody. It is time to change that.  I welcome the Commission’s Reflection Paper on Harnessing Globalisation as I believe globalisation can be beneficial where it is properly harnessed.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written. - As socialists, we have long insisted on the need for the Union to place among its main priorities a more courageous and ambitious management of globalization in order to ensure that the benefits of this phenomenon are for all and not just for a minority. Therefore, we welcome the presentation of the Commission document that serves to open a period of reflection and that, as an essential step to reach a solution, recognizes the negative impacts that globalization has on our societies. However, in its analysis, the Commission puts too much emphasis on markets and not enough on people. The Union can, and must, protect European workers against unfair competition and social dumping. To do this, we must ensure that our values, principles, rules and standards shape globalization and not the other way around. Only from a strong Union will we manage to harness and harness globalization, reaping the benefits of closer ties between countries and continents, while protecting our citizens and their jobs, and promoting sustainable global growth.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. - Humanity has often experienced forms of cultural and economic interdependence between different societies and cultures active in geographic areas that are very distinct from each other. The globalization that affects our time, however, presents unprecedented characteristics due to exceptional factors such as the new telecommunications, internet and modern means of transport. Economic crises, political changes but also the rapid succession of fashions and the spread of new consumer goods today have the ability to spread and influence the communities of every nation on the globe in an extraordinarily short time. From an economic point of view, globalization certainly has the great merit of having saved millions of people from poverty and misery. It is equally true, however, that globalization has also involved a less equitable distribution of wealth, as well as serious alterations in the labor market. I therefore believe that Europe today has the ambitious task of managing to lead the phenomenon of globalization, in order to derive all possible benefits for citizens and businesses, while at the same time eliminating the collateral effects on society.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: written. - As socialists, we have long insisted on the need for the Union to place among its main priorities a more courageous and ambitious management of globalization in order to ensure that the benefits of this phenomenon are for everyone and not just for a minority. Therefore, we welcome the presentation of the Commission document that serves to open a period of reflection and that, as an essential step to reach a solution, recognizes the negative impacts that globalization has on our societies. To do this, we must ensure that our values, principles, rules and standards shape globalization and not the other way around. Only from a strong Union will we manage to harness and harness globalization, reaping the benefits of closer ties between countries and continents, while protecting our citizens and their jobs, and promoting sustainable global growth.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: written. - For some time, we Socialists have been insisting on the need for the Union to place among its main priorities a more courageous and ambitious management of globalization in order to ensure that the benefits of this phenomenon are for everyone and not just for a minority. There must be no victims of globalization, neither in Europe nor in the rest of the world. We must ensure that our values, principles, rules and standards shape globalization and not the other way around. Only with a strong Union will we be able to harness and harness globalization, reaping the benefits of closer ties between countries and continents, while protecting our citizens and their jobs, and promoting sustainable global growth. Therefore, we welcome the presentation of the Commission document that serves to open a period of reflection and that, as an essential step to reach a solution, recognizes the negative impacts that globalization has on our societies. However, in its analysis, the Commission puts too much emphasis on markets and not enough on people. The Union can, and must, protect European workers against unfair competition and social dumping.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: in writing. - Globalization is one of the most important challenges facing Europeans. And while it has contributed to economic growth in the EU, its benefits are neither automatic nor evenly distributed. Its effects include relocation of industry and an increase in unemployment in the common market. The EU should strive to create new, fairer rules of operation in the global market: address tax avoidance, state aid and social dumping. There should be a fair tax system so that global corporations cannot avoid paying their fair share of taxes where the profits have been made. Effective trade defense instruments and trade reciprocity (reciprocity) could help in this process. Social protection must be strengthened and the emphasis should be on education and training to help citizens adapt to changing global conditions. European industry and, of course, the workers they employ must also be better protected. The EU should be a kind of guide and actively promote trade based on fair rules. We have to make the rules, not follow rules set by others.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written. - As socialists, we have long insisted on the need for the Union to place among its main priorities a more courageous and ambitious management of globalization in order to ensure that the benefits of this phenomenon are for all and not just for a minority. Therefore, we welcome the presentation of the Commission document that serves to open a period of reflection and that, as an essential step to reach a solution, recognizes the negative impacts that globalization has on our societies. However, in its analysis, the Commission puts too much emphasis on markets and not enough on people. The Union can, and must, protect European workers against unfair competition and social dumping. There must be no victims of globalization, neither in Europe nor in the rest of the world. To do this, we must ensure that our values, principles, rules and standards shape globalization and not the other way around. Only from a strong Union will we manage to harness and harness globalization, reaping the benefits of closer ties between countries and continents, while protecting our citizens and their jobs, and promoting sustainable global growth.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: written. - As socialists, we have long insisted on the need for the Union to place among its main priorities a more courageous and ambitious management of globalization in order to ensure that the benefits of this phenomenon are for all and not just for a minority.
