To do this, we must ensure that our values, principles, rules and standards shape globalization and not the other way around. Only from a strong Union will we manage to harness and harness globalization, reaping the benefits of closer ties between countries and continents, while protecting our citizens and their jobs, and promoting sustainable global growth.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: in writing. - Europeans must possess high-quality education and professional skills in order to face the rapidly changing economic and social reality. The constant development of acquired skills and competences is nowadays essential for finding and keeping a job. To achieve this goal, our actions should focus on improving the access, quality and effectiveness of education and training. We must ensure professional and personal development opportunities for all citizens at all ages. Our policy must be geared towards empowering citizens and their ability to adapt to the changes brought about by the processes of globalization and digitization. In particular, we should focus on ensuring equal educational opportunities for all. The fight against unemployment among young people and the strengthening and rapid implementation of the European Youth Guarantee, the scope of which should be extended to young people up to 30 years of age, are also of key importance. Subsequently, the budgets of key education programs, such as Erasmus + and Europe for Citizens, should be increased so that goals can be achieved more effectively and equal opportunities can be promoted among young people. We cannot forget about the values ​​that unite us. In this context, it is important to develop the EVS and define its legal status, taking into account the rights and obligations of volunteers.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! In recent years, right-wing governments have been unable to put globalization in the interests of the people. Anyway, we can say that right-wing governments have simply been defeated by globalization, they have let people down. This is especially true in Hungary. Now these governments and parties are trying to campaign so that they can still protect people from the harmful effects of globalization. Do we believe them? I do not think so. We need a governance in both the European Union and Hungary that can really tame globalization. It can stop jobs going abroad, dumping cheap products. We need a policy that can eliminate the worst by-product of globalization: social inequality. However, the solution is not the border lock, the wire fence, the protective duties. These can give a false security image, but in reality only make the situation worse. Will the wire fence stop cheap Chinese products or reduce our dependence on Russian gas? I do not think so. We simply have to be better than the Chinese or the Russians. We need innovation, a knowledge-based society, education, businesses, not hungry farms. It doesn’t go overnight. The traditionally strong Hungarian gray stock is there, it is up to us what we start with.

name: Eva Maydell (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the Commission’s Reflection Paper on Harnessing Globalisation and their efforts to make this central part of the discussion on the future of Europe. I also congratulate the successes of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund but I am concerned about its long-term orientation. For my generation there is no doubt that managing globalisation successfully means riding the wave of digitalisation and technological innovation. This can be both empowering and disruptive for our labour markets but it is a sine qua non condition for success. Europe needs to focus on two priorities. First we need to equip our citizens with the skill necessary for the global workplace. Those are digital competence with higher profile. Mainstreaming training programmes for digital skills is the way to go. Already today 90% of all jobs require some level of digital skills. Second, in the age of internet of things, robotics, artificial intelligence, Europe needs to have a regulatory environment unlocking the potential of data flow, and even more, making Europe an incubator for innovation. Here we will be stronger if we move together and not as separate Member States. Completing the Digital Single Market is the step that we should take now.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – No one was ready or prepared for the outcome of globalisation! In the beginning, we saw globalisation as an opportunity for countries, companies and people to travel, expand, grow and connect. Only later on did we recognise the wide range of economic and social spill-overs that affected all parts of our lives and people all over the globe.  Lack of control, mismanagement, misguided development policies, the race to the bottom and the lack of rules associated globalisation with job losses, social injustice, squeezed living standards, rising inequalities and low environmental, health and privacy standards. The globalisation backlash has led to political disenchantment and an increase in the protectionist movements and populist politics that were the leading force behind a few elections’ outcomes, as well as the Brexit referendum. In today’s world, isolation is definitely not the answer and global cooperation is increasingly important. However, we need to realise that modern capitalism, not managed in way that can benefit all, makes people restless for not being in control of their own lives and their own future.  Globalisation requires a new institutional architecture and a new moral ecology, and I am afraid that unless we take active steps now, populism, radicalisation, and xenophobia will continue to spread across our countries.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I congratulate the European Commission on presenting a document on globalization and launching an open debate. The growing fears of citizens about globalization and its threats are felt everywhere, and the positive aspects of the phenomenon of globalization identified by the Commission do not dispel those fears. It is not enough to discuss, we need to prove to our citizens that we are not passive observers of the globalization process and that we are able to meet the expectations of our citizens, and to take the best from the globalization process. Of course, we don’t have to shut ourselves in, but we need to learn to defend our interests more effectively. Concrete solutions are needed in tax policy, education and the labor market in order to better control complex social, economic and cultural processes. A more appropriate and wider application of the principle of reciprocity is needed. A socially sustainable and competitive knowledge society must enable its citizens not only to respond flexibly to changes in the labor market, but also to use globalization as an opportunity to expand borders, learn about cultures and work together to create the new world of the future.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: in writing. - It seems that we have not sufficiently taken into account the changing external conditions in the Union. The world is now developing independently of Europe, even though we have been unable to come to terms with it for a long time. It has changed, among others the approach of the new White House host to European affairs. Although recently it has become friendlier than it was suggested by the campaign announcements, it is certain that it will not be like in previous presidencies. The processes of globalization and the functioning of the world market require the establishment of certain rules in the field of trade or the operation of financial institutions that would create a certain order, because otherwise uncoordinated actions will lead to chaos, as exemplified by the recent economic crisis. Hence the important role of EU diplomacy, including economic and trade diplomacy. Even the president of the United States does not seem to be able to stop globalization. Despite the US withdrawal from the Pacific Agreement (TPP) and the suspension of talks with Europe (TTIP agreement), international trade continues to liberalize, as evidenced by, for example, subsequent trade agreements negotiated by Europe, including with Mercosur (Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay), Japan, Mexico, Australia and New Zealand, or the entry into force of the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) under the World Trade Organization (WTO) at the beginning of this year.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - It is positive that the European Commission is now openly admitting in its reflection paper on "Harnessing globalization" what many have been saying for a long time: globalization has not only advantages, but also many disadvantages. The difference is striking between word and deed. This is sometimes subtly apparent from the Commission's choice of words: “Many Europeans are also concerned. They associate globalization with job losses, social injustice or low environmental, health and privacy standards and fear that globalization will erode their traditions and identities. ” This is not a mere perception, but a bitter socio-economic and ecological reality. The Commission says that after this debate we will be better able to "provide sustainable and fair solutions that meet the expectations of European citizens." That remains to be seen. Because the urge to conclude bilateral free trade agreements of the type CETA and TTIP continues unabated. These treaties, it has already been extensively demonstrated, will not contribute to more sustainable and social standards. This kind of free trade policy does not lead to a race-to-the-top, but a race-to-the-bottom. The EU would be honored if it recognized this inconsistent attitude.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: signed up.- I am convinced that the process of globalization will not only continue in the years to come, but will also accelerate.Those politicians who believe that they can protect jobs through some measures to limit the effects of globalization will soon find that such measures are ineffective.If at the end of the last century, globalization was accelerated mainly by the collapse of the socialist economic system and the unprecedented expansion of the market economy, now this process is being pushed further by technological progress.Consequently, the European Union must support the training of the workforce, capable of meeting the requirements of globalization, modern infrastructure and innovation.In this way, Europe will remain attractive for investment and business and will not become an open-air museum.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: written. - As socialists, we have long insisted on the need for the Union to place among its main priorities a more courageous and ambitious management of globalization in order to ensure that the benefits of this phenomenon are for all and not just for a minority. Therefore, we welcome the presentation of the Commission document that serves to open a period of reflection and that, as an essential step to reach a solution, recognizes the negative impacts that globalization has on our societies. name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The so-called globalization, made possible by the acquisitions of science and technology in the last half century, has never been neutral from a political point of view. Globalization today is an instrument at the service of the dominant classes with few winners who continue to exploit millions of losers. So it was in the past and so it is in the present. The effects of this globalization are the effects of the system that produced it. Its contradictions are also the contradictions of the system that produced it. The contradiction between the social character of production and the private appropriation of the means of production. The contradiction between a system that "either grows and accumulates or dies" and the limits of a generous but finite planet. But this globalization also raises the historical limits of a system whose contradictions are, today, all too evident and which we face every day. The European Union, as an agent of this globalization, continues to resist the winds of history, staging forward escapes that do not solve the problem, but postpone the rupture necessary for the emergence of a new society: the socialist society.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: written. - Mr President, globalization has changed our lives at a rapid pace. Connections, information and services move almost real-time on the internet, with people studying and working across borders and traveling more than ever before. International trade generates revenue for Europe: one in seven jobs in the EU depends on exports. Each additional billion in exports means an average of 14,000 new jobs for us. However, the benefits of globalization are not evenly distributed. As a result of intensified international competition, many traditional jobs have also been lost in Europe. Many citizens are rightly worried about their own future. The challenges of globalization must be tackled both at European Union and Member State level and at local level. The European Union has the opportunity to be a strong leader in the management of globalization. We are the world's largest trading power, investor and development financier. We need to ensure fair rules for international trade and taxation. Member States have a responsibility to educate their citizens, update their skills and reform their labor markets so that everyone has the opportunity and capacity to keep up with the change in working life. Transparency has benefited us and we will continue to benefit from it as part of the direction of globalization.

name: Moussa Faki Mahamat
text: President of the African Union Commission. - Mr President, Honorable Members, Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen, I welcome the opportunity you are giving me to address your prestigious assembly representing the peoples of Europe in their diversity. The Africa-Europe partnership, strengthened since our first summit in Cairo in 2000, has taken decisive steps in its exhilarating adventure. I am convinced that the next summit in November, which is being prepared, will constitute a new stage in our march towards a bright future for our peoples. The Africa-Europe couple has a beautiful history where shadows and lights have crossed paths in the past, but nowadays it is proud of its liveliness, its dynamism and its promises of a future horizon. in blue. Successive milestones in a series of contributions, from one side of the Mediterranean to the other, Egypt, Greece, Phenicia, Rome and Carthage had for centuries been weaving between our two continents, the web of an indissoluble relationship. Colonization, throughout two centuries, will have brought face to face our cultures and our civilizations so different in their spiritualities and structuring dogmas, but complementary in their humanism and their essential and imperishable inclination to freedom. The colonization of Africa by European powers was, of course, a controversial moment in our common history. Yes, there was domination, exploitation, enslavement, even slavery, that execrable insult to human dignity, the traces of which will not disappear as if by magic. Famous poets have immortalized this affliction. African and European thinkers and intellectuals have interpreted and explored this segment of our history. Politicians have made the trial of colonization and the hymn to the glory of decolonization the paradigm of their liberating doctrines. All have, rightly, fired the right lessons so that it never happens again. However, I did not come today, like a backward-looking man, to stir the knife in the wounds and even less to let myself be tempted by the illusion of a construction of a continental destiny by pouring myself out of the past past. I simply wanted, in the opening remarks of my intervention, to underline the indelible character of the scars left by this legacy of yesterday, as it is forged and inscribed in the collective memory of the African peoples. The story of our relationship, like any story, ardent and passionate, has not had only shadows. It is also - fortunately - a story of enlightenment, fruitful exchanges, reciprocal cultural and spiritual influences, enriching, invigorating and emancipating. This meeting has, over the centuries, contributed to the civilizational heritage that is yours, which is ours. Ladies and Gentlemen, our international environment is being rebuilt at a surprising and no less worrying speed. New powers are emerging, seeking their place in a world that has become multipolar. New challenges arise, for which the only hope for a lasting solution lies in collective and united action. In this restructuring of a geostrategic universe, which is also highly globalized, Europe and Africa inevitably seem doomed to strategic understanding, seized by the vital evidence of their community of destiny. Their history, their different but complementary values, their geographic proximity make each an extension of the other, inciting and engaging them constantly, with force and reason. Ladies and Gentlemen, in order to flourish and bear fruit, the partnership between the European Union and the African Union must be based on solid principles and define all fields commensurate with its multidimensional scope, its visionary ambitions and its global challenges, constantly extension. Mutual respect, equality, freedom and solidarity are the benchmarks and unalterable milestones for a solid, lasting, mutually beneficial relationship. Africa has gathered its minds to design and adopt an ambitious agenda for the next fifty years, aimed at building an integrated, prosperous and peaceful Africa. On examination, such an agenda cuts across some key issues, the Africa-Europe strategy, the tenth anniversary of which we are celebrating together this year. Agenda 2063 is today the banner of the African Union. It is he who guides our paths to the future and lays the foundations for our international cooperation and our strategic partnerships. Although Africa has been and remains the theater of many deadly conflicts, the main ones of which are in the Horn of Africa, the Sahel, in the Lake Chad basin and in Central Africa, the elements of its rebirth are today. hui tangible. It abounds in wealth such as its mines, its fishery resources, its immense arable areas and above all the vitality of its mainly young population. Good governance articulated on a courageous and determined vision of African integration, trade incentives, the removal of customs barriers, innovative initiatives in clean agriculture and renewable energies, and technologies and services constitute an essential lever of the desired renaissance. Its economic growth rate has remained sustainable over the past ten years. Our ambition will support a merciless fight against impunity, mismanagement, corruption, waste and embezzlement of public funds. From this point of view, the priority for us relates to the implementation of the relevant instruments adopted by the competent bodies of our Union and the respect by the Member States of the commitments contained therein. The reform of the African Union decided by the the January 2017 summit is seen as a real chance for our rebirth in that it resolutely calls for taking charge of the organization on our own. As such, it is called upon to strongly support the positive trends observed. Our continent is now joining forces to roll back and eradicate the social tragedies it faces through drought, famine, armed conflicts and human rights violations. These crises and conflicts place the twin issues of peace and security at the top of our priorities. Silencing the guns by 2020 is a goal we are pursuing with determination and determination. The fight against terrorism, jihadism and radicalism is at the heart of our constant commitment to peace, security and stability to which we are devoting tireless and vigorous efforts, both in prevention and in post-conflict management and reconstruction. . We highly appreciate the multifaceted support that the European Union is giving us in this fight, in particular through the Peace Facility. Ladies and Gentlemen, all current and prospective expertises indicate with certainty that Africa is the region of the world which suffers the most from the degradation of the natural environment and climate change. The devastating effects on the fauna and flora irreversibly reduce - sometimes annihilate - the very possibility of life in large areas of the continent. The excruciatingly baffling paradox here is that Africa, the least polluting continent on the planet, is the one that suffers the most from climate change. In this regard, is it not superfluous to recall that Africa only benefits from the smallest portions of international efforts and sacrifices to thwart or, at the very least, alleviate the universal threat posed to humanity? climate changes? This question is one of the fields of our partnership, which must henceforth be better understood, better treated and better prioritized. To this requirement is intimately linked the opening of wide corridors to the African and international private sectors. It is also to be welcomed that European trade with Africa has increased in recent years by 50%, bringing the overall volume of European private investment to around 200 billion euros per year. The company is the primary creator of wealth, jobs and economic prosperity. Its crucial role in our economic and social development will now take pride of place in our policies and strategic partnerships. Our deep awareness of the imperatives of a new economic governance encourages us to situate ourselves in the perspective of a continental free trade area. This awareness makes us particularly attentive and sensitive to the ideas of investment in the private sector and the daring invention of a Marshall Plan for Africa, concepts opportunely defended by the German presidency of the G20. From this prestigious and honorable platform, I express our strong support for his efforts in this direction. African youth represent more than 60% of the population. Women make up more than half of Africa’s current population. Youth and the gender dimension are in our strategic vision cross-cutting concerns that feed into all our programs conducted alone or in partnership with other actors. The question of the emigration of whole sections of our young people in Europe poses a double challenge: to those who throw themselves blindly on the paths of the shipwreck, as to those who, without preparation, find themselves submerged by these waves of human beings. The challenge posed to us by all these phenomena has no solution, except for one: to develop Africa and to reinvent for our youth a better future on the continent. Our partnership finds a field here, still untapped, with an exceptional community of interest and mutual benefit. The diaspora, considered in our vision as the sixth region of Africa after those of North, South, East, West and Center, occupies an important place in our agenda. Its multifaceted contribution to the development of the continent draws on the intellectual and financial resources it provides. Ladies and Gentlemen, I have insisted in the preceding passages on the fields of partnership which are more or less common to us. They are the gist of the message you do me honor to listen to. However, I would be incomplete and my ardent thirst to speak to you from an open heart, without make-up, would remain unfulfilled if I did not ask the fundamental question of the relationship to be established between the universalism of our partnership and its relativism. Many questions attest, once asked, to nuances, and sometimes even to divergences, between Europe and Africa. It is not my temperament, nor the political philosophy on the basis of which the heads of state or government of Africa have elected me, to preach the conflict of civilizations, cultures, religions. My credo in this area is dialogue, the search for consensus, mutual discovery, understanding, the solidarity of civilizations, cultures and religions. I plead not for the construction of walls to protect oneself from the Other but for the construction of bridges to socialize and commune with this Other. (Applause) In building bridges, we cannot preach uniformity and the negation of differences. Our diversity is the engine of our movement, of our life, of our dynamism. Is it not unjust, dishonorable and harmful to elude, through diplomatic abuse, this fruitful diversity? Yes, Africa has views of its own on a series of issues: issues of international criminal justice and universal jurisdiction, the relationship between justice, peace and reconciliation. Obviously, the often overused slogan "to African problems, African solutions" cannot be used as an alibi or a pretext to legitimize deviance or other political misguidance. However, it is still very topical. I am delighted here at the remarkable vigilance of African civil societies and their mobilization in almost all areas of our cooperation. Perhaps, Honorable Members, you will find that I have overloaded the train of our partnership. I dare to hope to protect myself from my turpitude by the famous formula of Jules Verne: "Nothing great is done that is not an exaggerated hope". Ladies and Gentlemen, I invite you to consider that in Africa you have an open heart, an alert mind and firm, hard-working but generously extended hands. Thank you for considering this invitation and, even more, for accepting my heartfelt thanks for your kind attention. Thank you. (The Assembly, standing, applauds the speaker)

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr. Chairman, thank you. As you can see, we are already building bridges between the European Union and the African Union. Members have risen to greet you and to thank you for your speech. Now you have to start working. You have to be pragmatic and concrete. I think that together with Mrs Mogherini, who is the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, we can do a good job. Parliament is strongly committed to this subject. We need to build bridges at the economic level, at the political level as well as at the transport level. I have always been in favor of the idea of ​​linking the trans-European transport networks and the trans-African transport networks that you are building. We have to work a lot together. I am optimistic, but we must also be very clear. We cannot win the challenge against terrorism and we cannot solve the immigration problem if Europe and Africa do not work together. That is why we have to strengthen these links and, I tell my European friends, we should always look at Africa not with European glasses, but with African glasses. This is where the friendship between the African Union and the European Union stands. Therefore, you are always welcome in the European Parliament. Thank you again. (Applause)

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.(Results and other details of the vote: see minutes)

name: Sophia in ’t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, we have just listened to the address by the leader of the African Union, which I think is an important event, and, on that occasion, I have a request to the leadership of this House. Just a few days ago we learned that Dr Denis Mukwege, the Sakharov Prize laureate, will no longer get full protection from the United Nations. Already last month, one of his collaborators was savagely murdered, and there are threats against his collaborators. I would like the leadership of this House, together with Ms Mogherini, who was here just now, to use all their connections, talk to the UN, and make sure that he gets full protection for the work that he is doing.

name: Przewodniczący.
text: - Thank you, Madam, we have noted and that we will be discussing with Mrs Mogherini.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to use this opportunity to ask for your support and, on behalf of this House, draw the attention of the Mexican authorities to the murder of Javier Valdez Cardenas, a brilliant journalist who bravely exposed corruption, drug trafficking and organised crime in his country. His brutal murder yesterday was a signal to discourage other investigative journalists. We want to tell the Mexican authorities that we honour his memory and want them to bring the perpetrators to trial for this despicable murder.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: If you allow, in order to save your time, I will not read the titles of the reports, because we have them printed, and we go to vote immediately after the rapporteur's name.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: - Mr President, very quickly, just to underline the importance of this European Union joining this international committee.It is the international body for basic cotton products and currently joins 27 countries, including producers, dealers, consumers.This committee is one of the few bodies that the European Union is not a member of.Now, being part of other institutions, such as international product organizations such as sugar, olive oil and cocoa, it was not very clear how it did not belong to this group and, therefore, I hope, therefore, to count on a positive vote, in fact,according to what happened in the respective commission, and that's all.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - The European Union is funding Bosnia's reforms with almost EUR 900 million by 2019. This year alone we are sending EUR 44 million to Bosnia.But the Dayton Peace of 1995 has created dysfunctional institutions today.Maybe it was necessary then to end the war, but today I make this country impossible to function.A law can only be passed in every republic, Republika Srpska, the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, plus the cantons of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as such it is practically dysfunctional and needs to be remedied, because the war is over, I repeat, and the country must move forward..For Bosnia to have a European future, Sarajevo politicians must implement political and administrative reforms, fight corruption, take measures to reduce unemployment.Thanks.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - E-government is vital for government in the public interest.A digital portal for open and transparent access to information for citizens and SMEs needs to be created.Digitization refers to the mandatory provision of data, but at the same time to the accessibility of the information that people or SMEs want.People need direct and quick access to information every day, to think only of the administration, the tax or the health.Broadband expansion is essential for a fast connection, especially in Romania, where 47% of the population lives in rural areas.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!The e-government development plan for 2016–2020 is one of the most important plans for the civilization development of the European Union.It is difficult to imagine the development of the electronic society nowadays without e-administration.However, there is a big problem with this, both in the EU and in individual Member States.In the private sector, electronic communication is already common and it is difficult to imagine the development of the economy and entrepreneurship without electronics, while e-administration is limping.It is very important that within the framework of the eGovernment development plan in the European Union, this priority is continued and the goals set out in the plan are achieved.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, today I voted against the EU eGovernment Action Plan 2016-2020. I fully support the use of the internet and modern technology to enhance democracy, but I believe it should be a matter for individual Member States. Forcing new techniques on Member States may well run contrary to local cultures and could disenfranchise the many who are not used to using such systems. Furthermore, it is abundantly clear that the internet is not secure, and rushing into eGovernment threatens the security of nations. I also have grave – very grave – issues over the potential for the imposition of Brussels-generated censorship and the overall loss of personal liberty. The digital single market is a poorly disguised attempt by the European Union to take control over the internet, and the cosiness between the European Union and some internet giants makes me uneasy. I object to the power grab and I encourage all Member States to do their own thing.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, I supported this report, I voted for it, but in the discussions and in the debate I said why there should not be just a paper action plan. We have a lot of problems with the rural environment. There are only 28% of the rural population connected to the internet. We cannot do e-government in the internal market if we do not connect the rural environment as well. We also need to increase the skills of citizens, not just government workers. The citizen in relation to the administration must also have computer skills. And then let's not forget the cyber attacks these days. We need to provide protection. At the same time, these things need to be done and we need to really develop e-government because it brings a lot of profit, fights corruption, increases productivity and, obviously, increases the level of information of citizens. We need a plan, but at the same time we need to look at how we give cohesion funds to poor and remote areas so as not to discriminate against these citizens.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - I supported this action plan and I am a little surprised that this agenda should fall within the exclusive competence of the Member States, as we have heard from my colleague.I am convinced that the electrification of state administration is absolutely crucial for the realization of all four fundamental freedoms in particular, but also for cross-border eGovernment in general.It is also important in other areas, such as the countryside.That has already been mentioned here.Or the electronization of health care can qualitatively contribute to improving the quality of life.These are all areas in which we need to invest, in the digitization of public administration decision-making procedures.I could count much more here.Indeed, the priority of the 21st century must be to ensure the electronicisation of public administration at all levels and access to the Internet for all spheres of the EU population.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - We are all aware that everything around us has been digitized in recent years.That is why I welcome the European Commission's action plan, which seeks to respect the trend that is advancing in our society.I am absolutely convinced that it is the digitalisation of public administration that will help to improve both its accessibility and the quality of public services and the fight against corruption, and will help national citizens, such as small and medium-sized enterprises, who are often forgotten on this issue.Personally, I think that cross-border eGovernment needs to be addressed in the future, because in my opinion this is an important step towards fulfilling the EU's four fundamental freedoms.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, today the EU voted on a government action plan on digital control of EU institutions in the public sector. What does this actually mean? Listen to the words placed in the documents. What it actually means is that the EU wants to know about every individual’s data in the European Union being controlled in every country’s public bodies: the tax system, the NHS. This document today says that the EU wants to have Big Brother beyond any concept of Big Brother. If you have private data with your doctor, the EU will know about it. If you have data about your taxation, the EU will know about it. Your passport, the EU will know about it. From the moment you get up in the morning to the moment that you go to bed at night, EU bodies will know everything about you. Big government, the big state, the big EU is here.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Thanks.In 2014, less than € 160 billion was collected from VAT compared to actual VAT revenue.In addition, fraudulent amounts have risen steadily over the past three years.There is still no unified, unifying, unitary data system that can be compared between Member States.As such, it is difficult to measure what everyone does and how they collect and where they go wrong.But that's probably done too.That is why it is imperative, in conclusion, to support and make as soon as possible the institution of the European Anti-Fraud Prosecutor who is independent, efficient, impartial and who works against fraud and especially, let's not forget, to have the power to seize property.which are supposed to have been defrauded or on money so that it can be confiscated.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report, which unfortunately highlights a negative trend in fraudulent practices in the EU, which increased by 36% in comparison to 2014. It is apparent that there are still many legislative loopholes which need to be addressed when it comes to identifying and tackling fraudulent financial activity among the members of the European Union. In order to reverse this trend and protect EU financial interest, enhanced cooperation at EU level and between EU bodies and the Member State competent authorities is crucial. In addition, I strongly agree that OLAF as an institution should work more efficiently; investigations must be shortened and recommendations to the Member States better enforced. Finally, it is time to value seriously the role of whistle-blowers in disclosing irregular practices. Whistle-blower protection should be made a clear priority.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - It is very complex to talk about fraud in the European Union, because what emerges from the annual report and what we wanted to underline in the REGI committee is that in reality, data cannot be relied upon. In Europe there are different legal systems, there is no case in point recognized as fraud at Community level, Member States have full discretion in communicating the number of detected or ascertained frauds. All mechanisms that complicate the picture and expose it to easy exploitation. It is not certain, for example, that the states that declare the most fraud are actually the most corrupt, often it simply means that they have a more effective control system. Then we must distinguish between fraud and irregularities. In particular as regards the cohesion policy, the difficulty of the procedures and the bureaucracy lead to a high number of irregularities, which are rarely however in the end ascertained as fraud. Then the way forward is the one that OLAF and the national anti-fraud coordination services, the AFCOS, are taking, which are making efforts to ascertain just that.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, from the very beginning I say that I voted, I supported this report.I said in the debate and I want to repeat even now: frauds are done cross-border, statistics show that especially on VAT, which is also the tax that supports the national budgets the most.I can't help but say that in the trade agreements with the countries that the European Union has, exactly from there come a lot of counterfeit products, counterfeit on price, counterfeit on quantity or composition.That is why I think it is good to have this report, but we will not be able to if the customs union will not work and the customs union will not work if the computerized systems for data transmission are not financed.And I agree with the seizure of property but only when fraud is proven, not when they are suspected.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this annual report on the protection of the European Union’s financial interests, entitled ‘Fight against fraud’. I want to see fraud resolved and I want to see a very strong position taken on fraud, but when you have a system and an organisation like the European Union policing itself – and we know the many faults in that particular area – then you will understand why I could not support a report that, quite frankly, papered over the cracks, did not want to deal with the issues and was in essence a token gesture. Had the report been a lot stronger in accurately identifying the scale of the issues, and had there not been amendments submitted that actually highlighted the countries at fault, then I might have supported its adoption, but I want to see scrutiny, transparency and accuracy. I do not want to see the detail being hidden.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I have been hesitant for a long time on how to deal with this report.In the end, therefore, I abstained and took the opportunity to explain my political position.I am in favor of fighting financial fraud very hard and defending the EU's financial interests, but on the other hand I must admit that some of the wording in this report seems very abstract to me and, unfortunately, I cannot fully identify with some.E.g.I think that setting up a European Public Prosecutor's Office will not help much in the fight against fraud.At a time when only a certain part of the states have signed up to this new institution, and therefore a considerable part of the countries will not respect such an office and will not fall under its competence.I do not think that will help much in the fight against financial fraud.So I think we should look for slightly different paths than those proposed in the report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótálas i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar a rinne 553 Fheisire as 676; agus dár ndóigh is fadhb í seo a bhí ann riamh agus, faraor, beidh sé linn go deo. Ach ní hé sin le rá gur cheart dúinn cur suas leis; caithfimid a bheith ar an airdeall i gcónaí go háirithe má bhaineann sé le caiteachas airgid an Aontais.  Cuireann sé déistean orm go bhfuil mí-úsáid agus mímhacántacht ag dul i méid in ionad ag dul i laghad maidir le caiteachas airgid an Aontais. Dá bhrí sin, tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go mbeadh pionós dian ar na tíortha agus ar na tionscnaimh éagsúla nach bhfuil macánta agus, freisin, ba chóir dúinn níos mó cumhachta a thabhairt d’OLAF agus, b’fhéidir d’Europol, agus níos mó acmhainne a thabhairt dóibh chun deireadh a chur leis an gcleachtas mímhacánta seo.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr President, every year 1.3 billion tonnes of food are lost or wasted, and in Europe alone the figure is 88 million tonnes. In Bulgaria, the percentage of citizens living below the poverty line is just over 40 percent. Over 30 percent of their income is "eaten", so to speak, from the table. At the same time, over 900 thousand tons of food are dumped in Bulgaria. It is hard for me as a citizen to see our grandparents digging or walking around the buckets. This is socially irresponsible and I strongly believe that business must take an active role. The steps taken by the Bulgarian ombudsman Maya Manolova are commendable, as well as the efforts and achievements of the Bulgarian Food Bank. But the fight against this social problem must be dictated by the government, not expected by citizens to insist on it. We should not wait for advice on good practices from outside, but we should propose measures for the utilization of the residual food resource.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Longing for Poland, the well-known poet Cyprian Kamil Norwid wrote: "To this country where a crumble of bread is lifted from the ground by respecting the gifts of Heaven ... I miss you ...". That is why, among other things, I also note the moral necessity to counteract food waste by all means and means, and I tabled amendments, especially regarding the need to improve food quality. Although I voted in favor of the report, it is a pity that an issue, which I believe is extremely important, has not been noted, especially because of the high percentage of it being wasted in households. The report deals with a number of important aspects, but one of the important, but not covered, aspects is the poor quality of food, especially processed food, produced with the use of pesticides, preservatives and other additives, antibiotics, in addition, often adulterated, which, when transported thousands of kilometers, is simply unpalatable and it quickly - even edible - becomes inedible.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, one bag out of four is thrown away in Europe. This is economically, environmentally and morally unacceptable. Back in 2011, when we did the report in this Parliament, I started a campaign in Sweden called Basta to Food Waste, a grassroots movement to get people to change their lifestyle without reducing their living standards. Therefore I very much welcome our vote today in favour of substantially reducing food waste, continuing to keep the issue high on our agenda and raising awareness. We have voted to have a common definition and common methodology to measure food waste, and that will also help us to exchange good practices. Member States must facilitate food donations. There are still tax rules and legal requirements that make it easier for retailers and restaurants to throw away edible food rather than reusing it or giving it to those in need. Innovative solutions and shared economic co-cooking should also be encouraged and, most importantly, the difference between ‘best before’ and ‘use by’ dates has to be made clear to consumers.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - In the European Union, we produce as much as 88 million tonnes of food waste every year, while as many as 55 million Europeans cannot afford a quality meal every other day. More than half of food waste is generated by households and, of course, the public sector. This waste is generated along the entire food chain, from farms to the food processing industry to shops and, of course, supermarkets. According to the Food and Agriculture Organization, as many as 793 million people are malnourished worldwide, and as many as 55 million in the EU itself. Research shows that, for example, 377 tonnes of tomatoes are discarded in the food chain in the EU in one year. To produce such a quantity of tomatoes, 90 km2 of land, 57 billion liters of water and 7 million working hours are needed, and the crop ends up in a landfill. And as we have heard today, this is also an open area for the so-called circular economy, so it is also necessary to listen to tax breaks and more efficient ordering, which is very important.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!Efficient management of resources is currently a civilization challenge.This task also includes respect for food.Meanwhile, in the European Union, we waste nearly 90 million tonnes of food annually.Most, 53%, in households, but not better at other stages of the food chain, e.g. in processing (19%) or in gastronomy (12%).However, taking into account that the most food is wasted in households, the main emphasis should - in my opinion - be placed on raising citizens' awareness in this area, developing consumer awareness.Another issue is the facilitation for those who could share, but for example have a tax barrier in front of them.I am thinking of the VAT Directive.Changes are needed that will enable tax-free donation of food.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - Reducing food waste is a moral issue and also an economic issue, because 88 million tonnes of food waste per year equals 173 kilos per European citizen, an enormous amount of which most are not even aware. Unfortunately, waste occurs at all stages of the food chain. For this we need a coordinated action that involves from the producer to the consumer and that deals above all with favoring donations, because in the world, let's not forget, there would be food for everyone but not everyone has food. Fortunately, there are also practices that favor donations and, in addition to this, there are experiences that minimize waste, for example through applications that some merchants use at the end of the day to send alerts and apply discounts on fresh products. Considering that food waste is however the work of families, of private consumption, we must implement policies that include training and education already at school. It is our responsibility.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: - It is completely unacceptable and we all agree that we should not throw away as much as 170 kg of food each of us in Europe every year. That is, we throw away one third of the food, and 10% of people do not have the resources for quality food. We need to know that we throw away more than half of this food in households, then in other parts of this food chain from the processing, catering, trade sector. It is therefore essential that what the report says does a lot to raise awareness among young people, raising awareness among consumers, local communities. It is right to involve volunteers, including the professional public, who can make a significant contribution to making better use of food. Legislative framework, which we wrote in the report, deadlines, also relief for profits as well as for those who donate food. However, the environmental burden created by discarded food is also important, as it accounts for as much as 8% of greenhouse gas emissions, so these incentives are necessary, even in the context of the circular economy, to use this waste as a source and not to burden the environment.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I voted against this initiative because it will not reduce food waste. On the contrary, it will further promote the profit of the distribution and food industry, which will continue to have at their disposal many more foods they need and at low prices, with the certainty that they will have an outlet in the donation and in the animal feed business. It also opens the door to tax incentives in the future for donations and to finance public collection, transport, storage and distribution of donations. However, direct and indirect unemployment will continue to increase with the disappearance of small and medium-sized agriculture, and poverty, social exclusion and wasted energy as well. Hunger is not fought with charity, it is fought with policies that guarantee decent income and wages for the entire population. Reducing production, regulating production in relation to markets, balancing supply and demand, looking for local markets, selling fresh and bulk products and adopting expiration dates, reducing long-term packaging, are some of the steps in the right direction.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - In general, I do not welcome some own-initiative reports, but this one is certainly very important to me, because it highlights a problem that each of us can influence with our behavior. In light of how many millions of people in the world go hungry every day, every food thrown out of our fridge is actually a slap in the face. The report is very good, it is descriptive, it shows how many millions of tonnes of food we are throwing away, how many millions of tonnes of resources we use to process such food waste, etc. There is one, in my opinion, one very meaningful measure proposed. areas of value added tax. I would very much like the Commission to hear this appeal. I supported this report, as is clear from my explanation, which I am now making, but I also want to say that we cannot stay with this report alone. We have to tell people that it's also mainly about their behavior. So: enlightenment, enlightenment, enlightenment.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, the fight against food waste is probably one of the most glaring failed acts of our European policies. Fifty European texts are working on it, even more: directives, regulations, resolutions and despite this, each European household throws away the equivalent of 400 euros of food each year. This is an unacceptable and even amoral waste when you know - and they have been quoted - the poverty figures in Europe. The Commission has no other choice but that of ambition, namely to rectify the situation and to stand alongside the European Parliament to achieve our objectives of reducing food waste, namely less 30% by 2025 and less 50 % by 2030. Two points are essential: clarifying the labeling, on the one hand, as has already been said, because “to be consumed preferably before” and “to be consumed until” are real highways for waste, and think globally, on the other hand, if we want to reduce it from producer to consumer. Agriculture, fisheries, the environment, health, VAT: all these sectors are concerned, but we need an engine, a real will, a real strategy from the European Union.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - I would say in this report that I voted in favor of it because I consider it very important, but I may be missing one fundamental thing that has not been mentioned here, and that is that there is actually no methodology for measuring food waste.I think that the European Commission should start from this point.Then we could get to the next points.For example, what packaging can we use today so that we do not have to waste food anymore, or consume the explanation of terms to or minimal durability.I think that many consumers do not even recognize the difference between these concepts or do not know about it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: - A Uacharáin, arís vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar a rinne 623 Fheisire as 676 sa chás seo;agus taispeánann se without go dtuigeann feisirí cé chomh tábhachtach is atá an t-ábhar seo agus cé chomh tábhachtach is atá se dúinn chun rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi.Dar ndóigh, tá na figiúirí den bhia a chaitear amach gach uile bhliain scanrúil.I ndáiríre, tá be mhorálta.Féach ar na figiúirí: 88 milliún tona de bhia caite amach gach uile bhliain san Aontas ar chostas € 143 billiún ag úsáid an méid uisce a ritheann trí abhainn an Volga sa Rúis agus ag cur 3.3 billiún tona astaíochtaí CO2 san atmaisfé.Is léir go gcaithfimid aontú chun deireadh a chur leis seo.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!The customs union is one of the main pillars of the European Union.Legislative law in this area is, however, complicated and the procedures very difficult.This limits to some extent the activities of small and medium-sized enterprises - I am thinking of cross-border activities here - and unfortunately facilitates illegal activities by criminal companies.Therefore, it is necessary to change regulations and procedures, including the implementation of electronic solutions.But not only the regulations, not only the procedures are important.It is also important to strengthen cooperation between the customs administrations of the Member States.Equally important is what was mentioned in the document, i.e. strengthening the cooperation between the customs administration and enterprises.If these tasks are completed, we may have better results in this area.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, at the core of these proposals is the creation of yet another European Union control body, this time to manage Member States’ customs authorities. Now, as always, the European Union is dressing up a power grab, and I emphasise ‘a power grab’, as something beneficial – in this case, to prevent illegal and counterfeit goods entering the Union. But the reality is that Brussels is looking to extend its control and to reduce again the sovereignty of Member States. Remember that the freedom of movement, people, services and goods is in place as a key pillar, and yet it seems at odds with what we have been voting on this morning. The salami tactic for power-grabbing has been going on for years, and I am very glad that, once Brexit finally takes place, the United Kingdom will not have to cede yet more power and more control to Brussels – to yet another EU body – in respect of what should be a Member State competence.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: - Finally the customs report has been approved and getting to this point has not been easy, because this is an uncomfortable report, which denounces how some countries do not apply the necessary customs controls by bringing billions of EUR of counterfeit products into the European market or evendangerous.A report that was opposed from the beginning, here in Parliament, first a long conflict of attribution, then an endless series of parliamentary low blows and, finally, last week the request of some parties to postpone the vote to a later date.To all those who have tried to stop us, I want to say that they have not succeeded and instead I want to thank all those who have supported our battle, the majority in fact.It was not easy but in the end the customs report is a reality and now I hope that the Commission will immediately follow up on our recommendations.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, I take this opportunity to congratulate the rapporteur here. Yes, it has not been easy and it is never easy to get a report, but today we debated and voted on two important reports. Fighting fraud and illicit trade are two things we need to be concerned about and can only be done if there is cooperation, data transmission because, as I said, illicit trade is done cross-border, unsupervised imports are made. We need Member States to work together, and we need to say that both illicit trade and fraud are a cancer for SMEs, especially for entrepreneurs who work properly, but they are also a danger to the citizen because not only the food imports the rapporteur was talking about, but toys, clothing and all other products can be a danger to consumers. That is why I supported the report, but we must ask the Commission, as we said in the debate, to keep us informed of any improvements that are being made or of new measures to achieve positive results.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - As far as this report is concerned, I supported it.I really consider the customs union to be one of the EU's great projects, and I want to thank all the customs officers for the excellent work they are generally doing.Yes, it is true that customs procedures are often very complex, administratively demanding, and it is our task to eliminate these administrative burdens as much as possible.We also need, of course, to motivate the customs authorities to cooperate and to coordinate at European level their cooperation, which is often really difficult.This is very important from the point of view of combating illegal trade, because it violates the right to demand the fulfillment of all obligations.Those who violate the law usually gain an unjustified advantage, and those who comply with it then find themselves in a very disadvantageous situation, so we should ensure compliance with the law in the area of the customs union.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - I also surprisingly supported this report because I consider the EU and the customs union in it to be the basis of some future world development.In my opinion, customs authorities also play an important role in protecting economic interests.It is important that they have an effective strategy and also that they reduce the consequences of the damage to the illegal trade.However, with increasing international trade, new trade challenges need to be met.There is a need to improve customs cooperation and, in particular, the exchange of data between customs authorities.It is also important that the customs authorities in the various Member States do the same and that there is no repeated divergent interpretation of European rules.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, today the EU voted on a report on the tools needed to facilitate trade with countries outside the European Union. The report, which is here in my hand, actually says that complex rules and procedures can overburden small and medium—sized enterprises, placing considerable strain upon them. I have been arguing for the past two and a half years that this is what the EU has been doing through its rules across the whole of Europe. It also recognises the need for free trade and cooperation agreements and says that it has them with South Korea, Canada, the US, China and Japan. Yet when it comes to Brexit and the United Kingdom, in this report the views on free trade and small business between the EU and the UK goes out of the window as MEPs in this Chamber – as you can see, an empty one at the moment – demand further punishment of the United Kingdom rather than entering into a free trade arrangement. That is the EU negotiating style.

name: Przewodniczący.
text: - I hereby close the explanation of vote.

name: El presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate based on the Declaration of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Union's strategy for Syria [2017/2654 (RSP)].

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you very much, and I apologise for the delay. We had a longer-than-expected college meeting and I apologise for that. I am particularly glad that we have the opportunity to again share in this Hemicycle the work we are doing on Syria – especially today, as the UN has reconvened the talks: intra-Syrian talks in Geneva just started this morning. I spoke just a couple of hours ago with Staffan de Mistura again, the UN Special Envoy, who has this morning concluded the first renewed round of talks with the Syrian parties, for a new round aiming at entering into the substance of the political transition, including on constitutional setup. This is the process on which and in which the European Union is investing, supporting the intra-Syrian talks, the UN facilitation and the work of the Syrian opposition, the civil society, especially the women of Syria – work that we support every day with our teams, both in Geneva and in Brussels, but also in the region. So the European Union has a special role to play, to help the Syrian people end the war in their country. The European Union is not a military actor in Syria. I know some might argue that this makes us a less powerful player in the region. Even if, as you know well, I always value a lot whenever we manage or we decide to use also our hard power in some situations that require this, I strongly believe that the fact that we are not a military player in the Syrian crisis makes us stronger in the political context of trying to solve the problem and the crisis there, exactly because we have not taken part in the devastation of the country, and at the same time we have been on the side of the civilian population, all through the war, as the first humanitarian donor for Syrians both within and outside the country. Exactly for this reason, we have a stronger role to play when it comes to the political mediation and solution. First of all, let me stress one basic thing that sometimes we take for granted, but I think in these times we are living, it is definitely not something that is irrelevant: we are the ones contributing to the humanitarian work inside Syria and around Syria. We are the ones bringing aid through the UN agencies and international organisations; trying to save every single life; trying to bring every single child to school; trying to guarantee the minimum basic living conditions for Syrians. This is something I will always be proud of. Some might consider that Realpolitik goes as far as making this irrelevant. Let me tell you that the basic condition – not only of humanity from my perspective, but also for the political future of Syria – is that there are some Syrians left. I am sorry, this is very hard to say, but our work of saving lives on the ground, guaranteeing that people have humanitarian aid, medical assistance, food, water – basic, basic living conditions – is first a humanitarian duty, and second it is also a major political asset, also to be a recognised, trusted, political actor for the parties. It is precious: so precious that to me it is invaluable. Because we have not destroyed, because we help life, we can better help the Syrians rebuild the future of the country. And this is something that not only the international community, not only the region, but also and first of all, the Syrians recognise to the European Union. This is the core of the European Union’s Strategy on Syria, adopted by the Council on 3 April, with conclusions endorsing my joint communication with the Commission. This is our answer to anyone who believes – as I was saying – that we are powerless because we are not shooting. It is exactly the contrary. The entire European Union is united behind the goal of a political solution to the war and the means to achieve it. It demonstrates what we can do in practice to end this war and ensure that lives are protected, rights respected, democratic aspirations and needs are met. In the Strategy we outlined a clear set of objectives: seeking a political solution to the conflict within the UN framework; supporting the opposition – including the High Negotiation Committee – to develop their proposal for a meaningful and inclusive transition; and in parallel, as I said, working to save lives, to promote human rights, to strengthen civil society, the role of women, to promote accountability for war crimes – that is extremely important, and I will come back to that – and to support the resilience of the Syrian people. The Strategy indicates the direction of our actions. It is not a philosophical paper; it is a road map for acting together. Two days after it was endorsed, we have begun to put it into practice: hosting the major international Ministerial conference on Syria in Brussels, together with the Secretary-General of the United Nations. We brought together 80 delegations from countries and international organisations from the region and the entire world, raising more than nine billion euros until 2020, including EUR 5.6 billion for 2017 alone. There was a risk of the international community being disrupted – of having a sort of donors’ fatigue when it comes to the support to Syrians, and I was glad to see that we managed to mobilise more resources than last year in London. This is important; it makes a difference to the lives of the people on the ground. But again, as I said, it makes a difference also for the UN and our support to the UN system – another political objective which is very dear in our hearts and minds in this period of time, and it strengthens the possibility for political work to be done in Geneva. More than two thirds of this amount comes from the European Union and the Member States. So, once again, we are throwing a lifeline to millions of Syrians, inside the country and in the region, building in this way the basic conditions for the future of Syria, the survival of Syrians. As you might remember, on the eve of the Brussels Conference, a terrible chemical attack hit Idlib’s province, and I do not believe this was a complete coincidence. Normally, as the international community gathers to work for peace and show unity, and determination and commitment, the enemies of peace tried to derail its efforts. But that very same day, from Brussels, from the European Union, from the UN, from so many countries and organisations, we sent two powerful messages. First, we all agreed that those responsible for these crimes must be held accountable. And last week, exactly one week ago, on Europe’s Day, 9 May, in New York, I was briefing the UN Security Council and sharing with them the fact that the European Union fully stands behind the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons in its investigations: this is the right forum to document any responsibilities for the use of chemical weapons in Syria. The Brussels Conference also made a call for support to the new ‘International, Impartial and Independent Mechanism’, established by the UN General Assembly, which will assist in investigating and prosecuting war crimes cases in Syria. Accountability for us is key. Second, in Brussels we all committed to work for a political solution agreed among the Syrian parties as the only just but also the only realistic way to end the war. Accountability and the need to support a political solution and to be serious about that: these were also the main messages we heard from the representatives of the Syrian civil society – Syrian women – during the Brussels Conference. Together with the third word we heard a very powerful word from them: hudna, hudna, hudna. They were repeating it to us, and this means ‘we need a ceasefire’. We need violence to decrease and peace to reach some areas of the country. For three days, around the Brussels Conference, over 40 Syrians from all parts of Syria and from the diaspora, representatives of civil society organisations with very different backgrounds, women and men, different ages, worked to agree on a set of common messages for the Conference. Their representatives delivered their messages to the ministers in the political session. We have immediately turned into practice the Strategy’s recognition of the civil society’s crucial role, and I know this Parliament is particularly supportive of that – rightly so. These are the people who can reach across the conflict lines, talk to each other, heal the wounds of over six years of war, to make reconciliation truly possible on the ground, locally. And the expertise they hold will also be essential to post-conflict reconstruction. In fact, let me say the Syrians who came to Brussels from within and outside of Syria, different parts of the country, agreed very much with our determination to begin preparations for the day after the end of the conflict. Because too many times – too many times – the international community, and also Europe, was not prepared for winning the peace after a war had ended. It is a mistake that we cannot afford anymore; Syria and the Syrians cannot afford that mistake. Of course, reconstruction will only begin when a political transition will be under way, not before. This is in the hands of the Syrian talks in Geneva under the UN auspices that the European Union is accompanying day by day. But the European Union has already started to engage and to contribute to the post-agreement planning, in close cooperation with the United Nations and the World Bank. Also because this can be a very powerful tool, maybe one of the most powerful tools today, to support and accompany the political process, showing the peace dividend, being an incentive to the Syrian parties to find and implement an agreement. The same logic marks our Syria Strategy: we do not try to bet on the future, but to prepare for it and contribute to shaping it, together with the UN, together with the powers of the region, but most of all, with the people of Syria. Because peace can only come from the Syrian people, from a political solution agreed by the Syrian parties. This is the most complex and the most violent conflict in our times, and it is clear, I think, by now to all in the world that no regional or global power alone has the strength to solve it. We need forces to join along one line, which is a political solution agreed by the Syrian parties in Geneva under the UN auspices. All different initiatives – and we wish that all of them manage to deliver and to be implemented, including the ones taken in Astana – now have the big responsibility to converge towards Geneva, to help the Syrians build peace and find their own path towards national reconciliation. And there are no shortcuts for that. We have seen it for six years: Geneva, the UN process, the multilateral framework, these intra-Syrian talks are and must remain the only way to transition. As I said today, Staffan de Mistura has resumed the talks with a clear intention of entering into the substance of the transition, starting from the constitutional set-up of the country. The European Union stands there in Geneva, as well as the work we do in Brussels and in the region, to accompany the UN, their work, to accompany the Syrian people for a democratic, united and inclusive Syria to finally bring peace to the country and to our entire region.

name: Arnaud Danjean
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Madam High Representative, our collective inability to put an end to the Syrian tragedy is not only a moral tragedy vis-à-vis the hundreds of thousands of victims, it is also a diplomatic failure that darkens considerably any prospect of stability in Europe's neighborhood. That is why no diplomatic effort should be spared to help find a solution. The strategy you are presenting to us is in many ways still terribly out of step with a reality whose horror seems to know no bounds. At least it has the merit of recalling some principles of a solution. Principles, let us remember, have already been put together for five years and which, we hope, will one day come to fruition. Of course, Europe is far from alone to blame for this failure. Others carry even more overwhelming responsibilities. First, the regime, which has been playing the worst-case policy from the start, but which still has support and a reality, not only in Moscow and Tehran. Jihadist groups, which thrive on chaos and sow terror on unprecedented scale. Irresponsible regional powers for which Syria is only a maneuvering ground for their own ambitions. And great powers that do not seem to appreciate how their so-called strategic visions are in fact small sordid very short-term calculations that fuel the crisis and have mutated it from a civil war to a lasting regional conflagration. Europe is unfortunately not yet a key player in resolving this conflict. We should undoubtedly have a more realistic approach to the balance of power, perhaps more modest ambitions, but in any case a desire at all times to exert all possible influences on those who have a share in the fate of the Syria in their hands. Our humanitarian, financial and policies, which you recalled, must be focused on achievable goals.There cannot be other more pressing priorities on your agenda.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, today I will speak mainly about the future because we have to make every effort to ensure that there is a future for the people of Syria. We have to ensure that one of the main objectives of the EU Strategy on Syria is to facilitate a political solution, which should also include a UN monitoring and enforcement mechanism. Moreover, we have to make sure that the European Union plays the most effective and active role possible within the existing UN agreed negotiating framework. The European Union is the largest donor to the Syrian crisis and, through the last Brussels Conference, has committed itself to making a substantial post—conflict contribution to reconstruction. Madam High Representative, we thus call on you to leverage this significant financial contribution in order to play the most immediate and important role in the negotiation process and to ensure that a fair and just political transition will come about as soon as possible for the Syrian people. We cannot leave this in the hands of an illegitimate regime that has slaughtered its own citizens for so many years. We cannot allow this to continue with the support of Syria’s allies, Russia and Iran. We cannot let down the Syrian moderate opposition or the people of Syria. They are the ones to invest in and to protect if we want any kind of future for Syria – even more so now after the dreadful chemical attack in Khan Sheikhoun. Civilians continue to suffer and to be targeted. Respect for the ceasefire has been violated many times, so we need to ensure that, finally, we have a ceasefire and, at the same time, that humanitarian workers will be allowed access. It is also very important to ensure that the recent memorandum on the setting-up of the de—escalation zone, signed by Russia, Turkey and Iran, will not allow further targeting of the Syrian moderate opposition. One key concept in all of this is ‘early accountability’. It is fundamental now to bring justice, balance and moderation for any future government. Perpetrators should be brought to justice: they have to face criminal justice and be sanctioned by international law.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I say to the High Representative that we continue to describe the situation in Syria as being a civil war, but over the course of the past seven years the conflict has become increasingly a proxy war between the two main divisions of Islam. Despite paying lip service to the fight against ISIS, Russia continues to target the majority of its efforts against other Sunni groups that seek to overthrow the Assad Alawite regime. Turkey is still driven by Erdoğan’s overriding aim of preventing the emergence of a Kurdish quasi—state on its Syrian border, regardless of the fact that the YPG forces have proved to be the most effective forces against ISIS and have received continuous support from Turkey’s NATO allies, including the Americans.  Western efforts have, with the exception of the US strike against the Shayrat airbase in April, exclusively been focused on the fight against ISIS. The Assad regime, with Iranian support, is meanwhile at its strongest point since the conflict began, consolidating its territorial gains and confident that Russia’s continuing military backing for it will give it sufficient protection. Such confidence was demonstrated by the horrendous chemical attack carried out in Idlib in April which killed 70 people. Such confidence has also resulted in other atrocious human rights abuses. Just yesterday the US State Department endorsed the findings of an Amnesty International report which claims that prisoners at the Saydnaya prison complex are being executed and buried and incinerated in mass graves.  In the Geneva UN talks, the departure of Assad is clearly the first point for moving forwards. I called in this House more than six years ago now for a no-fly zone, but all options must now be considered for the sake of defending civilians and their lives, of peace, including things such as transitional arrangements, territorial partitions and even amnesties, however unpalatable. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.-  Mister President!Mr. Tannock, where did you get the knowledge that the news from the US State Department was true?It was US Secretary of State Colin Powell who spread lies about war crimes during the Iraq war: incubator murders, he presented photos of weapons of mass destruction that did not exist at all.Colin Powell says today: I regret, I sleep like a baby, every two hours I wake up and cry.Don't you know any of this?

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I apologise, but my headphones were not working, so I did not catch the question. It will have to be repeated. I am sorry. Perhaps you could repeat it in a compressed, concise, telegraphic form.

name: El Presidente. –
text: I ask Mr Voigt to be shorter in his question to Mr Tannock.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
