text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Yes, in a nutshell: I asked how you can be sure that you are hearing the truth from the American State Department?After all, it was Colin Powell, the then US Secretary of State during the Iraq war, who also told us fake pictures of weapons of mass destruction, of the incubator murders in Kuwait and so on.Today he says: he regrets it and sleeps like a baby today and wakes up screaming at night.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think that I used the words ‘true facts’. I stated in my speech that the Syrian Assad regime has carried out atrocities. I will stand by that statement concerning the use of barrel bombs over civilian areas, with the killing of women and children deliberately by the regime. As for the probable use of chemical weapons, the fact that the previous administration under President Obama unfortunately refused to act on it as a red line has resulted in President Assad continuing to prosecute his war in an atrocious fashion. I do not deny that the other sides have also committed war crimes. There have been war crimes committed by all sides, but this is the most horrendous situation and I have no doubt about the guilt of the Assad regime.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, please allow me to start with a point of order. We started the debate 20 minutes late today, through no fault of the High Representative, but I think it would actually be normal and reasonable for you as President to inform Members. So that is just a kind request for the future. I would like to say to the High Representative that the discussion on the EU—Syria strategy is very urgent. Yesterday, the US Government found a crematorium next to a military prison to hide mass killings, reminding us of the limitless brutalities perpetrated by the Assad regime and its allies and the immense suffering of innocent people in Syria. It also painfully reminds us of our own promises when we said never again. We must focus on justice and accountability, and peace for the people in Syria. I am afraid that we are not, as the EU – as you said in the last debate that we had – where we have to be with regard to Syria. Not at all. Nobody is.  At last there is a common position among Member States – better late than never – with this Syria strategy. Indeed we must demand a much stronger role towards a political solution that is negotiated under the leadership of the UN. We must leverage our role as a major humanitarian aid donor and as an expected contributor to the immense task of reconstruction to persuade those who kill and destroy to end this dead-end street, to stop sieges, detention, starvation as a war crime, to save the people, and also to make sure that our own interest is better safeguarded. Besides the strategy, I would like to urge you again to do more to use the good contacts that you have developed in Tehran to persuade them to end the support for the Assad regime or face consequences. The same goes for those Member States, such as Italy, when there was an opportunity in the past, which have vetoed EU sanctions on Russia for their terrible support of the bombardment of innocent civilians. I believe there has to be accountability in the broadest sense and we still need more EU leadership because, in the vacuum that we leave, others take a role that will not benefit the interests of the Syrian people, nor our own.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: blue card question.- Mr President, I would like to ask the lady colleague whether what she has said about crematoria and other things in Syria is a figment of her imagination or has evidence, not to mention in Parliament various such things without evidence.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Sir, if you had listened you would have heard that I cited the US Government. It is your choice to believe it or not. But even without this latest report of the presence of crematoria, the suffering of the Syrian people speaks for itself. If you do not want to believe it, history will judge you harshly.

name: Marisa Matias
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Madam Mogherini, you know that, in terms of general guidance, I have no fundamental disagreements with what are the positions you have taken in terms of a political solution and support for the Geneva talks process and the Astana negotiations , but having said that, we are talking about the European Union's strategy and I believe that there are many gaps to be filled in the European Union's strategy. Even though it is just a political strategy that, as I said and I agree with you, it is a lot, it is what is needed. Right away, last week, we heard about the recordings when there was a shipwreck in 2013 in the Mediterranean Sea, where 268 people died, including 60 children, who were literally left to death by the Italian and Maltese authorities, who did not pay aid. I have not heard a word of condemnation from the European authorities and institutions. And the question is, where was the European Union here? Was not. And these people were allowed to die because the European Union no longer had humanitarian aid, because it turned Frontex into patrolling, it let lives count less and it let borders count more when these people need help. Another issue has to do with bureaucracy. When it comes to relocating refugees, why does it take so long, why is it so bureaucratic? How is it possible that within the European Union there are children without papers? What is this conception of undocumented children within the European Union? So, cutting red tape is within our reach and finally, finally, Mr. President, allow me to finish, it has allowed everyone. Last point: I said that the European Union does not have a direct military role in Syria, but it does have an indirect role. For the third, fourth, fifth time, whatever is needed, I say: stop the sale of arms to terrorist groups by European countries. An immediate embargo is the minimum minimums, because there is peace only if the war is ended and, for peace, we do not need European weapons in the territory.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, High Representative, Mrs Mogherini! You pointed out that another round of the Syria peace talks begins today in Geneva. The expectations that there will be a breakthrough this time are still very low. However, there is the Astana agreement initiated by Russia, which gives cause for cautious hope, because the agreement provides for the creation of so-called de-escalation zones. The EU must now work to ensure that the UN Security Council is involved in monitoring these zones, particularly with the aim of sending a blue helmet mission there. The Astana Process can certainly be a helpful complement to the peace process. Of course, however, the upper hand must remain with the United Nations for a peaceful solution. It is good that the EU wants to promote a national reconciliation process in Syria and that it expects and demands that those responsible for war crimes and human rights violations are brought to justice. All EU member states must participate politically and financially in this. I call on the EU member states to give adequate support to the mechanism adopted by the UN in December to investigate war crimes in Syria. Reconciliation and accountability for crimes committed at war are essential for a peaceful future. I also call on Syrian civil society - both in Syria and in exile - to be involved as full actors in shaping the future of their country. Above all, the EU should strengthen those who work for human rights, equality for women and the development of democratic structures. I warmly welcome the fact that the EU intends to continue to make a significant contribution to humanitarian aid in the region - it is urgently needed. I would also like to emphasize that refugees People from Syria find generous acceptance in resettlement programs in the EU, and that we create legal access routes for these victims of the war and that they find appropriate protection in Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, are the dead counted or weighed? For me, for us, they are just counted, and their number is unacceptable in the unfortunate Syrian land, once the cradle of civilization and coexistence between religions and ethnic groups, today a hell of blood, extremism and violence. We have all learned of the tragic facts of Khan Shaykhun, deaths we mourn, violence that we condemn without reservation, calling for an independent UN investigation that ascertains responsibility because the guilty must pay. Unfortunately, however, I notice that not all the dead are mourned by the media in the same way. Just yesterday another 23 victims, including 12 women, were killed by the bombs of the international coalition on the border with Iraq. They add to the 352 officers since 2014, perhaps even more, I suspect. There are many forgotten humanitarian and Syrian disasters. In Deir ez-Zor for almost three years, as many as 120 000 trapped civilians have been under siege by Daesh, surviving only thanks to high-altitude air launches by the United Nations. Nobody remembers them. If that area were controlled by militiamen, I ask you, would there be more attention? While there is talk in Geneva, Syria is on fire and in Astana it is decided. Official UN negotiations appear to have been reduced to a mere proforma. On the contrary, in the Kazakh capital the plan of the four de-escalation zones is increasingly defined, a plan thanks to which the main global and regional powers are also discussing the positioning of their respective satellite militias, dividing their respective zones of influence. in the battered Syrian chessboard. The truth is that in this very complicated scenario it is now better for everyone to almost crystallize the conflict, rather than risk it being only one to win it. But the real question is: who is going to free Raqqa? They will be able to take on this huge and terrible task, even with the more US aid, only the brave Kurds of the YPG who for years have had to face Daesh? Will we continue to remain silent on the Turkish pressures, which continue to regard them as a terrorist organization and demonstrate their willingness to reach an armed confrontation with anything but veiled threats? Will we continue to tolerate that those who have been paying a very high price in terms of lives for years, who are fighting these militiamen ready to blow themselves up, could be attacked by a candidate country for membership? I also ask you to carefully check the sanctions also on dual use goods, because, from what the Red Crescent on the field also reports, hydraulic pumps and anticancer medicines encounter enormous difficulties in getting to the field and on the ground in Syria and to deal with them. , as always, it is the people, certainly not the leaders of any kind and any position. Fortunately, as you mentioned, we are not an armed actor and we absolutely must not become one. I agree with the analysis, this makes us more credible in the transition and in the reconstruction, unfortunately it is impossible, however, to effectively implement a post-conflict plan as long as the various contenders continue to dispute the remains of a country now in ruins. Here we can make a difference, with our geopolitical and above all geoeconomic and commercial weight, towards regional and non-regional players. This brutal proxy war, because it is a proxy war, must end. The Syrian people cannot continue to pay for sins that are not their own and to cry for deaths that are all the same, because none of them is more equal than the others.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too am convinced that the European Union, if it were not an NGO that behaves as such and comes to us to make a philosophical discourse, yes, a generic and philosophical discourse and speaks of human rights, of genders, of women, all very interesting things, but it eludes political, diplomatic problems and above all it does not tell us what the European Union is doing which would have, as has been said a moment ago, enormous potential to influence, if it were something other than an NGO. You, High Representative, have overlooked a lot, for example, on the Astana agreements, which, on the other hand, by providing for a hypothesis of de-escalation zones, therefore of normalization and maintenance of truces, are very useful for the transition phase. He hasn't told us anything about the summit between Trump and Lavrov, which was very important because Syria was at the center of the conversation, tell us what you think. We want to know something more precise about what the intervention, the opinion, the influence of this European Union is, if it is not an NGO, as everything suggests. Here too the talks, among other things on the hypothesis of creating buffer zones in Syria, as indeed Tillerson had already proposed. I think that these attempts are very important, because they serve to bring the ceasefire closer, they are diplomatic actions on which the influence and intervention of the European Union could have a concrete and important aspect, if we really want to act towards the transition to truce and peace, naturally with the consequences also for human rights which are obviously a very important thing. I believe that we must take into account the overall scenario, the fact that the United States is favoring a massive concentration of troops from Jordan and this, of course, has a very important importance because the intent is to prevent the Isis troops en route from being replaced. from the galaxy of pro-Islamic rebel troops. On the other hand, I want to say, in conclusion, that there is a problem that seems to me to be avoided here, in these debates, that of foreign fighters who are fleeing.ISIS considers them very precious;those go back to Europe and we will find them in our house and you don't say anything.You are irresponsible!

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: - Mrs Mogherini, you spoke about the European Union's humanitarianism in Syria. Mercy! Was it not the European Union that activated Article 42 and gave freedom to Britain, France and others to bomb Syria with thousands of dead and refugees? In the end, it seems, instead of a blessing, it curses countries that have energy sources and transportation routes. Middle East, Balkans, Ukraine, smell of gunpowder. Borders are being redrawn. The European Union is militarizing to be, as it says, "present worldwide". Competition intensifies with the risk of generalizing conflicts, as in the Aegean. Peoples are sacrificed for the interests of monopolies, either through anti-labor policies or in wars. The Greek government SYRIZA - ANEL calls on NATO in the Aegean, upgrades US and NATO military bases, such as Souda, ie bases of attacks on the peoples of the region, such as the US missile attack on Syria with dozens of dead. The only agreed issue for Brexit is securing British bases in Cyprus. The people to respond with their coordinated struggle against imperialist plans, a response that will be heard loudly in the mobilizations in Brussels, at the NATO summit on May 25.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, I will start by referring to the conference on the future of Syria which took place last month in Brussels and whose conclusion was very clear: we need a solid and credible political transition . And for this credibility to be achieved, we need transitional justice and a fight against impunity that are at the center of the transition. This is why I proposed, a few months ago, to work on this issue in Parliament and I have just written a report on the Union's strategy to punish genocide, war crimes and crimes against 'humanity. I believe that the need to prosecute members of Daesh but also of the Syrian regime for crimes committed in Syria is an axis that must be followed. This issue must be addressed urgently, as the evidence of murders, rapes, torture and genocides committed against Christians, Yazidis and other communities is disappearing. We must therefore collect and preserve the evidence now, otherwise we will no longer be able to prosecute the culprits. I believe that the Union also has a role to play at the diplomatic level with the United Nations Security Council, so that it refers the situation in Iraq and Syria to the International Criminal Court. In this situation, the second option would be to support the creation of an international tribunal for Syria, to which I once again add Iraq. I believe the only option we have is to rule out all expectations and move forward in that direction.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - We discussed the European Union's strategy for Syria, but are there any? Listening to you, Ms. Mogherini, we are content to work for the post-conflict. However, the war continues. It has lasted for more than six years, with more than 400,000 dead, 5 million refugees, 6 million internally displaced. Syria confronts us with more than the impotence of the European Union, with the inhumanity of humanity. In the last few days, we have seen chilling videos: surgeries performed in Syria, in refugee camps in neighboring Turkey, harvesting organs on children still alive for the benefit of traffickers' networks, in addition to thousands of arrests and disappearances by the regime and active terrorist groups on the ground, in Syria, the use of sarin gas and other chemical weapons, civil massacres, etc. The list of horrors is endless, but it does not move or move European governments. High Representative, it is at least required that Member States adequately finance an impartial and independent international mechanism, established by the UN in December 2016, to investigate war crimes committed by all parties to the Syrian conflict. Justice must be a priority, impunity is an impediment to resolving the conflict and any prospect of lasting peace in the postwar period, as Ms. Mogherini also acknowledged. I would also like to hear you, Mrs Mogherini, say it louder, confront our Member States with the obligation to welcome victims and refugees from this conflict, instead of trying to externalize responsibilities to countries like Turkey or Libya. We do not forget that it was also the failure of our governments to act, coordinated and strategically, that left the doors open to Russia and Iran to support Assad's criminal regime, allowing him and Daesh and other terrorist groups to massacre the Syrian people, with direct consequences for our security, for regional and global security.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Mr President, after six years of unbearable suffering of the Syrian people, of violations of human rights and humanitarian law, possible genocide, Syria needs a lasting negotiated ceasefire. Unfortunately, after failures of ceasefire agreements until now, we have the right to be sceptical also about current initiative as elaborated in Astana for de-escalation zones. There are many loopholes and inconsequences there, and beneath the thin veil of diplomatic nitty-gritty there is the aim to support the murderous Assad regime. We need credible initiatives. Also we need an enhanced role of the EU with other NATO partners.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: - Mrs Mogherini, today we are talking about the greatest humanitarian crisis facing the world, a crisis which is having a major impact on the region.Six million children depend on humanitarian aid.Today we are talking about Europe's strategy, but to be honest, it is too small.Too little, too late if you ask me.You argue for political dialogue.We are a major humanitarian donor.That's all right.But we are counting very hard on the United Nations.How credible is that if the United Nations fails to condemn the latest poison gas attacks?We need to do more to bring the perpetrators to justice.I have not heard you about the United States.I have not heard you about Russia.When we talk about a real strategy for Syria, I ask you: can it be a little more?Can it go a little faster?Such that we can save those children.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I will not refer again to the causes or the historical responsibilities we have for the tragic situation in the region. However, I can not draw any useful conclusions from the EU strategy. The response to the refugee crisis has largely revealed both the lack of solidarity and the lack of political will on the part of the EU. I therefore describe the minimum framework that will justify the role and the reason We must ensure that the solution and the perspective are freely shaped by the Syrian people. After 6 years of catastrophic war, it will be inhumane but also dangerous for stability to allow it to be financially blackmailed and raided by the "democratic" reformers, à la Iraq. Aside from bigotry for the return of refugees, let us give those who remained the feeling that they can at least hope for a better future than the catastrophic present reserved for them by the economic and geopolitical interests in the region.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to address two very specific demands on Syria to Ms Mogherini. First, when trying to reach a long-lasting political solution to that bloody conflict, the EU should never forget that it all started when the Assad regime brutally oppressed peaceful demonstrations of common people just claiming democracy and freedom for their country. Then of course it all went more complex, with many factions from the inside and from the outside trying to take advantage of the chaos and the war. But in the beginning, what ignited this terrible conflict was the criminal reaction of the Assad regime. Never forget that, and always stay by the side of those who want to honour the wishes of freedom of the ones who were repressed back in 2011 and thereafter. And second, the EU should make sure that the many crimes against humanity committed by the Assad regime and its allies and by other non-state armed groups will not go unpunished. The creation of a Syrian war crimes tribunal will be needed in order to make justice but also in order to boost universal justice.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, it is Groundhog Day once again in the European Parliament. I look up to the public gallery and say ‘Welcome to another month of one of our sessions of hand-wringing!’ Madam High Representative, I do not need to take up too much of your time, as I have said these things before in response to the same tired old speeches that I am listening to today. Whilst the extremists thrive and the people of Syria continue to die, we continue to have these debates about regime change, the influence of President Putin and how much better Syria will be once we have brought in democracy. Our track record in the region in terms of the decimation of civilian populations to ensure democracy is not too impressive, and I am sure the peoples of Libya, Iraq and Afghanistan would forgo the prospects of a democratically elected legislature in return for a roof over their heads, food in their mouths and the prospect of living beyond the next week. Can we deal with the extremists in Syria before even more make their way to Yemen to further destabilise that benighted country? Can we forget about forcing regime change and help the Syrian people rediscover some normality, without us deciding what that normality should be? I will now go outside and bang my head against the wall as I fear it will be far less painful than listening to this.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: - Mr. President, the West has no strategy.European policy in Syria is suicidal.Your position, namely neither Bashar Al-Assad nor Daesh, is untenable, Madam High Commissioner.The West is pursuing the pro-Islamist strategy of playing the card of Sunni Islamism to contain Russia and Arab nationalism.You are more concerned with attacking Russia systematically than with combating Islamic terrorism, which you promote.Therefore, Madam High Commissioner, today the best advice I can give you is: do nothing more in Syria.Today, in my opinion, the only state capable of restoring peace and showing that it has real military, political and operational capacity is Syria.This country is today at the origin of the solution which we must find precisely to bring peace to the Middle East.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Mr President, doing a little research on the current developments in Syria, I have found some very interesting facts which I have to report to the plenary. Obviously we unequivocally condemn the Islamic caliphate and it seems that in a year or two this threat will have been eliminated. But the West has chosen to turn against the legitimate government of Syria, to arm and finance the opposition, that is, the terrorist gangs that misleadingly used the front of the "supposedly" free Syrian army. Today, these gangs are part of Hayat Tahrir al-Sam. This is the new name of the al-Nusra Front, that is, al Qaeda in Syria. Neither the United States nor Canada has yet added Tahrir al-Sam to its list of terrorist organizations, which makes me wonder about their real motives, especially if we take into account yesterday's invasion of Syria by British and American forces. I therefore call on the European Parliament to condemn any support for any terrorist organization and to immediately start talks with the legitimate government of Syria, with the sole aim of restoring peace to this long-suffering country and not of promoting geopolitical interests.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, in the devastating conflict in Syria, I believe that it is important to distinguish the effects from the causes. And in effect, it has been said that the European Union is a selfish union. Honestly, this is a conflict for which the responsibility of the international community as a whole falls, and the European Union has made the greatest contribution - first, at the London conference; now, at the Brussels conference - and has been supporting the countries of the region: Lebanon, Iraq, Egypt, Turkey, and so on. It cannot honestly be said, with some exceptions, that the European Union is a selfish union. Now, obviously, it is necessary to go to the causes of the conflict, and it is evident that the European Union has to play a role in a peace in Syria that is stable and that is just. Some colleagues have referred to the Astana Agreement, which is an agreement that has been established between Russia, between Turkey and between Iran and, as far as I know, Madam High Representative, it is an agreement that does not have the consent of the parties. I believe that the only path is the one that the High Representative has pointed out to us: support the efforts of the Secretary General of the United Nations, end the conflict, actually put in place a coalition government, make a constitutional modification, end the Islamic State and establish a roadmap for an electoral process. Now, the important question, Mr.President, and I will end this, is to determine whether, as it seemed after the arrival of President Trump to the United States, Al-Assad is going to remain in power with the support of Russia, his vetoes. in the Security Council, their interests in the Iran zone, or not. I believe, Mr. President, that, sincerely, Al-Asad's permanence in the presidency of the Republic would prevent, as the High Representative has told us, a strong, united and democratic Syria.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, the chilling statistics of those killed and maimed in Syria are well known. We now need to focus on solutions. Therefore I welcome the strategy as a first step. However, as with everything else, implementation will be the key to success, and this will hinge on a number of key points. How will we ensure the Astana deal does not provide a carte blanche for targeting the moderate opposition? What will we do to push the UN monitoring of both the agreement and humanitarian access already vetoed by Assad? I recognise that many colleagues have mentioned the de—escalation zones and that halting violence is a positive step, but if we do not want to replicate the December ceasefire, which ended in last month’s chemical attack, we need to address the points I have just mentioned. Furthermore, I would say it is critical that the lessons we learned in Iraq are implemented to avoid repeating the mistakes made there. Leaders who kill and maim have to face justice – there are no compromises about that at all. However, uprooting an entire administration will lead to yet another failed state. Those without blood on their hands should be allowed to contribute to rebuilding future Syria. Whatever shape the future governance of Syria takes, if it is not inclusive, it is set to fail. We need to break the cycle of sectarian violence and exclusion. All groups, clans and sects needed to commit to a peace deserve a political representation. Finally, in this strategy, what will you do, High Representative, to add bite to our bark? How do you hope to overcome the blockages in the Council on sanctions against some of the key players involved and bring about pressure on the international community?

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Sir. Chairman! The situation in Syria is deeply tragic and appears to be continuing as long as a good basis for future peace cannot be found. That is why I believe that the European Union should immediately and urgently focus on the stability of neighboring countries. There are two neighboring countries that are particularly vulnerable and vulnerable, namely Lebanon and Jordan. Both countries have received a very, very large proportion of those who have fled the situation in Syria, and both countries are under enormous pressure to deal with the human accidents and major logistical challenges that come with it. Therefore, our efforts right now and here should be focused a lot on and make sure that the instability in the region does not spread further. And then, of course, we must hope that the ongoing negotiations will lead to a more stable and peaceful situation in Syria itself. As far as that is concerned, I think it is important when we talk about the situation in Syria itself that we also look ahead. There is a clear challenge in the fact that right now we see everyone fighting the Assad regime as potential allies. We must remember that there are also great radicalized elements among the people both in the Assad regime, in ISIS, and also in some of the rebel groups that are fighting both the regime and Islamic State. Therefore, it is important that when we move forward and look at the possible peace that is to follow in Syria, we fight radicalized elements on all fronts and do not stare blindly at one side or the other of the conflict.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: - The sixth round of the Geneva talks on Syria, which you, Mrs Mogherini, helped to start, is reported to have started today without much anticipation.For those who believe more in political solutions and active diplomacy than in escalating military activities, the events in Geneva, after the negotiations in Astana under the auspices of Russia, Turkey and Iran, led to a partial positive result, the declaration of safe areas, are a positive sign.It would be wrong if the documents we adopt in the European Parliament about the tragedy in Syria were just a kind of chronicle of events, without a vision, proposals and plans for our own action that would lead to an end to the war and the urgent reconstruction of the destroyed country.It would be even worse if Syria were offered Cold War battlefield status instead of solutions, international solidarity and cooperation.From the comfortable seats of the European Parliament, I sometimes have the feeling that we want something like this here as well.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mrs Mogherini, I personally - and I think, logically, you too - are tired of hearing a description of the suffering of the Syrian people, or even a description of the crimes against the Syrian people. It tends to be a kind of theatrical representation, at a time when we have not been able, for six years, to find solutions that bring peace to this country. I call on you to continue your efforts, so that we can see if peace will come to this place in the near future, and the time will come for those responsible to be held accountable and for those responsible to go to prison, if we manage to bring them to justice. before justice, for this great tragedy. Because, in the end, Syria has become an arena where foreigners fight for their own national interests. You have no role other than the one you described, to continue your efforts, to see if we can find a solution to this very tragic problem that is in our neighborhood.

name: Bodil Valero
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! Thanks so much. Many Kurds live in my hometown, and during all the years that the conflict has been going on, they have given me information about their reality. That information has been difficult to obtain through the Commission or the Council. They have given it to me from day one of the conflict until today. How they first tried to stay out of the conflict. How they tried to help internally displaced people who flowed into the country. How the relief shipments did not arrive. That they were not allowed to represent themselves in the peace negotiations. That in the midst of all difficulties they have built up a form of democratically controlled autonomy, in which all groups are included. How they were forced into the war against Daesh. How throughout this time they have been opposed by Turkey, which is also bombing them. And more, and more. I wonder why we basically never talk about what is happening in Rojava when we discuss Syria here. We can not continue to just refer to the fact that the government in Rojava was once considered part of the PKK - was part of the PKK. But we can not refer to it today. We have a whole new reality that we must relate to. Thanks!

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mister President! We have to state that, in consultation with Syria, Iran, Turkey and Russia, four protection zones were set up in Syria last Saturday. I visited Syria in 2015 and 2016 and in the last twelve months we have actually been allowed - must - acknowledge that peace has returned in large parts of Syria. From Latakia to Damascus, from Aleppo to Palmyra and Homs, there is peace today. The government troops have retaken a total of over 1,000 towns, villages and communities. How about choosing a new EU approach, a relocation plan, just the other way around? Now to call on the millions of refugees to go back to their homeland, and to provide the countries with a quota system, which have many refugees, and to provide a corresponding special payment for every refugee who does not return, so that the people there in Syria can be helped with the reconstruction, instead of constantly delivering weapons to these areas?

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to join the previous speakers in expressing my distress over the massive destruction and human suffering in Syria, including the recent chemical attack and the ongoing bombing and starving of civilians. That is why I absolutely have no understanding for what my colleague, Mr Voigt, just said about the current situation in Syria. I welcome the Syria strategy presented by the High Representative and Vice-President, because it calls for a comprehensive political solution in Syria through stronger EU involvement and reconstruction efforts. As suggested by the High Representative, once a political settlement has been achieved, the EU could offer vital support during the transition process by assisting a newly-formed government in drafting a new constitution and organising free and fair elections. The experience of Iraq has shown how easily power vacuums are filled by extremists. This is why we need to start thinking of reconstruction and provide long-term support in building governance structures and economic development in close cooperation with local communities. Moreover, given the involvement of regional actors in the Syrian conflict and the ethnic and sectarian tensions in the Middle East, we ought to address conflicts in the wider region and include local actors. An end to the fighting, humanitarian access and a political settlement must remain our utmost priorities, yet we cannot afford to neglect long-term planning. A broader and more strategic approach that takes local and regional factors into account is necessary to fight extremism and achieve political stability, and that is why, High Representative, you are on the right path. Thank you for your good work.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: – Mr President, yesterday 35 Syrians were killed – innocent people: men, women and eight children – because a bomb from the coalition forces went astray. Just consider for a minute if these were your children, your relatives, your friends, wiped out, within a minute gone forever. It is horrifying because events like the one I have described happen every day – and not just this year, but for the last six years. What are we doing to bring this to an end? I am afraid not enough. Sure, we help with humanitarian aid but, as for peace efforts, we are relying on the US, the UN and, more recently, on Russia. Does the European Union not have enough power – and I am talking about the political and economic clout – to pressure the proxy powers whose strategic interests are costing the lives of more and more innocent people in Syria?

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: - Madam High Representative, you are talking about an EU strategy for Syria and de-escalation zones. I always value to look closely at the facts on the spot. What are we seeing at the moment? An escalation, an intensification of the struggle. There is no political compromise in sight. I therefore have a number of questions for you. Have you been invited to the meeting in Astana? Has there been preliminary consultation between one of the players there, namely candidate country Turkey, and the European Union? And what about the often concealed but fatal role of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps in Syria and the Shia militias with all their atrocities, comparable to the Sunni atrocities of IS and Al Qaeda? Madam High Representative, you were so proud and pleased with the agreement with Iran. How do you combine the rapprochement with Iran with the country's utterly destabilizing role in the region? In Israel and Jordan, they are extremely concerned about the consequences of the agreement concluded in Astana and those so-called de-escalation zones. Hence an intensification of the fighting toll in southern Syria. And I don't blame them. How important do Israeli and Jordanian security interests weigh to you, to the European Union? If you look at the behavior of the EU Member States, how can we speak of an EU strategy? I find it really incomprehensible. But yes, facts don't matter here anymore, just wishful thinking, self-exaltation and self-aggrandizement.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, the war in Syria is in its seventh year. Bombardments continue, innocent civilians are dying, people are being attacked by chemical weapons, children suffer, people lose their homes. Sure, we gather to raise money for humanitarian needs; we help the refugees and try to find ways to keep them from entering Europe; we concentrate on the post-conflict reconstruction of Syria. But the war is far from being over. The EU must find a way to contribute also to finding a solution to the conflict and not leave it only as a prerogative to Russia and Iran. That is why I strongly support the Syria strategy. The EU, as the largest donor, must have a say in the negotiations on the future of Syria. Also, we still need to strive for a solution under the auspices of the United Nations. The EU must actively contribute to the fight against ISIS, and all those responsible for the heinous crimes in Syria must be brought to justice.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL).
text: "We have trained and armed people we know nothing about, and they have moved to the Islamic State," Donald Trump said. It is an eternal pity that respected politicians at the helm of Great Britain, France and Germany, possibly at the EU level, are not capable of similar self-reflection as the President of the United States. After similar sanctions, which you are gradually imposing on the Syrian regime of Bashar al-Assad, ladies and gentlemen, there has been no positive change in the regime anywhere in the world. Sanctions linked to military intervention are causing disintegration in both Somalia and Libya. The long-term crisis in Afghanistan and other similar countries is the result of this senseless policy. We can only solve today's situation in Syria by unconditionally supporting peace talks, removing nonsensical sanctions and a massive program to support the restoration of infrastructure and housing stock. Other proposals address neither the current situation nor the stabilization of the country, Mr Belder. Let us vote together for peace and reject another round of steps in the style of traditional colonial powers.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: - Mister President! Dear Vice-President and colleagues! Yes, we should vote for peace, but what kind of peace? Peace of the sovereignty of nations, of the unity of nations, peace that has to do with human rights, or cemetery calm - none of these seem to have been clarified to me. I think the proposals of the High Representatives are good that we should be fit for the conditions of the peace building, which also have to do with the reconstruction plans there and much more. I think this is urgently needed, but I am very concerned about geostrategic developments. I have the impression that the fact that Russia has de facto interrupted the Geneva peace process by bombing Aleppo has meant that people like Mr Voigt can now talk about a cemetery quiet, and we have to state that, for example, a conference is now takes place in Astana. And that we can have a geostrategic line from Tehran through Shiite Baghdad - Assad and Hezbollah - in cooperation with Turkey too, and that neither the United States nor Europe are at the negotiating table. I am concerned in a certain way how we were in this proxy, which it is, on various levels to the exclusion of the USA and also Saudi Arabia on this issue, in the long term, can bring about a really peaceful solution. I believe that this advance from Russia, which will be the decisive force there, and the fact that everyone is running to Astana but we are de facto not there, is a big problem that we have to face.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Madam High Commissioner, I would like to greet you and express my agreement, in essence, with the strategy that I have just outlined here, because, frankly, I do not conceive of another and I have not heard another one in the course of this debate. I heard several criticisms but there was no real alternative strategy presented here. The Syrian conflict has long since ceased to be a strictly national conflict. It is a regional conflict with a true worldwide projection, because it calls for the participation of the main powers. It is a conflict that stems from religious confrontations and geopolitical calculations that are at its base and the European Union must invest, as Mrs High Commissioner mentioned here, in two aspects that are fundamental: on the one hand, to contribute to the mediation effort politics, in close articulation with what the United Nations has been doing and, in particular, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, and investing heavily in humanitarian aid, which we have already been doing. The fact that we are not, as she also mentioned in her speech, an active military actor in this process, gives us, at this moment, some advantage in this process, in this phase of the process. For this reason, what is expected and asked of the European Union is precisely that, is that it will bet heavily on political mediation and bet heavily on humanitarian aid, and the news it brought us from the Brussels Conference in relation to the position taken by the European Union and by several European states are comforting news.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!This war was terrible from the very beginning, but we watched its dynamics, we saw what it leads to: the destruction of social peace, the destruction of Christian life, the launching of a terrible wave of immigration towards Europe (not only from Syria), and finally the involvement of great powers.Today we are not really dealing with Syria's ties with Russia or Iran, but with the direct presence of Russia, Iran and Turkey in this country.And all this happens when thousands of people suffer daily, as many colleagues have said.This war must be brought to an end as soon as possible.The only correct strategy is to support Staffan de Mistura's activities and achieve pragmatic peace as quickly as possible.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, undoubtedly, the regime’s forces and those of its allies are responsible for the systematic, widespread and gross violations and abuses of human rights and international humanitarian law. Sadly, this April, the Syrian regime conducted a chemical attack against civilians in Idlib province, where at least 70 civilians, many of them children, were killed, and hundreds more injured. Therefore, I call on the EU to continue its policy of imposing sanctions targeting the Damascus regime and its supporters as long as repression continues. Only the wilfully blind would think that President Assad is part of the peace solution, when he has been the main source of violence and instability. In addition, I call on the EU to continue to provide humanitarian support to Syria. But we have to be careful not to provide unconditional assistance to the Syrian Government.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, after having organized, armed, financed and supported the terrorist groups that led the civil war to Syria, the American administration, dragging the European Union, decided to show, once again, that it intends to impose its world domination by the force of arms and the threat of war. Thus, unproven accusations regarding the use of chemical weapons are repeated. Even the proper and impartial investigation that the Syrian Government itself has requested is not allowed, reminding us of the invocation of weapons of mass destruction when aggression against Iraq and a whole list of lies about Libya. Disrespect for the UN, its Charter, its principles and operating rules is repeated; the violation of international law is repeated with the bombing of a sovereign state, the threat of destruction of a country and disrespect for the most fundamental rights of the Syrian people. It should be the duty of this Parliament to condemn the war of aggression against Syria and its people and to call for peace, for a political solution that guarantees respect for the Syrian people's right to their sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Mr President, in the wake of the six-year war, 13.5 million people are now in need of humanitarian aid in the country, millions of them internally displaced, and a further 5 million Syrian refugees have been received by neighboring countries and the wider region. The European Union and its member states are at the forefront of humanitarian aid in Syria. At the same time, I can say with satisfaction that my country, Hungary, is also an active participant in this support policy, paying special attention to helping persecuted Christian communities. A lasting political outcome in the region can only be expected if the United States and Russia succeed in reaching an agreement and working together for a peaceful solution. It is in the common interest of the parties concerned, Europe and the world as a whole, to reach a Russian-American agreement. An EU strategy established with the involvement of the European Parliament can make a crucial contribution to the long-awaited solution and reconciliation. The Union must also play a key role in ensuring that displaced ethnic and religious communities return to their homeland as soon as possible and that reconstruction of the bleeding and ruined country begins.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the situation in Syria remains tragic. The contribution of the European Union and Mrs Mogherini, in particular, to achieving a lasting political solution in Syria is crucial. The aim is to bring peace to this troubled country, so that it can return to normalcy and the European Union can contribute to reconstruction. Europe can do much more for a united, democratic, politically stable Syria, and that is, to a greater extent, the responsibility of the Council. We must move forward, we must take the initiatives. Europe must be, for a problem that concerns it, the dominant player far more than the United States and Russia. And in the context of these initiatives, the extreme point of the European Union, Cyprus, must be exploited. Cyprus is very close to Syria and should be the political and diplomatic base of the European Union. That is why a conference should be held in Cyprus and at the same time a staff should be established there in relation to the Syrian one. In this way we will send the essential message that Europe is there, it does not visit and leaves alone.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Commissioner, the situation in Syria requires a fair and sober assessment, a fair solution and international agreement. A series of coups called the "Arab Spring" did not bring the propaganda goals, namely democracy and prosperity of the states, but on the contrary - created chaos and destruction, suffering, enclaves ruled by obscurantist thugs, strongly divided on religious grounds within Islam societies. There is one unavoidable condition for the stabilization of Syria, and that is the non-admission of fanatics to power. The mistake and failure of Iraq, when the state whose ruins the Islamic State sprouted, must not be allowed to be allowed. The so-called "moderate opposition" is by no means a reliable partner in building Syria and raising it from the ashes of war. Part of it is under the control of a Turkish dictator, another part is under the control of no less brutal Saudi Arabia. So why doesn't anyone in this room mention Saudi Arabia's sinister role in the bloodshed in Syria? I have the impression that there is shame and fear in the Chamber of pointing out the direct culprits for the bloody Syrian slaughterhouse - Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Turkey. Perhaps the multibillion-dollar deals between EU member states and Saudi Arabia are the reason for this shameful and shameful silence, and that, colleagues, is hypocrisy. In conclusion, Syria's borders must be unconditionally guaranteed, Riyadh and Ankara's claims to these territories must be cut off, and fanatical thugs destroyed. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I agree with many of your statements, the situation in Syria has indeed been very tragic for many years.I just want to ask you, you said that we need a proper analysis of the situation in Syria in the light of the many hundreds of thousands of lives that the tragedy has cost in Syria.Don't you think that after those few years of struggle, we should already have those analyzes and should we also face concrete proposals for resolving the situation?

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: answer a question asked by picking up a blue card."Thank you for the question, colleague."Yes, you are right, the analysis had to be prepared and presented by the European Commission here.But there are several factors in this Syrian crisis that are being ignored, namely the role of Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Turkey, and they must not be abandoned or neglected, because in this way they will not befound a lasting solution.This is my answer.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the extremely complex conflict in Syria has created the worst humanitarian crisis since World War II. Daesh and other Jihadist groups have been party to cruel and brutal atrocities, and serious violations of human rights and humanitarian law have been committed by Assad and Western—funded rebel forces. No one side should be exempt from prosecution for war crimes. The use of chemical weapons must be investigated by a properly-resourced UN mechanism, regardless of who the perpetrator is. Such war crimes cannot go unpunished. I welcome the fact that further peace talks are starting today. We should support the UN rapporteur on these peace talks because there is no military solution to Syria, and all the sides involved must engage in the peace process in a meaningful manner. The Kurdish forces and people deserve their own stand—alone seat in those negotiations through the PYD, and any establishment of zones must serve the innocent civilians of Syria and not geopolitical interests.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, we are in the seventh year of war in Syria, we are facing the worst humanitarian crisis since the Second World War. I saw the dislocation of the forces in the field on a map and we are faced with a mosaic of different realities, with ethnic and territorial conflicts that often appear irreconcilable. The situation, we know, is dramatic but we cannot give up. Every effort must be made to achieve peace and to achieve this goal we cannot rely on the countries that are engaged in the field today, which are only bearers of their interests. The only hope is that the work that is being carried out today in Geneva, by the UN, by Staffan De Mistura, will be successful. Mrs. Mogherini, the only thing that must be done is to strongly support this attempt by the UN and, if we do not achieve the goal of peace, our action as Europe can only and exclusively be one: to strengthen the great work done so far. in humanitarian terms both inside and outside Syria, where millions of refugees are found. If, as we all hope, a positive conclusion is reached in Geneva, Europe will already have clear ideas on what needs to be done. I have read carefully the communication you presented on March 14th, which clearly describes the six points on which Europe will have to act. On these six points, which you reminded us a little while ago, I think there can only be strong and convinced support from this Parliament, and we hope that this will happen soon.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, Federica Mogherini, the truth is that the war in Syria is the greatest failure of the international community in recent decades, a disheartening and shameful war for the entire international community. The European Union has been covering and assisting all the multilateral negotiations that, under the auspices of the United Nations, have been carried out in recent years. Today, in Geneva, we must continue to do so, because political negotiation is the only way out, with a triple objective: national reconciliation, democratic transition, inclusive governance; and, at the same time, justice, and to judge the war crimes that have been committed by different actors in Syria. For that, what is our greatest lever? To be the largest donor on the territory - the high representative has already indicated, has underlined: it is our greatest strength to influence - and to remember that in the background we have a Middle East with a geopolitical struggle of different forces and that we have to be capable of having sufficient force also in matters of security and defense to stabilize and pacify this region that today is on fire.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!Today we are talking about the European Union's strategy for Syria.I would like to remind you that six months ago Parliament adopted a resolution in which, in clause 15, as stated, we demand respect for the rights of ethnic and religious minorities in Syria, including Christians.We know that the situation for Christians is dramatic, so I am surprised to note that the Council's strategy from last month does not recognize this problem at all.In the six areas outlined, where e.g.ensures that the Union will continue to support the Syrian opposition, promote democracy and freedom of expression, the Council does not address the situation of Christians in this country who are abducted, tortured and killed.And just because the founding fathers of the European Union were Christian democrats - Schuman, De Gasperi, Adenauer - more attention and specific actions should be focused on these issues.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr President, after years of war, the Syrian conflict seems entrenched and the complexity on the ground is such that any initiative encounters major obstacles from the beginning. The agreement reached in Astana earlier this month and the so-called "de-escalation zones" have already been mentioned, but it is necessary to know the details of this agreement, in which the Western countries, as it were, have had no role any. It is true that, considering the experience of recent years, doubts about the viability of this agreement and the political will of the parties to execute it are logical. There is even concern that these so-called "safe zones" could be exploited to upset the balance of power or demographic balance, or even to break up Syrian territorial unity. I would like, during the new round of negotiations this week in Geneva, to shed a little more light on this Astana initiative, and for you to tell us a little about it. In any case, as Mr. De Mistura also points out, it is necessary to take advantage of the current moment and redouble efforts to move towards a ceasefire. Of course, the central strategic objective is to end the war, but until this is achieved - and it does not seem that it is close -, we have a moral obligation to continue responding to the humanitarian needs of the population. That is why, Mrs Mogherini, I welcome the work that the Union and the Member States are doing on this humanitarian issue, and I also welcome the commitments reached at the Brussels conference last April.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, let me start by saying that we greatly appreciate the ongoing efforts of High Representative Mogherini to reach out to the key actors in the region with a view to resuming the political transition, post—conflict reconciliation and reconstruction of Syria. While it is important to discuss the future of Syria, the present does not give a lot of hope that the immense suffering of the Syrian people will end very soon.  Therefore let me ask the High Representative two questions. Firstly, the meeting between President Trump and President Erdogan is about to start as we speak. Whereas the US has decided to arm Syrian Kurdish forces in the upcoming offensive to take Raqqa, an ISIS stronghold, Turkey’s Syria policy has become focused on the primary goal of preventing the rise of a Kurdish entity in northern Syria at all costs. Obviously, arming the Syrian Kurdish forces also has an impact on the internal situation in Turkey. The larger Kurdish issue can no longer be ignored. How is the EU helping to develop a comprehensive policy and to push for a Turkish-Kurdish peace deal on all fronts? Secondly, and very briefly, Russia, Turkey and Iran recently signed a memorandum in which they also discussed de—escalation zones. Could you please give me your comments on that agreement?

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, the European Union's strategy for Syria is welcome, but I am afraid it is too late.The conflict has been anything but black and white since day one, and it is obvious that the intelligence communities of several world powers are involved.Thus, Syria has become a global playground for testing power and measuring strength, and now someone has to repair the consequences.I am in favor of getting involved because the Syrian people deserve help, but I really hope that we will be more effective than before.From the first day, Western leaders openly sided with the so-calledrebels, trying to portray them as a constructive opposition to the Assad regime.It turned out to be quite the opposite, that they are all just non-peaceful and constructive opposition.I hope that we will not make such serious mistakes in the implementation of this strategy either, because Syria cannot stand new failed attempts.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: – Mr President, a crucial moment in the Syrian war is approaching. The so-called capital of ISIS is about to fall, or rather the city of Raqqa is about to be liberated by forces supported by the international coalition. These troops, the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), have proved to be those effective feet on the ground that Western leaders hoped for. Despite Turkish condemnation, the United States last week decided to directly support the Kurdish part of SDF. The Arab part of the SDF has already received support, so the US decision should be seen as a calculated move to strengthen those in Syria who have proved to be reliable allies. SDF is the armed forces of a multi-ethnic region that is trying to implement democracy. The ambition is to include all groups in the decision-making. Because of this, I encourage the Commission to study the developments of the Federation of Northern Syria (Rojava). I also encourage the Commission to work for an end to the blockade of the region. Let humanitarian aid in and give people a fair chance to continue their path towards democracy.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – Mr President, today it is self-evident that European strategies towards Syria have failed. The EU was consistently sidelined in the UN-sponsored negotiations. We are constantly being surprised by the moves of others: the US, Turkey, Russia and Iran. Collectively the European countries are the largest humanitarian donor in Syria, but this does not translate into any real influence on the dynamics of the conflict. It is, of course, difficult for the EU to play geopolitics, even peacemaking, without real military weight. The EU will never be the leading player in brokering a lasting ceasefire, let alone a political transition in Syria. Our best chance is to become an actor who opens up the political space and creates incentives for UN negotiations to succeed through confidence-building, financial support and future reconstruction, as well as through sanctions and measures to bring the perpetrators of war crimes to justice.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to join those colleagues who welcome the strategy for Syria. In this horrifying conflict, the EU needs to step up its efforts and play a greater role in finding a lasting political solution. We need to be able to react promptly to changing realities on the ground and to challenges in the region. We should be acting in areas where we are able to make a real difference, be it through diplomatic support or post-agreement reconstruction and reconciliation in the region. We should step up our contribution to the political process under the UN-agreed framework and at the same time continue in our resilience and humanitarian support under the ‘Whole Syria’ approach. I welcome the fact that the EU strategy is outlining EU readiness to help in transition processes and the reconstruction of Syria. This will be a hard and extremely complicated task. Therefore, we need to have a clear idea of how to do it. Contributing to a political solution to the Syrian crisis is by all means a great challenge – however, not the only one we are facing in the region. We have to remain sensitive to the stability of the neighbouring countries: Jordan or Lebanon, but also Turkey. In this respect I would like to appeal to the High Representative to carefully monitor developments in the region and be ready to follow the strategic goals outlined in this strategy.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, you are right to point out the strategy of the European Union in this delicate phase, because just when everything seems to give in to the violence of endless war, when from time to time it seems decisive and almost exclusive role of a single regional power, the more the strength of our political and diplomatic initiative returns. And we on this must keep pace. Above all, maintain the commitments made for humanitarian action. It is decisive and fundamental to accompany the nine billion we have invested, we have decided to make a commitment for 2017, with continuous and constructive action on the field; helping Jordan and Lebanon, which are the countries most exposed in this affair and, finally, this is the most political step I would like to point out, keeping Astana and Geneva together. Do not divide us, neither here nor in diplomatic action, but consider the two moments as complementary to a political action that must lead to a ceasefire on the ground and thus allow the political action necessary for political reconstruction, the future of Syria. . It seems to me that this is the ground on which we must decide our initiative and our action and the action that you are courageously standing by as the European Union.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would say to Mrs Mogherini that a strategy for Syria is needed and this is better late than never, as has already been said. But the problem is that the EU’s role from the start of the Syrian conflict has been, let us say, hesitant, trying to avoid involvement in the conflict. Paradoxically, the Syrian war has now entered European homes. But now, as Mr Tannock has said, the Syrian conflict has turned from an internal war into an international proxy war. The void left by the non—involvement of the US and the EU has been filled by Russia, Iran, Turkey and local extremists. Without the full assistance of Russia and Iran, the Assad regime would probably have collapsed about two years ago. What is the price of non-involvement? The second point: safe zones. There has been outcry in Syria from the beginning and up until today, and there are still five million people under siege or difficult to reach. We are eager to provide humanitarian aid and that is very good, but the question is how to reach the people without safe zones. Third, no effective conflict resolution or sustainable peace is possible without full accountability. War crimes must be investigated. Assad is out of any international agreement because of his war crimes, and his only destination can be the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - The EU Council set out an EU strategy for Syria in April this year. According to the Council, the EU firmly believes that the conflict cannot be resolved militarily. Likewise, UN Security Council Resolution 2254 favors a political solution. Both of these resolutions suffer from a lack of courage. Security Council resolution for fear of a veto of the Russian Federation, the EU Council fears accusations of radicalism. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, let us not allow indecision, fear, inability to take responsibility to become part of European foreign policy. The EU's relationship with Syria is reminiscent of Europe's helplessness during the Kosovo crisis. It was not the Union that was able to stop Milosevic's ethnic cleansing of Kosovo Albanians. It was NATO and the United States that stopped the genocide by bombing Yugoslavia. It was as if the situation was repeating itself. The EU has not yet been able to play a primary role in resolving the Syrian crisis. The United States and its coalition have already found enough determination to militarily support the Syrian Kurds' YPG and YPJ's fight against ISIS. The search for today's Javier Solana continues. For example, the courageous resistance of the Kurds against ISIS will emerge in the EU and openly support it.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: - High Representative, we are well aware of the efforts of the European Union and the international community in general to resolve the conflict in Syria. But time is running out, the war has been going on for six years and there is no peace in Syria. The European Union's initiatives, especially in the field of civil protection and humanitarian aid for the Syrian people, deserve to be respected. However, they do not resolve the conflict. The London and Brussels conferences are also good initiatives, but what is needed most is a political solution and a settlement of the conflict, peace is needed in Syria. What do we, the European Union, look like in this geopolitical game in general? You argue that the European Union has the potential to play a more important role in the peaceful resolution of the conflict in this country. That’s why we don’t take advantage of those opportunities, if they exist. Your contacts in Iran have already been mentioned here today and could be exploited. If there is that opportunity, let’s seize it. At the end of April, you visited Moscow. I hope that there was also talk of Syria. In general, is Russia de facto still involved in the Geneva process? Are there any hopes that they can change their position on support for Assad? These are questions we are waiting for answers to. Thank you.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, more than 400,000 lives have been lost in Syria in six years, and 11 million have fled their homes. The Six-Year War has completely changed the lives of all Syrians, but Syrian Christians are particularly vulnerable because they face only one choice: convert to Islam or die, with the open intention of Islamic terrorists to completely eradicate Christianity from those areas. Of the 1.25 million Christians in Syria before the start of the war, less than 500,000 remain today. Syria is sixth on the list of countries where it is most dangerous to be a Christian. The Christians who remained in that country were an easy target because they were geographically concentrated in a few places, and almost all the churches were completely destroyed. But Syrian Christians do not want to leave their homeland, they want to stay in their homes, and we must not allow Christianity to disappear from those areas. A safe and stable Syria for all its inhabitants - such is Syria. The clanking of weapons, the explosion of bombs, the constant fear that has been a daily occurrence in Syria for the last few years must stop. Syria deserves peace and the European Union can and must do more to achieve peace, especially to protect all human lives, especially those who are most at risk, and that is Christians.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - I think we all want peace in Syria, which is why we welcome the EU's strategy. The question remains to what extent the goals proclaimed in this strategy are realistic if a large part of Syrian territory is still controlled by the Islamic State and if Assad's and Putin's armies massacre moderate opposition instead of jihadists. The EU strategy envisages task number one, a political solution to the conflict. If this solution is to be realistic, then all major forces must work together. That is why I reject the Russian veto against the Security Council resolution calling on Assad's regime to cooperate with international investigators in the April chemical attack. Ladies and gentlemen, do you think that Assad would be willing to act if the US did not bomb Assad's armed forces? I am afraid that Assad would not be willing to act today. I appreciate that the EU has focused its attention on the future. Especially for humanitarian aid and also for education. There are 1.5 million Syrian children in Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon who need education. So I am glad that the EU is helping to educate these children and is thinking about the future of Syria.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Rethink Rebuild based in Manchester is one of many grassroots Syrian civil society support groups from 17 different countries who are asking for urgent and robust action to address the situation at its root, namely through civilian protection. Here is their recommendation for you: ‘We are tired of the endless political negotiations, which we know will fail because of Assad and his allies’ contempt for such processes and for international law more generally. We are frustrated that endless amounts of humanitarian aid are being doled out to Syria, whilst we have not been able to end the humanitarian crisis itself. We therefore call upon the international community to implement immediate and enforceable measures with a defined scope and the purpose of civilian protection, and in compliance with international humanitarian law to address the root issue in Syria, namely, civilian protection from the Assad and Russian killing machine. Whatever route the international community chooses to follow, it must put this at the heart of its policy, and a failure to do so will only mean that the resulting humanitarian refugee and terrorism crises will continue. #safelyinsyria

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the situation in Syria is really tragic, with thousands of victims and millions of refugees. But we have not heard of a real strategy on the part of the European Union, which will lead to normalcy, which will really put Europe in a more important role. Instead, we see that Europe has left Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Turkey literally threshing. Turkey, which is constantly smuggling oil with ISIS. Turkey, which is arming ISIS. We did not see any real action to strike ISIS. Instead, we leave Turkey to disband the Kurds, at a time when it is necessary to create a Kurdish state in the region. We believe that there should be greater involvement of the UN in the peace process and that Greece and Cyprus, which maintain historical relations with the region and especially with Syria, should be utilized.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, Madam High Representative, a little over six months ago I was visiting a camp for Syrian refugees in Turkey. I was able to measure the work that was being done both by the UN and, above all, by the NGOs, which allowed these Syrian refugees to live in almost acceptable conditions. But the Syrians we were able to talk to had only one desire: to return to their country. And I do believe that humanitarian aid is a good thing, but today we have to go much further. We must try to find a political solution because we have rarely seen conflicts that are resolved by war. I strongly believe in the political solution. It’s complicated, it’s true, because in that area there are the Russians, the Americans, Iran and Turkey with the Kurdish question as well. It’s complicated, but I believe that you are on the right track and that everything must indeed be done for this political solution.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the European Union, as a strategic partner and financier, must be resolutely involved in the peace process in Syria. But this involvement must be honest and impartial. It is not possible for him to openly support the Syrian opposition and demand that he be considered a correct and objective partner by the Assad government. Also, in a multinational conflict in Syria, one cannot look for war criminals only on the governmental side. After all, its involvement must be within reason. It cannot at this time call for the establishment of no-fly zones and no-fly zones at a time when ground and air operations are still under way to defeat ISIS. In order for the European Union to have a decisive and successful involvement in Syria, it must pursue a policy free of entanglements and serve expediencies and must decide to engage itself and not allow others to carry out projects on its behalf.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, first of all I thank the High Representative for her statement. As many colleagues have already said, we need to end the conflict in Syria urgently. As you might have heard, in the northern region of Syria, in Rojava canton, there is a democratic regional self-administration, the Federation of Northern Syria. Kurds, Syriacs, Yazidis, Turkmen and Arabs are cooperating peacefully in this region, making a model for the whole country. High Representative, there is a great need for humanitarian aid in this Federation of Northern Syria. Unfortunately, the KDP is still blocking the area. The situation is worsening. Therefore, I urge you to do whatever you can to stop this blockade and to send humanitarian aid to this region. We need better political cooperation between the European Union and the Federation of Northern Syria. We really need to fully cooperate with a real democracy in the region. Therefore, High Representative, I call upon you to normalise the relations with the Federation as soon as possible.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the war in Syria continues to have devastating and tragic consequences. Since the beginning of the conflict, about 500,000 people have died and more than 5 million refugees, a disaster of biblical proportions. But the horror never ends. The accusation launched by the United States according to which in Saydnaya, a few kilometers from the Syrian capital, a prison has even been identified with a crematorium to leave no traces of the crimes committed. In this context, the strategy put in place by the European Union should be welcomed, which includes, among other things, the prosecution of those responsible for war crimes and humanitarian assistance to the civilian population. The situation in Syria is very serious and at the same time complex due to the effect of the overlapping of various tensions. The European Union is the world power that undoubtedly has the greatest interests in stabilizing the entire Mediterranean area and it is also for this reason that it cannot fail to play a leading role in the peace process. Thank you, High Representative Mogherini for the proposals made and for what he is courageously doing.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the appalling consequences of the Syrian conflict that erupted six years ago amount to possibly the worst humanitarian tragedy in recent world history. The continuing horrific actions taking place, from violence by terrorists to military actions against civilians, including those in hospitals, have long made us feel helpless and desperate. However, we should be hopeful that one day soon IS will be thrown out of Raqqa by the American-backed coalition forces. We should be fully prepared for that moment so that when the time comes we can stand as strong guarantors of a genuinely inclusive political transition, and as reliable partners in the reconstruction of a stable Syrian society.
