As the largest humanitarian and financial donor, we are in a good position to demand a strong say in the peace negotiations and in the reconstruction of the country.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S & amp; D). - Mr President, we do not tolerate the crimes of the Syrian regime, but we do not tolerate the crimes of anyone in Syria. Mrs Mogherini, you will agree with me, there are no good and bad killers of defenseless people. The Islamic State has been and remains the main source of heinous crimes in Syria and the main ally of the international alliance against the Islamic State is, and has proven in practice, the Kurdish YPG, but Turkey reacts by calling it a "terrorist" and a bomber. The United States has already chosen the YPG as its potential ally against the Islamic State. Where are we? Will Turkey determine our policy? And I end with a question: how much more effective would it be if there was a common defense and security policy, with common defense structures.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I will start with a ‘good summary’, as I think our colleague Marietje Schaake put it. First, the European Union is united on a Syria strategy with clear objectives and indicators for action, and I am glad to see that Parliament is no exception in the European unity that has at last been achieved with regard to the direction of our actions to bring the Syrian crisis to an end. Second, and still quoting our colleague, we can now use all our means of leverage – and there are many in different fields – to support, in the best possible way, the only solution we see, which is a political solution under UN auspices. And let us be very clear on what our means of leverage are. First, the humanitarian one. Humanitarian aid, I must make clear, is never linked to political considerations. Our humanitarian support goes to anyone who needs to be helped, anywhere in Syria, with no political consideration whatsoever. Some of you referred, for instance, to the World Food Programme air-dropping food aid. That is happening thanks to European Union support, so all the aid you are seeing, all the children you are seeing saved, all the aid, food and medical equipment you see being delivered, is because of European Union work. We are not an aid delivery agency but we are the ones that make it possible for the UN agencies to do the work on the ground. So our role as a credible humanitarian donor, I believe, gives us the credibility vis-à-vis the Syrian civil population that allows us to play a sound political role in support of the UN process. The second means of leverage we have is reconstruction. Some of you argue, or question whether, it is too early to reflect on reconstruction for the future of Syria. Some of you say it is too late, some of you say it is too early. The important thing is to have clear ideas of what you need to do at every stage of the story, which unfortunately is a very bad story. There is a powerful element in our starting to look at the possibilities for reconstruction. First, because it offers a positive scenario, a peace dividend, and encourages the various parties to compromise in Geneva, because they know that if they agree on a political solution, if the political transition starts, if we go towards a democratic transition with inclusive governance and reconciliation, there will be someone in the international community – starting with the European Union but not us alone – who, on the basis of that political agreement, will be ready to work on the rebirth of the country. This scenario encourages the Syrians – and they need a horizon of hope – and puts pressure on the Syrian parties talking in Geneva, because what the Syrian people want is to make peace. And if we fuel this request for peace among the Syrian population with the perspective of normal life returning to the country, and accountability and reconciliation, then this will also create a little bit more space for the political talks in Geneva to take place, entering into the substance of what is going to be the future set up of Syria. As I said, it should be a united, democratic, diverse, secular and reconciled country. United – not fragmented or split into areas of influence. The third element that Marietje Schaake mentioned was our leverage with Iran. Many of you mentioned Russia and the United States, and I will come to that in a moment. I believe that the European Union is best positioned in the world probably to talk with one of the main actors in this crisis. Now I will not elaborate here on the assessment of the role of Iran in the crisis because I think you know that very well, but if you want to make peace you have to talk to those who are making war, and we are among the few that have good, constructive conversations with Iran – in some cases trust-based, and always very frank, conversations. Do not imagine that we are not doing this. We are, on a daily basis, and this is what we have been doing with the regional initiative. Why is it so important, if it is not getting headlines? Why have we chosen the regional approach? Because it is Syrians who have to have the courage for the transition and the compromise and the solution, the political solution. And we need to build the conditions in the region for all the different actors, from Saudi Arabia to Iran, from Turkey to Egypt, and the neighbouring countries, Jordan and Lebanon, and others, to be able to live with whatever agreement the Syrian parties come to in Geneva. Otherwise we will start again and again and again. This is exactly the exercise we are engaged in, accompanying the work of the United Nations – and, believe me, if we use our leverage and we use our power and we put our leverage and our power at the service of the UN mediation, this is not giving up our role. This is serving our interests to the best; this is playing our role to the best because, for the European Union, the multilateral UN way is the way to resolve conflicts.  I have always thought that we were all on the same page on this, and that particularly at this moment it is essential for the European Union to help, support and feed into the UN multilateral efforts to achieve peace. Any agreement found will not be sustained or sustainable if it is not embedded in a multilateral, global UN framework. This is the work we are doing. To turn to Russia: first of all, some of you asked for my comments on the Astana process. I believe it is useful. I believe the agreement that was reached recently on de-escalation zones is good, but we have seen agreements of this kind before and we know very well that the point is the implementation. The point is the real de-escalation of violence on the ground. The point is real humanitarian access in all parts of Syria. That is the key. And that is why we are insisting on the need for the guarantors of the Astana process to guarantee the implementation of the agreement. They have a mechanism and they have a timetable that is also closely connected with the timetable of the talks in Geneva. We encourage the three guarantors of the Astana process to work to implement the agreement and also to create the strongest possible link between the military de-escalation efforts agreed in Astana and the political intra-Syrian talks led by the UN in Geneva. It is very clear to us, and I believe also to the UN Security Council Members – all of them – that the political, intra-Syrian negotiations should take place in Geneva under the UN leadership.  Some of you also asked me about the position of Russia, and the position of the US. Let me tell you very clearly. I met Foreign Minister Lavrov, as some of you mentioned, a few weeks ago in Moscow, and this work on Syria was the main point. We also discussed the situation in Ukraine as you can imagine. With Rex Tillerson the constant cooperation and coordination we have is producing similar approaches that you see in messaging and action. He called me on the day of Lavrov’s visit to Washington precisely to debrief me about the visit. I can tell you, sometimes we pay less attention than they do to what we are doing, and I find that quite a paradox. Last week I was in the UN Security Council, and the US Permanent Representative to the UN, Nikki Haley, referred to the European Union’s key role in the Syria crisis, mentioning especially the means of leverage we have in terms of reconstruction and reconciliation. When Rex Tillerson was in Moscow, look at the press conference Lavrov held with him: Lavrov mentioned the Brussels conference and the role of the European Union in this. Sometimes I have the feeling that we give the work we are doing less recognition than it gets from some of our interlocutors on the global scene. We should be more self-confident about what we are doing, and recognise it a little bit more. Our role is not only humanitarian, but it is based on this good humanitarian work we are doing. I shall finish by saying I believe that the region is, and will continue to be, the key. I will be in the region again at the end of this week, in Jordan for a regional forum. I see a lot of potential there to try and accompany the various Syrian parties in what are, in some cases, local processes that can open small bridges or small spaces for attempts at reconciliation. In Europe we know very well that no end of war comes easily. We have lived through wars on our territory that required not only a lot of mediation, a lot of reconciliation, a lot of transitional justice and a lot of accountability, but also a lot of reconstruction – physical reconstruction and also the reconstruction of the social fabric of trust among communities. This will be one of the most challenging efforts we will have to make, to support the possibility of different kinds of Syrians feeling at home in the Syria of the future and trusting their neighbours, whoever they are. We will move now to another debate that certainly touches on some of these issues, but I think that the European Union will also have to play the card, when the time comes, of reconstructing – or accompanying the Syrians as they try to reconstruct – the social fabric, and as they manage, we hope, to give rebirth to their country in a united manner.

name: President. –
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 18 May 2017. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments)

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation of Christians in the Middle East [2017/2686 (RSP)].

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, on Palm Sunday, as you well remember, two Coptic churches were attacked in Egypt as worshippers gathered for mass. Forty-five people were killed and hundreds were wounded. Daesh terrorists claimed responsibility for the attack, because in their minds there is no room for the peaceful coexistence of different faiths. I will start with just one of the terrible attacks on Christians in the Middle East and mention the response that this madness provoked, which was one of the best responses I have ever seen to one of these attacks. Just a week later, on Easter Sunday in Jordan, tens of Muslim youths stood guard to protect churches and Christian believers to make sure that they could celebrate their holiest festivity in peace and respect. I believe that these young people of Muslim faith, these young Jordanians, are Daesh’s worst nightmare. They show the real face of the Middle East and they honour hundreds of years of peaceful coexistence of different religious faiths in the Middle East. You will remember well the message that His Majesty the King of Jordan delivered in this very Chamber exactly along these lines. When Pope Francis embarked on his historic visit to Egypt last month, he described Christians, Muslims and people of all faiths as fellow travellers. For thousands of years people of different religions have been fellow travellers in the Middle East, in Europe and in the rest of the word. At a time when freedom of religion or belief is coming under attack in many parts of our world, we have a duty first of all to preserve this diversity here in Europe as well. Religious or ethnic groups – Christians and others – are being forced to flee from lands they have inhabited for centuries. We can, and must, preserve the space for people of different backgrounds to be fellow travellers, sharing their land and their lives. Christianity was born in the Middle East. It belongs to the Middle East. Yet we know that entire Christian communities have been forced to leave their home countries and their region. The phenomenon is not new, but what is new is the trend that is now more worrying than ever. This is not only causing great human suffering to Christians as well as to many other minorities in the region but, if the Middle East loses its incredible diversity – that is a problem in itself – it would also lose its greatest richness. For this reason, the European Union is engaged on a daily basis to protect all minorities and every person’s human rights with concrete actions in several fields. I will mention a few of them. First, we systematically raise freedom of religion and belief at different levels of our political dialogues, including in our human rights dialogues with countries in the Middle East. Together with a number of partner countries, we have developed what we call our partnership priorities in order to promote common interests. The protection of human rights is always part of our own priorities. In the second field of action we always condemn violence against religious or belief minorities with public statements and with private demarches. Public advocacy is not always sufficient, but it reminds all these community groups that they are not alone in this struggle. In the third field of action we work to ensure that freedom of religion and belief remains prominently on the global agenda and specifically on the UN agenda, featuring a strong human rights approach. In the fourth field of action the EU Special Representative, Stavros Lambrinidis, is doing an amazing job and keeps raising these issues in all his official visits and dialogues – most recently to Egypt, just to mention one country. In May 2016, as a follow-up to the European Parliament’s resolution on the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by Daesh, we appointed Mr Figel' as the first Special Envoy for the promotion of freedom of religion or belief outside the European Union. In the fifth field of action we are seeking the broadest engagement of relevant regional actors and international organisations. Preserving diversity is, first and foremost, a Middle Eastern interest, so we will not stop working to protect all minorities. But we are not alone in this task and we look for cooperation with our partners. Sixth, we are providing very concrete financial support to local communities and minorities through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. The 2016 global call for proposals addressed the rights of persons belonging to minorities, and the new call on freedom of religion or belief will be launched in 2017, aiming at supporting local and international civil society organisations in promoting mutual tolerance and understanding. We are also providing support to Christians in countries where they are facing a precarious situation. In Iraq, for example, we are making sure that our projects for stabilisation also deliver on the needs of Christian communities. Last, but certainly not least, we are fighting terrorism through security cooperation, with our work to end the conflicts in our region, and by addressing the social, economic and cultural roots of radicalisation. In this work we also have a duty to get the narrative right and also to represent the best face of the Middle East: the face of diversity, the face of those Muslim young people protecting Christian churches. We must give voice, if I can quote Pope Francis in Italian: ..."non solo alla inciviltà del conflitto, ma anche alla civiltà dell'incontro". The narrative is important: to dismantle the narrative of those who believe that there is no space for living together either in the Middle East or elsewhere. Even in Syria – we were discussing this a few minutes ago – in the middle of the most violent conflict of our times, we hear stories of Christian and Muslim neighbours helping each other to make it through the war. The different religious groups and minorities – identities, groups – in Syria will have the major responsibility of trying to bridge the differences, the hate, and the difficulty of starting to live together again once the conflict is over. There is still room for hope. A future of diversity for the Middle East is possible, and we believe that this is work which we can do together with our partners, both globally and in the region. That is the commitment of our European Union: protecting and offering the perspective of diversity and unity.

name: Presidente. –
text: The services of the Presidency inform me that we are very late on the roadmap, after this debate five more will have to take place and therefore it is not possible, for this debate, to use the "blue cards".

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, when we speak of Christians in the Middle East, we think first of all - Madam High Representative too - of the Copts of Egypt. It is true, their situation is worrying. This community has been savagely hit by a series of terrorist attacks. Their security must of course be reinforced and the Egyptian authorities are making efforts in this direction. I believe that this issue must be placed in a larger context of persecution of Christians in the Middle East and that is why our political group has asked to have this debate, and not to speak only of the Copts. It should be noted that the proclamation of the caliphate by the group known as Daesh, or ISIS, is not only part of the war between Shiites and Sunnis, but is also directed against Christians. It is a fact that Daesh systematically targets Christians and the term genocide has been used correctly because it is precisely a desire to destroy Christian communities. As the High Representative has also said, the disappearance of Christians in the Middle East would be a tragedy that would mark the end of difference and of diverse societies. I think we totally agree and I think we absolutely have to prevent it. The European Union can act on several fronts, in particular by fighting against the instrumentalization of religion in conflicts. We must be adamant about respecting and implementing the provisions of international law on religious freedom, but in order to do this we must recognize the nature of this conflict.

name: Arne Lietz
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Madam High Representative! I grew up as a Christian in the socialist dictatorship in an oppositional parish household. In doing so, I myself experienced with family and friends what it means when a political system encroaches on people's personal and freedoms and they even leave the country as a result. I welcome the fact that we are dealing here today with the situation of Christians in the Middle East. However, I would like to take this debate as an opportunity to call for freedom of all religions in the Middle East and in other parts of the world. I would like to address three points here. Point one: Freedom of religion is an indispensable prerequisite for democratic development in the Middle East. In view of the religious plurality in the Middle East, respect for religious freedom is indispensable for peaceful coexistence, as the High Representative has just said. I call on the EU to stand up for the rights of non-believers and those of different faiths in countries like Saudi Arabia and Qatar, who are unfortunately trampled on there. In Egypt, too, the situation of Coptic Christians remains precarious. The wars in Syria and Iraq have led to the exodus of Christians and Yazidis in particular. These examples contrast with Tunisia, where the newly elected government has spoken out in favor of religious tolerance. For this it deserves the support of the European Union. Second, education and interfaith dialogue need to be strengthened. An important aspect of international support was made clear by Pope Francis on his last visit to Egypt. He emphasized that education and also religious education had to be strengthened in order to promote interreligious dialogue and contribute to peaceful coexistence. The EU can and should do more in this area. Third: the right to belong to any religion or to no religion, is universal and must be the benchmark for EU foreign policy.Article 18 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights establishes this universality of religious freedom.There is broad consensus on this in this House.On my initiative, in 2015 my colleague Rainer Wieland I published a call for active action against the worldwide persecution of religious minorities and for the defense of religious freedom as a human right.Members of this parliament from 28 countries supported this decision.Finally, I would like to mention the example of the award of the last Sakharov Prize.The European Parliament clearly supported two representatives of the Yazidi minorities in Iraq and Syria.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I have a long association with the Coptic Christians in Egypt through its large diaspora community living in London. The attacks of last month against two Christian churches in Egypt were the latest in a series of atrocities. These remind us not only of the continued security risk that Egypt faces from Al-Qaeda, particularly in the Sinai, but also of the wider plight that Christians as communities face across the entire Middle East. There are around 30 million Christians living in the region, the largest numbers based in Egypt, Lebanon and Syria. The Syrian civil war has tragically seen tens of thousands of Christians displaced and fleeing for their lives as Isis has deliberately targeted them both there and in neighbouring Iraq where, on a visit two years ago, I met a number of Assyrian Christian IDPs. I would like to take this opportunity to praise the efforts of the KRG in providing shelter for Christian refugees housed within its territory. Whilst I of course also welcome the support from EU Member States that has been given and offered to Christian refugees from the Middle East, I believe that it is important that we recognise that such expulsions of Christians is precisely the aim of groups like Isis, who wish to see a Middle East free of all non-Sunni Muslim religious minorities. Our efforts should therefore concentrate on establishing safe haven autonomous regions within the Middle East, such as in the Nineveh Plains in Iraq, and supporting communities to rebuild their lives and defend themselves in the places that their civilisation has been rooted for over two millennia. With some five million refugees and IDPs uprooted from their homes due to the conflicts in Iraq and Syria, it is easy for the plight of the Middle East Christians to be forgotten.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank you for the message of hope that you have brought in the particularly difficult debate that we must have again today. You are sending a message of hope not only to Christians, but to all religious groups that are today victims of persecution, discrimination, violence and murders. On the points you have raised, we must continue to insist on freedom of religion and, as Europe, take the lead for the respect of human rights worldwide. These are the things that we as Europe, as the European Union, must continue to do. We must focus on that. That is why I am very happy with the points you have listed. I would also like to emphasize that we must focus on punishing the perpetrators. As long as we uphold impunity, discrimination and violence will continue. We as Europe must also focus on that. It is a sign of real respect for human rights that you bring to order the perpetrators of discrimination and murders. Finally, Mrs Mogherini, you know that we as Liberals attach great importance to peace and stability in the region. I do not know how many times I have debated with you here on the Middle East, on Israel and Palestine. Well, next Thursday we will be putting an important resolution to the vote. Negotiations on this will take place tomorrow morning and we will work very hard with all parties to make a further plea to Israel and Palestine for that two-state solution. If we take that step, I think violence will diminish and perhaps there will be peace, allowing religious minorities to coexist in peace. You certainly have our support to go further and continue to advocate for human rights in the rest of the world.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - In the eastern part of the Maghreb and Mashreq, the situation of all minorities, whether religious or national, has been very difficult in recent years. Most of these countries have been inhabited for more than 8,000 years and have always suffered great damage, both in rural and urban areas, during wars. Nevertheless, dozens of different religions and ethnic groups have developed here for centuries in symbiosis and in touching each other. In recent years, with the advent of radical Islam, the situation of all minorities has deteriorated significantly. Anyone who does not conform to the ideas of radical movements, such as the Islamic State, can be murdered, tortured, raped or otherwise enslaved, according to its ruling officials. This is often a forced conversion. The largest of these vulnerable groups are the Christian Copts. In some parts of Egypt, traditionally rebellious nomadic tribes have embraced these ideas, and in addition to the life insecurity of Christians and minority Islamic movements, this situation threatens to stabilize the country's economy. We should therefore support the action of Egyptian and other governments against this danger.

name: Bodil Valero
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! As has already been said, conflicts, persecution and discrimination have driven thousands of Christians, but also other religious minorities, from their homes, and many have been forced to seek protection in the EU. Although Christians have lived in the Middle East for over 2,000 years, they are now only three to four percent of the region's population. That is a decrease from 20 percent one hundred years ago. In Sweden today live about 120,000 people from the ethno-Christian group Assyrians / Syrians / Chaldeans originating from Turkey, Syria, Iraq and Lebanon. Many arrived as early as the 1970s, but a large number have arrived recently. But as the diasporas of Europe grow, the continued existence of Christians in the Middle East is seriously threatened. But the wars in the immediate area will one day end, after all, and then we must be prepared to provide support for reconstruction and the opportunity for all those who want to return to their homes to do so. But for that to be possible, all religious and ethnic minority groups must have both the right and the opportunity to live in their historic and traditional homelands in dignity, equality and security, and to enjoy their democratic, human and political rights. Mrs Mogherini has already told us about everything we do, and that is very good. But we can also be a major contributor to promoting political dialogue. Mainly perhaps by recognizing the many ethnic and religious groups that originate from and live in the area, but also by letting them make their voices heard in political negotiations and discussions about the future and reconstruction of their homelands. Thanks!

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Madam High Representative, this is not the first time that I have stood in this Chamber to draw attention to the terrible suffering of Christian communities throughout the Middle East. It would appear that, far from major moves being made to alleviate that suffering, it is doomed to continue. Only this Easter, speculation increased over whether or not Christianity had a future in the Middle East. These are ancient communities, existing since the earliest foundations of the faith, and it is a daunting prospect that we could let Asian communities wither in the face of the growing radical Islamism throughout the region. Whilst the bombings of the Coptic Church in Egypt by Islamic State were a tragedy, the support by the Egyptian Government is a model that should be emulated throughout the region. The attack was not just on a community but on all Egyptians. We must continue to draw attention to the situation of Christians and to make sure that more is done to prevent the destruction of these ancient communities.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. -  Mister President! I am very happy that today we can discuss the dramatic situation of Christians in the Middle East with Mrs Mogherini. The immediate impetus for me to move this item on the agenda was the terrible terrorist attacks against Coptic Christians at Easter in Egypt. But also in this context we have to ask ourselves why in the 21st century - after around 2,000 years - Christians in the Middle East are exposed to this terrible persecution. It is not just IS, Al-Qaida, Al-Nusra - with the best possible support from Saudi Arabia - who are responsible here. We can say that an increasingly fanatical, aggressive Islam also does its part. This can also be seen in organizations like the Muslim Brotherhood. Because the Sharia ultimately does not tolerate a Christian minority and certainly not the practice of religion. Nevertheless, the European Parliament and the Commission also court European branches of the Muslim Brotherhood such as the organizations ENORB or FEMYSO. You give money - 85,000 euros for a brochure for Islamic youth organizations or even 450,000 euros for a Sharia project in Ireland. And here in the house, too, an ex-FEMYSO president is invited to the LIBE committee to let her talk about Islamophobia. One could have seen that their Facebook account was bursting with contacts with Hamas and radical Muslim Brotherhoods. With so much ignorance, what will our Assyrian, Aramaic and Coptic persecuted Christians think? You really have to ask yourself: is the West really clear in the head? The Christians in the Orient feel that Europe has left them in the lurch, but they need our material as well as ideal support more than ever. Please we act quickly! Prayer alone will probably not be enough.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Madam President, liberate, protect, rebuild: these three objectives should be ours on the issue of Eastern Christians, which we are addressing today. Free Eastern Christians from the gangrene which directly threatens them. We cannot do everything, but we can ask that they finally have freedom of religion, the removal of the offense of blasphemy in Muslim states with which we have diplomatic relations, and the removal of the mention of religion. on identity documents. Protect, because without lasting peace for the peoples of the Near and Middle East, we know that we may one day be the next victims. Send international observers or facilitate their sending. Finally, rebuild, because these peoples and communities do not aspire to migrate to us. They do not aspire to leave their land but, on the contrary, to stay or return when they have been forced to leave it.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, more than 200 million people are persecuted for their religious faith - Christians - throughout the world. Last year - 2016 - was a disastrous year in which 90,000 Christians died. It is evident that with the self-proclamation of the Caliphate and the Islamic State, this regrettable fact has become much more visible and the images of twenty-one Coptic Christians on the beaches of Libya in 2015 went around the world. In December 2016, there was another attack in Cairo, where 25 people died and more than 40-some were injured. The high representative has reminded us of the attacks on Palm Sunday. And it is true that there is a dramatic decrease in the presence of Christians in the region. In 2003, in Iraq there were a million Christians; Today, there are only 300,000. In the Middle East as a whole - it has been recalled by some of the people who have spoken, who have preceded me in the use of the word - the population in the Middle East of Christians was 9%; today, it is less than 2.9%. Therefore, faced with this picture, Madam President, we have to react and we must, of course, keep - as the High Representative has said - this issue at the top of the agenda. And, of course, we have to mobilize all the resources - which are many, as the High Representative has told us - to try to guarantee the rights of ethnic and religious minorities. I will end, Madam President, by saying that we must also support projects like that of the Bishop of Kirkuk, who has created a university with all religious confessions where all the refugees from Mosul are.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Madam High Commissioner, the existence of Christian communities in the Middle East goes back to the very moment of the origin of Christianity. In fact, it was in many of these communities that the first approximation between the Christian religion and classical philosophical thought took place. Christians who represented around 20% a century ago are now reduced to 3 or 4% of the region's population. Especially in the past 15 years, Christians in the Middle East have been subjected to discrimination, persecution and violence that often results in exile or death. The terrorist attacks carried out against religious minorities in this part of the globe are not new, not even exclusive to the Christian religion. Muslims who profess other conceptions of Islam are, moreover, the main victims of some kind of Islamic extremism. There, as here, terrorism uses atrocious violence, scares, dehumanizes and, finally, kills. In the territories occupied by the Islamic State, the Christian community is subjected to humiliation and absolutely demeaning pressure to convert to Islam. Populations are slaughtered, women are raped and turned into sex slaves. Outside these territories, terrorist attacks are carried out that kill believers in the sacred place of worship. We all remember, as has already been mentioned, the recent terrorist attacks in Egypt, two explosions on Palm Sunday, one inside a church, another outside another Catholic place of worship, 45 dead and more than 100 wounded. The war between Sunnis and Shiites, the growing influence of Islam on political institutions and the disruption of the state resulting from the war in Iraq contributed to a scenario of radicalization that jeopardizes the integrity of religious minorities. Europe must do its utmost to provide full support to these Christian communities that are so violently persecuted in the Middle East.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko (ECR).
text: – Madam President, as we just heard, 15 years ago there were about 2.3 to 2.5 million Christians in Iraq, and today there are about 200 000. In Lebanon we have one million Christian refugees from Syria. This is an official number, the unofficial number is twice as many. Two-thirds of Christians have left Syria. Are they safe in Lebanon? Hardly. Their future is uncertain, to say the least. All in all last year, as we also heard today, about 80 000 or 90 000 Christians were murdered throughout the world. The number was down by half in comparison with the previous years. A success? I would not say so. All these numbers are terrifying. So why is the reaction of the EU and the entire Western world so inadequate? One would think it is the West that should defend Christians because Christianity is a vital part of our civilisation. Without Christianity, we would not have existed. It is our sacred duty, as Christians, to defend Christians. If we do not defend them, no one will. So why are we not doing so? One of the reasons lies in deep anti-Christian prejudices. In Europe, Christians have been an object of increasing discrimination, and one would hardly expect that this hostility to European Christians could result in a full-bodied defence of Christians elsewhere. The fact that this meek reaction by Europe can be explained does not make it less shameful.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, five months ago we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Nadia Murad to draw attention to the religious minority of the Yazidis, which has been the subject of a genocidal campaign by Daesh militants, but the senseless and heartless brutality of Daesh continues. The slaughter of Christians in Egypt, which we are debating today, once again disfigures the face of humanity, as Pope Francis correctly warned this week. Ms Mogherini, I thank you for the strong comments you made today. I support you and hope your actions will be successful. Respect for fundamental and human rights is the core value of the European Union. Any violation of these rights, whether within or outside the EU, affects the democratic principles upon which our society is founded. All minorities, religious, ethnic or sexual, deserve our unstinting protection.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: - Madam President!First of all, I would like to thank the political groups for approving my motion, so that we have the subject of the persecution of Christians on the agenda here today.The topic is important because it is big.Over 200 million Christians worldwide are persecuted for their Christian faith.By the way: Last year the EU appointed a special envoy for freedom of belief and religion who is responsible for this.So I wonder where he is, and I am amazed that, at the instigation of the so-called Christian Democrats, he is not here today.But the important question is: Do we want to help Christians?And if we want to help, then how?We cannot take in all the refugees in the world, so we have to choose.And that is why I demand: If we have to choose, then let us give preference to Christians!

name: Mireille D’Ornano (ENF).
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, at the beginning of the twentieth century, a quarter of the inhabitants of the Middle East were Christians. They are now 3%. We will no longer be able to say that we did not know. Of course, Iraqi and coalition forces are making progress and achieving success in liberating Iraqi territories conquered by the "Islamic State" group - as we speak, Daesh now only holds 10% of the city of Mosul - but these military successes should not obscure reality. The Christians of Karacoche certainly celebrated Easter 2017 in their city, symbolically. Yet most of the people in the region are unwilling or unable to return home. In Iraq, where I visited last year, Christians have been victims of genocidal activities and continue to leave their country. Also, if we are to welcome Christians in suffering, it is also our duty to help them, especially in the Plain of Nineveh, to rebuild their city. Indeed, the Iraqi state is more concerned with its strategic ulterior motives in the Sunni-Shiite conflict than with the plight of Christians. Faced with barbarism, Europe has the opportunity to speak with one voice to raise awareness before it is too late.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, the persecution, harassment, murder and violent Islamization of Christians living in the Middle East can be compared to the martyrdom period of the early years of Christianity. A literal genocide is taking place against Christians, who are disappearing from the demographic, cultural and religious map of the Holy Land. During my visit to Maaloula, Syria, I witnessed the destruction of priceless relics caused by Islamists in the historic Monastery of Agia Thekla. Note that Christians and monuments experienced Islamic barbarism while no Muslim was harmed. In ISIS slave markets, a young Christian or Yezidi, 10 to 20 years old, sells for about $ 150, while young women aged 1 to 9 sell for $ 200. Those who fight for multiculturalism and open borders should ask themselves how much human dignity and faith are worth. No one needs to accuse me of being Islamophobic and intolerant. I prefer not to accept the massacre and humiliation of Christians by Islamists, despite the political correctness that is being promoted. Christians are being annihilated in the Middle East. Europe will have a turn now.

name: Michèle Alliot-Marie (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, as far as Eastern Christians are concerned, the European Union must go beyond speeches of good intentions and polite generalizations on human rights. We cannot let Daesh redesign the Middle East and eradicate Christian minorities. When Muslims are attacked around the world, Muslim countries respond. When Jews are attacked, Israel reacts. Europe, which has Christian roots - like it or not - must also make its voice heard. What will she say as Christians are forced to leave the regions that are their traditional anchors? What are we going to do to allow them to stay or to come back? Of course, the European Union can rely on religious authorities and local governments when they are open, but more needs to be done. What is at stake is not just respect for human rights, but also tolerance, balance, security in the Middle East and, from the Middle East, the whole world. We must therefore take concrete action today. Madam High Representative, means do exist, but beyond speeches or certain initiatives on human rights, what are you actually going to implement in the judicial, diplomatic, coercive and even military fields to enable people to stay or come back home?

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, today we want not only to denounce, but also to underline the institutionalized discrimination and persecution that Christian minorities are suffering in many Middle Eastern countries. But we would also like to remember that this is also being suffered by some who are considered close allies. In Egypt, the Coptic minority has been denouncing that they do not receive security, they are not provided sufficient security. As we know, there have been terrible attacks on your churches in recent months. In the Gulf countries, in several major Gulf countries, the visibility of Christianity is prohibited. Sharply prohibited. And many Christians today are migrants in the Gulf, especially vulnerable migrant workers. We have to use all our tools - also diplomatic ones - to protect those communities, but remembering that there are many, many minorities discriminated against: Yazidis, Shiites in some countries, Kurds, Turkmen. They are many, and some Sunni groups. Tolerance is for everyone.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: - Talking about the situation of Christians in the Middle East today mainly raises the pressing question of whether there is still a place and a future for them in the Arab world. Or will the slogan of expelling Jews and Christians, painted on walls in Arab cities after Saturday's songs, actually materialize in the 21st century? The scourge of Islamist terrorism afflicting Christians in the Middle East is sweeping across the European continent just as well today. For the sake of self-interest alone, the European Union should clearly stand up as the protector of Christians and other minorities in the Middle East. This also means providing concrete support to reform-minded forces. Education within the Muslim community is very important here, because in the words of an expert by experience, totalitarianism based on the Islamic faith is the worst among all government systems. I therefore call on the EU and the Member States to commit themselves to the best of their ability for a future for Christians in the Middle East. After all, their future is closely linked to the Europe of the future.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Mrs Mogherini, colleagues, we are witnessing a violent and systematic process of ousting religious minorities from the Middle East. We are alarmed to see radical groups in Syria and Iraq subject women and children to severe persecution, oppression and discrimination. Hundreds of families in the Middle East are forced to make fateful decisions every day about whether to leave their homeland, abandon their faith or part with their lives. The main repressive body is the Islamic State, which purposefully destroys cities, religious temples and shrines. Alas, these are not historical facts from another era, but real pictures from the last six years. In this regard, I call on the European Union to take urgent measures to protect all religious minorities in the Middle East. I strongly believe that the peaceful coexistence of Christians and Muslims and all religious minorities in the Middle East is the foundation on which the European Union must build peace and security in the region.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, US Vice President Pence, speaking to an evangelical association, condemned Isis guilty of genocide against Christians and says "it is time for the world to call them by his name" and quoted Trump , who calls them by name, "Islamic radical terrorists". Now, a question spontaneously arises: how come the high representatives, starting with the High Representative, do not even have the courage to call them by name these "genocidal"? I hope that in the reply, if there has been inattention or omission, the High Representative will correct this grave error. We must have the courage to call the culprits of this genocide, in pieces, because it is something that happens before our eyes, something that affects our brothers of blood and also of religion. This morning we welcomed a high exponent of the African Union with great salamelecs, yet 70 per cent of the dead Christians are not in the Middle East, they are in Africa, but no one, after so many salamons, has considered it right to draw the attention of this high African political authority. More courage is needed, gentlemen of the European Union!

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the terrorist attacks against the Coptic community in Egypt are part of an attempted genocide. In the words of Isis stated a few weeks ago, Christians and their holy sites are legitimate targets in a war against infidels and tyrants. If this total contempt for human dignity does not end the discussion about whether the Christians can live under Jihadi Salafists as long as they pay a penalty tax, I do not know if anything will, because the threat against Christians in Egypt is fully in line with the barbaric acts of Isis in other parts of the Middle East.  Last February, a majority of this Parliament passed a resolution that defines the persecution of Christians in Iraq and Syria as genocide. This is, of course, important, but in view of the constant threats against Christians, it is imperative that further steps are taken. The Commission must act for a legally-binding genocide recognition in the UN Security Council.  Efforts for legal action against the perpetrators must be intensified. Respect for freedom of religion must be a top priority. Middle East governments – terrorist groups alike – should always know: violation of the universal right to believe and worship will be punished. Justice will prevail.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: - It is appropriate for Mr Kristjan to take the form of a series. For the purposes of the communication, the members of the Committee of the Regions shall be informed in the event of a conflict between the members of the Commission and the President of the Republic. L-isplużjonijiet li saru f'ņadd il-Palm f'żewġ knejjes communicates. Il-Kristjani ġew attacked the r-reliçjon u t-twemmin tagħhom għal għexieren ta ’snin. It is possible for a group of terrorists to enter into a regime, which is to discriminate against each other, and to ensure that they are committed and relied on. Dan huwa l-kontra l-valuri tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Irridu niddefendu l-pluraliżmu reliġjuż. L-Unioni Ewropea trid tkun aktar b’saħħitha u tikkundanna kull forma ta intolleranza u vjolenza kontra l-persuni minħabba r-reliġjon tagħhom. Il-Kunsill tal-Affarijiet Barranin li jmiss irid jindirizza dil-kwistjoni issa u mhux iktar tard.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, colleagues, the situation of the Christians in the Middle East is alarming, as many of us here are saying, especially in Syria and Iraq. The Christians, as the indigenous people of the region, creating a much-needed balance between religion and ethnic groups, are expelled or killed, or persecuted. With no Christians left, the European Union loses a reliable and perspective partner for reconstructing the Middle East. Madam High Representative, it should be our foremost priority to protect people who are culturally and civilisation-wise close to Europeans. We should support these groups, both in the humanitarian and political ways – but not only in Syria and Iraq, but also in the southern region of Turkey and other countries in the Middle East. It is a shame we let these atrocities happen, but thank you very much for the things you expressed in your statement at the beginning about the ways we support the minorities and the groups there. Another example is the Palestinian Authority. Churches under their authority are not able to register, even though they fulfil all requirements set by the law. The Palestinian Authorities simply refuse them. I have these examples; I can bring them. Madam High Representative, I call upon you to discuss these matters with the Palestinian authorities.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: - Madam President, massacres, assassinations, persecutions, abuses, humiliations, rapes, kidnappings, destroyed monasteries and churches, spoliations, expulsions, exodus ... The history of Eastern Christians is tragic and their daily life is a real ordeal. On April 16, Christians in the West and Christians in the East celebrated Easter. Unfortunately, the echo of oriental bells responding to the sound of our church steeples is fading and if Western chanceries persist in restricting themselves to customary protests, soon this echo will die out. The recent attacks against the Copts in Egypt remind us of this. Eastern Christians are the target of Islamist groups who intend to strip the Middle East of their presence. Eastern Christian communities, among the oldest in the world, are now on borrowed time, even though they have been established for several centuries, long before the Arab-Muslim conquests. At the turn of the twentieth century, nearly one in four Middle Easterners was Christian. Today, Christian communities represent 3-4% of the population of the Middle East. They are only 11 million, a drop in the bucket among a population of 320 million Muslims. Under the pretext of exporting democracy with bombs from Iraq to Libya, our governments have allowed the emergence of jihadist groups. Western countries urgently need to adopt a realistic international policy. It is a disservice to Eastern Christians to demonize the Syrian and Russian governments while negotiating with Turkey and prostituting themselves with the godfathers of international jihadism, the Gulf petromonarchies.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE).
text: –  Madam President, dear colleagues, what we are talking about today is not a question of religiosity. The elimination of Christians from the Middle East is much more of a human rights and security issue. In Egypt the Coptic community enjoys great support from President Sisi, but even so it is extremely difficult to counter jihadism. In Iraq, however, the Christians will clearly disappear within a very short time. Even if Isis is on the defensive, there is no guarantee of security at all. The EU is doing a lot to provide aid, but individual Member States also have their homework. If the international community misses the opportunity to help Christians return to their homes, tens of thousands, maybe hundreds of thousands, of families may decide to leave Iraq for ever. EU financial support, including development and ECHO programmes, is inaccessible to religious minorities and historical churches. The result is that affected communities are left out of the EU’s humanitarian projects. Through the activities of  AFET and DEVE, we must continue efforts to involve the relevant  organisations as partners in the European Union aid and reconstruction projects. European politicians, let’s wake up, really wake up. We have been given a chance, so we should use it.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Mrs. Mogherini! I express my solidarity with your words. Congratulations! It's good that we are debating this. The European Union, or Europe in general, has really Christian roots, but at the same time we are a continent, we are a highly tolerant community: we welcome immigrants of various faiths, including Muslims, we allow them to cultivate their religion here, and we should expect the same from the countries of the Middle East. I believe that we should make every effort to prevent the de-Christianization of this region. And from this point of view, I wanted to endorse what Mr Legutko said: Lebanon is an example of a country where Christians and Muslims coexist. Lebanon now has almost the same number of immigrants as regular citizens. Let us pay attention to this country, let us help, because I think that Christians in the Middle East have the right to expect help from us, and we are obliged to do so.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Madam President! The Christian-Jewish cultural heritage in this area dates back millennia, and it is a culture that has dominated the Middle East for longer than the cultures that currently make up the majority. Therefore, it is a double disaster that the sectarian conflicts that ravage the territories, especially Iraq and Syria, but also elsewhere, mean that the Christians and other minorities in the territories come under double pressure, namely both the general pressure that these wars and conflicts lead to, and in particular also the pressure, that it is clear that the minority groups are particularly vulnerable to religious persecution, to extinction, to other crimes against humanity. That is why, as the European Union, we also have an obligation to protect the people who come under this pressure, and perhaps to a special extent to take Christians into refugee camps and elsewhere when EU countries choose quota refugees. There is no doubt that this is a problem which must be taken seriously and which must be dealt with immediately if there is to continue to be a Christian cultural heritage in these countries.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr President, at this time, Christians and other minorities are subject to particular persecution in some parts of the Middle East and Africa. Daesh activity is particularly serious, and I recall that our Resolution of February 2016 classified the acts perpetrated by Daesh against these minorities as genocide and requested that the international community put in place the necessary mechanisms so that the International Criminal Court could purge the corresponding criminal responsibilities. Today, I have not heard you speak about the qualification of this matter as genocide, Mrs Mogherini. At the same time, we have to continue helping these persecuted minorities, help that can mean, in many cases, welcoming them into our territories and, in others - wherever circumstances allow - we will have to support initiatives that facilitate these displaced or persecuted people. return to their places of origin, as many of them wish. I welcome the announcement yesterday by the Spanish Foreign Minister that, at the end of this month, the second International Conference on victims of ethnic and religious violence in the Middle East will take place in Madrid, where some of these issues will be addressed. I have not heard a mention of this point from you either, Mrs Mogherini. Violence against religious minorities - and Christians in particular - makes no sense from any point of view, nor from any religion. And I am also going to quote Pope Francis, recently in Cairo: "God only likes the faith professed with life, because the only extremism that believers are allowed is charity." And finished. Christian thought is very close to this European Union. Therefore, at this time, what we cannot allow ourselves is that from the European Union we fail Christians.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Mr Millán Mon, it would be good for European leaders who claim to be Christians to hear and draw consequences from the message of Pope Francis, who, being religious, is also political. The trip he made to Egypt, in the aftermath of the attack on two Coptic churches, was powerful in that effort of ecumenical understanding, of solidarity, of peace, of combating extremist violence. And this week, in Fatima, the Pope recalled the importance of dialogue and coexistence between Christians, Muslims and other religious denominations for the salvation of humanity. Anyone who calls himself a Christian more obliged must understand that the defense of Christian communities and other religious minorities in the Middle East can only be ensured if Europe leads the international community in ensuring effective protection so that these pre-Islamic minorities can return to their ancestral territories. that have already been released, like Sinjar, or as they are released, as now in Mosul and around Mosul. It is therefore essential to give priority to supporting the reconstruction of these liberated areas, which has not yet been done. On the other hand, we must defeat and counter the Islamophobia and anti-Semitism that the populist extreme right is sowing in Europe, because without our Muslims we will not be able to overcome the terrorist threat and violent extremism.

name: President. –
text: There is a request for a blue card, but I am not taking blue cards because of our time constraints, and that was already announced by the previous Chair.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Madam President! According to Open Doors data, 2016 was the worst year in the last 25 years when it comes to persecuting Christians in the world. According to other data, four out of five people killed because of religion are Christians. Of the ten countries that record the worst persecution of Christians, nine are Islamic countries. All these data, and many more, show that, in fact, we are dealing with a systematic ethnic-religious cleansing and genocide. Nevertheless, the post-Christian West and post-Christian Europe are reluctant to address this topic. Western politicians avoid pointing to Christians as victims, special victims, and persecution. They prefer to talk, like Ms Mogherini, about diversity or, like some colleagues, about religious freedom, about tolerance. Parliament too - so eloquent when it comes to Islamic immigrants to Europe - is reluctant to deal with this topic. Suffice it to recall today's morning debate. It is difficult not to associate this with the fact that in part of Europe - also in parts of Europe - Christians are faced with growing hostility and discrimination.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we must be very aware that, often, Christians in the Middle East have suffered the most from internal conflicts to which they were not a party. On the contrary, they have tended to have a mediating, reconciliatory role – so they have been caught between a rock and a hard place. One of my visitors from Erbil told me that the EU needs to have an honest debate about whether the international community really wants Christians to survive in the region from which Christianity emerged. If Christians were not humans, they would have been defined long ago as an endangered species and taken under international protection, but now their numbers are decreasing with dramatic speed. We heard about ‘de-Christianisation of the Middle East’, and probably Christians will not survive another major conflict in the area. The question is whether there will be any Christians in liberated Mosul, or living in the Nineveh plains. I have two proposals to the Commission. Firstly, the EU and international organisations cannot provide aid directly to religion-based groups, so we need to change the rules, because churches can provide most direct help to people in real need. And secondly, the EU can make a difference: as a large provider of humanitarian aid, our red line should be to set as criteria for local authorities that humanitarian aid must reach all groups and minorities without discrimination, and that Christians and members of other minority religions will be guaranteed a return to their homes and equal rights.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Madam President, in the wake of the bloody assassination of Coptic Christians on Flower Sunday, Jesuit Father Henri Boulad not only condemned radical political Islam but also, among others, the democratic West, which “co-created the concept of false Islamophobia with Islamists. to silence any criticism of Islam ”. Father Boulad also accuses European leaders of “contributing to the collapse of a valuable cultural and civilizational past in the name of multicultural ideology, wild globalism and unbridled openness”. I welcome today's debate in the European Parliament on the situation of Christianity in the Middle East. It is the legitimate expectation of our endangered Christian Brothers in Syria and Iraq not to forget them, not to leave them to their fate. This event is a manifestation of Europe's awakening conscience. Similarly, the Union and the Foreign Service stand for increased support for the hundreds of thousands of members of Christian communities who have suffered religious-ethnic cleansing and brutal genocide. In this struggle, special thanks are due to the Open Doors human rights organization for the protection of persecuted Christians, as well as to the European People's Party for their protection, and last but not least to the Hungarian government office set up to help them.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Madam Mogherini, according to reports, persecution of Christians has risen worldwide for three years in a row. In total more than 200 million Christians live in countries where they are subject to hostility, which ranges from constant pressure, social discrimination and harassment to physical violence, imprisonment and death. Christians are now killed in more countries than ever before and are persecuted in more countries than any other religious group. For those of us who have been following the story of Christian persecution, this news does not come as a surprise. Instead, it serves as a sad confirmation of what we have been witnessing over the past few years. In the Middle East, Christians’ homes and churches have been destroyed, their cross torn down and smashed, and bibles burned to ashes. But the worst stories are those of decapitations, mass executions and torture. We must ask ourselves, how long will we allow Christians to be the most persecuted people in the world? Until there are none left in the Middle East? Until they are wiped out in other parts of the world? It is time to act. The EU must come to the aid of those who are suffering persecution because of their Christian faith – and we can certainly do more. I urge you, Madam High Representative, to keep the issue of the persecution of Christians high on your agenda.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: - Madam President, there is no doubt that the situation in the Middle East is a nightmare. In the cradle of Christianity, in the cradle of Christianity, where the ancient Christian communities are located, there is currently a roller coaster for their disappearance. And if today we are talking about the destruction of Christianity in the Middle East, we must make it clear that this is a pre-eminent genocide of Christians and if indeed, dear Mrs Mogherini, a Christian from the Middle East asks us here in the European Parliament what we are doing today to prevent its extinction what will be our response? What will be our answer when from 28% Christians in the Middle East became 5% today? What is our response to the destruction of religious Christian culture, today, in 2017 in Cyprus by Turkey, by an occupying power. And when we talk about genocides, the champion of Christian genocides was Turkey. Armenian genocide, Pontian genocide, Greek genocide, genocide in another form in Cyprus where the religious Christian culture is destroyed and I would very much like, Mrs. Mogherini, with my unlimited appreciation and respect, to tell me if to Mr. Celik, You recently met him and told him that a country like Turkey is not allowed to continue terrorizing Christians in the region. To terrorize the Greeks of Cyprus, to terrorize Greece, to actually terrorize the occupied territories where it is located and to destroy the religious monuments. In closing, I would like to ask you the next time you meet with Mr. Celik to tell him what is happening to all those religiously looted, stolen Christian treasures made by Turkey. We want an answer and I will ask for a fund for the Christian religious treasures.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, Madam Mogherini, I am with you and I fully support your message of hope for all religious groups that are victims of terrorism. I strongly condemn the attacks and attacks against Eastern Christians, to be sure we must say Eastern Christians, against all religious minorities, but let us not forget that these attacks are against the whole community, against all the Egyptian people, against all of us. The Egyptian population has united around these attacks and we are dividing here. I couldn't believe it when I heard colleagues in this plenary today who say they are Christians saying things like "if we have to save someone, let's save Christians first", or "killing Christians is a double death". I sincerely ask myself: am I the only one to see a profound contradiction in these statements? Did we go back to the time of the Crusades? It is because dignity, humanity and human rights are what must unite us and terrorism is the essential issue in all of this. It is true, there are thousands and thousands of Christians suffering and dying in the Middle East, but there are also millions of Muslims suffering and dying in the Middle East. We must be with everyone and with everyone.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: - Attacks on Christians and churches in the Middle East by extremists in the name of intolerance are unacceptable, so we must condemn and resist them.In the Middle East, we have witnessed the persecution and oppression of Christians for many years, resulting in the disappearance of Christian communities with a thousand-year tradition in many countries, including Egypt, Syria, Turkey, Iraq and Iran.Intolerance of Christians is also growing in the European Union.Although freedom of religion is a constitutional right, believers, especially Christians, are often the target of ridicule, insults, and violence.According to the Vatican, about 90,000 Christians are expected to lose their lives in 2016.It is a frightening fact that places Christians at the top of the most persecuted religious communities in the world.In addition to raising awareness of the seriousness of the situation of Christians in the Middle East, the task of the European Union is also to be more actively involved in places where tragedies occur.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Western world seems to have become accustomed to the persecution of Christians in the Middle East, as if it were an inevitable tragedy that can only be accepted. Many of the ancient Christian communities are reduced to a flicker, driven away by decades of wars, the spread of poverty, economic and political instability and persecution. The problem, however, does not only concern Christians. As Pope Francis said, many innocent people are severely tested, both Christians, Muslims, and from minorities such as the Yazidis. The theme is broader and concerns religious intolerance, which makes no difference in belief when it comes to fundamentalism. An intolerance that must be faced through a path of dialogue and reconciliation to build a future of respect, security and peace, far from any form of war. But we cannot just denounce as we are doing today, we must take the responsibility to break the veil of resignation with respect to those persecutions that affect us all, as citizens of the world and as Europeans, even before as Christians.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Christians are one of the most vulnerable communities in the Middle East.Systematic expulsions, burning of churches, terrorist attacks on their communities and the suppression of their existence in these areas have been happening for years before our eyes.We constantly warn about it, we constantly discuss it, but the security of Middle Eastern Christians somehow always ends up far behind some other priorities and particular interests.I think we finally have to face the fact that the position of Christians in the Middle East is much worse than it was before the Arab Spring and the wars in Iraq and Syria.I am in favor of us fighting for our interests, but taking care not to push entire regions around the world into chaos.Middle Eastern Christians are also collateral victims of this chaos.If we want them well, we must act, not just warn.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I am watching very closely the sincere tears of all of us for the extermination of Christians in the land of their fathers. Preserving civilizations in their cradle should be a primary goal of the legendary globalization. But from the luxury of Strasbourg, ladies and gentlemen, our tears are no answer. What we have to do unfortunately is what we should have already done. I am one of the first in this room, if not the first, to say that the famous "Arab Spring" would quickly turn into a cold, heavy Arab winter, but no one listened. We did not anticipate the events. We let them evolve. Member States have played a role in declaring and continuing wars. So now I repeat that, unfortunately, our tears are not enough, nor do they hear or feel them.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - I believe that the High Representative hears our call for effective help to Christians.Christians, who are the most persecuted religious group, as we all confirm here.The Middle East is their home and they do not want to leave, but are expelled, killed.At the same time, they themselves have lived here for 2,000 years.They are an educated and peaceful group of people.What can we do for them?In 2015, the bishops asked us to help them accept them here in Europe.The Czech Republic symbolically accepted 90 Iraqi Christians, but it was really just a symbolic gesture.I think there have been concrete proposals here today, and I ask Mrs Mogherini to do what has been said here.Let us support Christians in the Middle East.Let's help them stay in their homes.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: - Madam President, before our eyes the holocaust of Christians is unfolding in the Middle East, where Christianity was born. The source of the evils, we will not analyze now but it can not disappear, is as long as there is an Islamic State. Beheadings, rapes, kidnappings, destruction of churches and Christian monuments. Our prayers and wishes are for all Christians but also for all non-Christians in the Middle East, but especially for the Orthodox, the Catholics, the Copts and all the rest. Mrs Mogherini, I will say it slowly to translate it correctly: I publicly convey to you the appeal of the flock of two Orthodox metropolitans who were abducted exactly three years ago from Aleppo. I am referring to Metropolitan Paul and Metropolitan Johanna. The flock wants to know if you know anything about their fate.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is very good that we are having this debate, firstly because for too long we have seen destruction and execution, the destroying of the Christian heritage and people in the Middle East, and we are really the only ones they can turn to. It is especially important that we send out a message to our fellow Christian brothers and sisters that the European Union is going to stand behind them. I was very encouraged by words of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Ms Mogherini, which are important to these people not only psychologically but also in a practical sense. The fact that four out of five people killed because of their religion are Christian tells its own tale, and we have a powerful role to play, especially in terms of humanitarian aid, development aid, etcetera. It should be a condition of aid that religious tolerance will be practised in these areas, and especially that there will be due regard for Christians. Many of us in Europe are Christian: are we are going to stand up for Christians in the Middle East?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the situation of Christians in the Middle East is nightmarish. We also saw it recently in the jihadist attacks on the Coptic Church in Egypt. The jihadists slaughter the Christian populations in Syria and elsewhere, carrying out a kind of religious cleansing. In Muslim countries, persecution is systematic and planned. In essence, this is a kind of different ethnic cleansing, a genocide. The European Union must be more determined to protect the Christian population and take steps to ensure a safe return to their homes. On the other hand, we observe that Saudi Arabia demands that mosques be opened in Europe, when it itself does not allow Christian churches to operate in its territory, especially in Mecca. So we have to be more determined to really prevent this holocaust of Christian populations in the Middle East.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Madam President, if I just wanted to name the terrorist attacks and read the names of the innocents who were murdered by Islamist militants just because they were baptized and went to church, I would not have enough time.The countries where these killings are taking place have received billions of euros in development and humanitarian aid over the last ten years.Only the recent attack on the Copts in Egypt proves that the situation of Christians has remained equally desperate since the assassination of Archbishop Rahh of Mosul in 2008.Our support for development has not changed, our help for Christians has not helped.They continue to be murdered, intimidated, abducted and denied their fundamental rights on a daily basis.With all due respect to Mrs Mogherini, I believe that the EU's external action is failing here.And on behalf of the citizens I represent here, I am calling for redress.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I normally speak in English in this Chamber but will you allow me, to conclude this important debate we had this evening, not the only time we have spoken about it, to speak in my language which is also one of the great languages ​​of the Christian community in the world. I believe that Latin is not included in the translations, so I stick to Italian. Having been born and raised in Rome, a few hundred meters from the Vatican, I believe that you can understand very well the importance that this debate has for me this evening and I believe that you can have full confidence in the determination, commitment and energy that I personally put into the work we talked about tonight. I would like to refer to just three points at the end of this debate. First, the European Union has and maintains human rights, all human rights, at the heart of its foreign policy. It is not the same for all international actors, at this moment in particular, but for us it is a beacon of our action in the world. Second, for us, freedom of religion and worship is a fundamental right that must be guaranteed, protected and promoted for all religions and in all areas of the world. This is true for Christians in the Middle East, this is also true for Christians elsewhere in the world, some rightly remembered the persecutions and attacks on Christian communities in other areas of the world, equally worrying, linked to different types of dynamics, but I would like also remember, as some colleagues did this evening, the need to protect all communities and all religions in our Europe as well. In this sense I would like to support those who recalled the need to prevent and fight Islamophobia, especially in Europe, quoting Pope Francis, who reminded us that Europe has the duty to rediscover its ability to integrate and always recalling, alongside the Christian roots of Europe, the fact that we have other roots and that one can always live alongside the other, in respect, in tolerance and in mutual protection. Third point: the situation of Christians in the Middle East is not just a question of human rights, it is not even just a question of tolerance, it is above all a question of preserving diversity, the diversity of a region, the diversity of a culture, the diversity of a story. From this point of view, I agree with what some colleagues said during the debate, it is a question of politics and it is a question of security, because the disappearance of Christian communities from the Middle East would involve a very change in the nature of Middle Eastern societies, with a it is very worrying both from a political and a security point of view. This is why the European Union works every day with the tools I reminded you at the beginning of our debate to protect the rights of Christians in the Middle East, as well as to protect the rights of all to profess their religion in every part of the world. . In conclusion, I would like to thank this Parliament again for the debate and also many Member States who are promoting initiatives in this sense. Some Spanish colleagues remembered the conference that will be held next week in Madrid, which is important in this sense, we spoke about it yesterday with the Spanish minister. I believe that it is important in this to be united, united around the fundamental principles that, I believe, we have all shared and to continue to act with great determination and with great rationality.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
