text: in writing. - Eastern Christians are not only the guarantors of the heritage of the early Christians, they are also the future of the Middle East. It is their presence that allows a peaceful coexistence between Sunnis and Shiites. This presence is undermined by Islamist militias, of which the self-proclaimed Islamic State and the ex-Front al-Nusra are part, but not only. EU member states, by arming some of these groups, have contributed to the gradual disappearance of Eastern Christians from their homelands. And the European Union, by giving legitimacy and credibility to the Syrian Islamist opposition in the unreasonable hope of obtaining the departure of Bashar al-Assad, also bears the heavy responsibility. I appeal to your consistency: the European Union cannot, without backing down, praise the development of multiculturalism and diversity for itself in the morning and promote their disappearance where they have already existed for many centuries in the afternoon. That’s why I welcome the change, albeit late, in Mrs Mogherini’s position on the political future deemed acceptable for Syria. By breaking away from the die-hard demand for the departure of Bashar al-Assad, she concedes that supporting an Islamist opposition was a mistake. It remains to condemn this one.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - Syria today is no longer a symbol of the peaceful coexistence of different religions, although it has been for centuries. I recently had the good fortune to hear the story of Father Jacques Mourad, who served as a priority for 15 years at a monastery founded in the 5th century in Al-Qaryatayn, Syria. This place has been a school example of the peaceful coexistence of the Christian and Muslim communities for centuries. Every year together they remembered St. Elijah, the patron saint of the monastery, who died a martyr's death rather than refusing his faith. All this is a thing of the past. After 15 years of church and community building work, Father Jacques Mourad was abducted by ISIS warriors, the monastery was looted, and the sacred tomb was looted. The father was in captivity in ISIS for four months, serving as a cell for a small restroom. He was abused on a daily basis by the means of the most varied psychic terror, but he did not give up his faith or smile. In the most difficult hours, he had a vision that said, “You are coming to the light!”. This light shines before him even now, after his release, as he personally carries the fame of the Syrian Christian communities in danger of life on a daily basis around the world. I considered this story important because it shows well that the threat to Christians in the Middle East is not an old legend, not part of a long history, but takes place today, before our eyes. Four out of every five victims persecuted for their faith in the world are Christians. We must use all the means at our disposal to protect Christian communities in the Middle East!

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - "Will Christianity disappear in the Middle East?", Is a question that is increasingly being asked. Christians used to make up 20% of the Middle East population, while that number has dropped to just 4% today. The situation is by far the worst in Iraq and Syria, but the situation for Christians is not much better in other Middle Eastern countries either. Almost 80% of all Middle Eastern Christians live in Egypt today, and Egyptian Christians had a bloody Easter this year. While Islamic militarism is the main and biggest cause of persecution of Christians in most predominantly Muslim countries, the strengthening of Arab nationalism plays a role here, which intensifies discrimination against Christians, and the introduction of blasphemy laws further complicates religious freedoms. While we are talking about the sad numbers, one cannot help but get the impression that the position of Christians in the Middle East is used only as a mere statistic in various political debates, with more discussion of guilt than concrete solutions to help Middle Eastern Christians.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. - It is quite clear that Christian communities today are being severely persecuted in many parts of the world. The Middle East is one such point in the world where Christian churches have been on fire in recent years and violence against the largest minority in the region is on the rise. All this is happening on paper under the rule of secular states, which are allies of the European Union in the fight against the Islamic State. More and more people in the region think that these states are not working to prevent violence against Christians who have lived there for millennia. The situation is very serious, experts say that after two thousand years of continuous presence, Christianity may even disappear completely from the region where it developed. I believe that a Judeo-Christian Europe has a responsibility in this matter and cannot be indifferent when faced with these phenomena. We are no longer talking here about the free practice of religion, but about the religiously based persecution and grave violence of entire communities.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Dadaab refugee camp (2017/2687(RSP)).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, dear colleagues, honourable Members of the European Parliament, thank you for taking this timely initiative to discuss the Dadaab refugee camp situation. You know the facts. In May 2016 the Kenyan Government announced its decision to close down the camp in the near future, citing security concerns and the need to end the protracted refugee situation. On 13 November the Government announced that the closure would be delayed by six months on humanitarian grounds. According to the announcement, priority was to be given to relocating non-Somali refugees to other camps – and this process has started – and to reintegrating Kenyans living in the camp.  To date over 23 000 refugees have been returned from Dadaab to Somalia. This year, however, on 9 February, the Kenyan High Court declared the Government’s decision to close the camp null and void and described the repatriation of refugees as unconstitutional and discriminatory. Yet the Kenyan Government has not officially changed its proposed closure date, 31 May 2017. That is 16 days away. The Government has recognised that the voluntary repatriation process must be implemented in accordance with the tripartite agreement between Kenya, Somalia and the UNCHR. When we consider the situation in Dadaab, we must also bear in mind the existing context in the whole of Africa, especially in Somalia. Despite some positive political developments during the past year, a renewed drought is bringing the country to its knees. Famine is looming. 6.7 million people, half of the total population, are in need of urgent humanitarian assistance. 683 000 people have been internally displaced because of the drought. As a result, humanitarian partners are now preparing for a possible influx of Somali refugees to neighbouring countries. We must also be aware that the EU adheres to the principle that returns must be voluntary, dignified and sustainable. Given the current context, that is a real challenge, a very huge challenge, and there may be further instability ahead for a country and a region already on the brink.  We must collectively commend the host communities of Dadaab, the people of Kenya and their Government for offering sanctuary to people fleeing violence, conflict and hunger. That is the message which I personally conveyed to the Kenyan Government and authorities when I visited Dadaab last year. The Government of Kenya is a driver of regional initiatives and has shown willingness to find a collective solution to this issue, in line with international standards and principles. That point was made in the Mogadishu Declaration of 22 February 2017, jointly endorsed by the region’s presidents, and also at the IGAD Summit, held in Nairobi on 25 March this year, on sustainable solutions for Somalian refugees.  The EU has already welcomed the Nairobi declaration. I would like to reiterate the importance of rapid implementation of the commitments underlying it. Investment in development has to be increased and better coordinated, but that is not enough. Policies need to be changed, especially for job access and for living outside the camps, as well as creating  conditions in Somalia allowing people to go home. I am glad to know that the spirit of the Nairobi declaration is reflected in the resolution of this Parliament.  Dear colleagues, another positive milestone was the London Somalia Conference on 11 May 2017, just two weeks ago. The agreement on a security pact and the new Partnership for Somalia was an important step forward. The European Union has announced an additional EUR 200 million for the period up to 2020. The EU trust fund is also providing EUR 50 million in Somalia to support the voluntary return of Somalian refugees. Of course, as the European Union we remain engaged in providing humanitarian assistance in the Dadaab camp and Somalia, in parallel with development support to foster conditions conducive to return including security and access to basic services in Somalia. The Commission itself has supported humanitarian assistance to refugees in Kenya with nearly EUR 130 million since 1996 and EUR 12.7 million this year alone. At the same time the EU has intensified programmes aimed at strengthening state building and stabilising Somalia. In addition, in response to the security threats coming from terrorists in Somalia, we are supporting various projects to counter violent extremists with an overall budget of EUR 18 million.  As I said, the EU acknowledges the generosity that Kenya and other countries in the region have shown to Somalian refugees. We hope that the Kenyan Government will continue to provide protection and asylum to refugees until they can voluntarily return home. We all need to collectively support the country doing this and to do so in a way that benefits both the refugees and the host communities in Dadaab. We also need to make every effort to help consolidate peace in Somalia. That is the only way to resolve the protracted refugee crisis in the region. I am grateful, as the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid, that  Parliament is continuing to support the common efforts to bring about a sustainable and lasting solution to the regional refugee crisis. I welcome the resolution tabled, which seeks to further support these measures. Thank you so much for your attention to this statement. I am looking forward to our in-depth discussions that will help us to see together how to evaluate the situation in the Dadaab camp.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the population of Dadaab camp is now approaching 266,000 people: 95% are from Somalia and 60% are minors. This population has been on the rise for three decades now. This situation is untenable neither for the Government of Kenya, nor for the neighboring countries and even less for all the people who live there. The closure of the camp is a sovereign decision. Yes, I am sure it is motivated by a concern to protect the population from terrorist threats from Al-Chabab. However, we cannot leave the Somali refugees to their fate, this will in no way resolve the current situation and will only further destabilize the region and strengthen the terrorist groups that advocate radicalization. I would like to salute the action of the Union, which has allocated 286 million euros for the period 2014-2020 through the European Development Fund and the European Trust Fund for Africa. Today, as a Union, we must assume our role of mediator and, above all, we must motivate an urgent regional response with three priorities: first of all, the return and reintegration of refugees in the spirit of the tripartite agreement signed between the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Kenya and Somalia. Then, the implementation of measures to stabilize the situation in Somalia, always with an approach that, by going beyond the emergency response, aims at the sustainable economic and human development of the populations. Finally, the strengthening of political dialogue between all countries in the region, subregional organizations and the African Union. Security, the fight against terrorism and radicalization are challenges that we must meet together, as partners. We must provide concrete and rapid responses that are equal to the dangers that threaten the region: famine, drought and war.It is crucial that our action aims to find solutions to the main destabilizing causes and thus to ensure the economic, political and human resilience of populations and States.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I have to congratulate you on his permanent commitment to causes as desperate as Dadaab. The truth is that the European Union is contributing - economically, of course - to the minimum support of the Somali refugees, although it is clear that nothing is enough and the call of the Secretary General of the United Nations demonstrates this. Money, we are able to donate. We can do diplomatic intervention; promote, as my colleague said, a regional solution; give a role to the African Union. The truth is that the European Union is not very well placed to give lessons to Kenya, which is a country that has shown enormous generosity with refugees, despite the difficulties that the country itself has. And the truth is also that the Horn of Africa is in a very dangerous situation, derived not only from the risks of terrorism, but also from famine and drought. How can we do to be more effective in helping those human beings need? Because even if the field closes, people are not going to dissolve: people multiply. How can we be more effective? It is the element that we have to find. Probably a greater involvement in the fundamental solutions towards Somalia, and a more concrete support to the Kenyan authorities so that they are able to carry out this relocation that, for the moment, looks directly like hell. For the refugees, voluntary return to Somalia ... It seems almost a joke to speak of voluntary return to a place where nothing but despair awaits them. In any case, I find it very positive that the European Parliament is taking a position on this issue and that Dadaab is in our debates, and I encourage you to continue to insist on the line that you are developing, Commissioner Stylianides.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, the Dadaab camp, created in 1991 at the start of the civil war in Somalia, is the largest refugee camp in the world. It now hosts more than half of the 486,000 refugees in Kenya. They are overwhelmingly Somalis and, to a lesser extent, South Sudanese. The country pays for its presence in Somalia in the fight against the Shabab and suffers retaliation, as in September 2013, with the 172 dead at the Westgate shopping center in Nairobi and, more recently, the 148 dead at Garissa University in 2015 Fear and rejection are mounting among the Kenyan people. As elsewhere, refugees seem to be increasingly becoming an electoral issue. There is recurring blackmail when the camps are closed and forced returns are increasing despite the dangerous and deteriorating situation in Somalia and although 86% of Somalis refuse to do so. We talk about the fight against the root causes of migration, but this starts with solidarity, when the proposed responses are increasingly military and security. Worse, UNHCR has only raised 15% of the $ 215 million it needs to care for refugees in Kenya, as drought continues to worsen the health situation. We are heading towards an unprecedented humanitarian catastrophe. It's urgent. The international community takes a heavy responsibility and European policies are not up to the drama that is playing out here. Humanitarian aid is totally insufficient.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, many of us remember when the first ships carrying Somalis started to come in the early 1990s. It is unimaginable that some people who then found refuge and life in Europe have colleagues and family members who ended up in Dadaab and in a smaller camp called Kakuma, which I visited some years ago. Some of these people have been living there for 25 years without any perspective on life outside the camp. Happily, of course, the camp has formed some good relations with the local communities and I think this is something that has to be supported, but the surrounding communities also need investment in development so that they can prosper and live beside the camp.  I think that it is very important to note the promising cooperation of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development of the region (IGAD). They recently had a summit, which was also mentioned in our resolution, and have admirably agreed to facilitate a voluntary return back home. We should in no way support any kind of forced returns to a situation which climate change is worsening, and where famine is threatening people’s lives – the Commissioner mentioned internally displaced people – and so we also need, as Europeans, to take our responsibility for resettlement of some of the people living in the camp.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Kenya has accepted refugees at Dadaab since 1992. The tripartite agreement between Kenya, Somalia and the UNHCR has led to some repatriation, thus we have been content to ignore this issue. In that time Kenya has suffered many terrorist-related attacks, not least at the Westgate Shopping Centre attributed to Al-Shabab recruitment in Dadaab. These camps should provide temporary safe havens and not dump victims of war and droughts. Dadaab represents all that is wrong with the way that we deal with displaced persons. Ludicrously, in a separate debate this week we will vote to condemn one of the only stabilising states in this region. Ethiopia has provided troops, material and money to overcome the anarchy in Somalia, but it is always inconvenient in this place to look at the bigger picture. Thus we find ourselves bemoaning the plights of displaced people, the inadequacies of African governments, and at the same time, undermine yet another country in this troubled region.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Almost thirty years of the humanitarian crisis in Somalia also include more than two million displaced Somalis, most of whom have found refuge in the neighboring countries of the Horn of Africa, including Kenya, specifically in Dadaab. The tripartite agreement between UNHCR, Somalia and Kenya offers some possibility of return due to the improvement of the political, stability and security situation in Somalia, which is undoubtedly far from perfect, but which forces people to return to their country of origin. The Kenyan authorities argue that the camp is closed due to the prevailing situation there and that terrorist organizations are recruiting new members among the people who live in the camp. This is an argument for what is expected to happen in May. Although the Kenyan court decision and the closure order were unconstitutional and discriminatory, the situation in Dadaab very aptly illustrates the complexity of the link between the refugee problem and the stability-building border management challenges. I believe that the Nairobi Global and Regional Action Plan adopted in March this year is an important declaration that refugees who choose to remain in the host country should have access to employment and services, as well as mobility. It should be emphasized that returns to Somalia, if any, must be carried out in accordance with international standards, that is, voluntarily, safely and with respect for human rights. The Union should allocate resources from the Trust Fund for Africa to this end, as well as support with it, bottom-up projects that will improve the quality and accessibility of essential services.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, two months ago, thanks to the support of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, I had the opportunity to visit the Dadaab refugee camp, created in the 1990s and which then counted 90,000 places. Today, it hosts more than 260,000 refugees. East Africa is now experiencing a most alarming humanitarian crisis due to drought, the epicenter of which is, once again, Somalia. Somalis are the most represented in the camp, constituting more than 90% of its population. In 2011, the drought had already caused the death of 260,000 people. We must act urgently. The IGAD summit recognized the role and generosity of neighboring countries in providing international protection for refugees, despite their own socio-economic, environmental and national security challenges. However, I now call for a global sharing of the responsibility that this region bears. Today's resolution goes in that direction. She asks Europe to accept its share of relocations, as are Canada and Australia. She supports voluntary returns, but recognizes that such returns are difficult in the current context of drought. She knows that Dadaab will not be able to close its doors and is therefore asking for increased aid. She also calls for more development assistance for the region and local communities, who now bear the burden of this migration, but she also calls for the Union's trust fund for Africa to be properly funded and effective. In general, the resolution calls for greater burden-sharing but also for sustainable solutions in terms of social, economic and environmental development.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the Dadaab camp in Kenya, where almost 250,000 Somalis are trying to survive; the 50,000 refugees from the Mali war who are in Mauritania; the 250,000 Sudanese refugees in the Chadian camps; or the Sahrawi people, who have spent forty years in the camps of Algeria ... are just some examples of the hundreds of camps in Africa. But the European Union has perverted cooperation funds and conditions them on the governments of the recipient countries to bow to the demands of "Fortress Europe". Cooperation funds are now used, for example, to build detention centers in Niger or to finance armies of certain African countries to implement the migration policies set by Brussels, policies for those fleeing war, poverty or exploitation, they remain in those fields without dignified conditions or they remain in their countries suffering barbarism. Policies so that no one reaches Europe. Africa hosts four and a half million people with refugee status. Here, on the other hand, they have not wanted to meet the absolutely insufficient objective of relocating 160,000 people to the various countries of the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as many have recalled, Dadaab was established as early as 1991 as a temporary solution for those seeking refuge from persecution, violence and instability in the East African region, including the civil war in Somalia. It is the largest refugee camp in the world, according to the UN, with 245,000 people, 60 per cent of whom are under 18, without education or work. Unfortunately, the issue of Somali refugees in Dadaab has become the subject of an election campaign for President Kenyatta, shouting the slogan to fight terrorism. We have obviously accepted and accepted the judgment of the Nairobi Supreme Court which states that this decision, to close the Dadaab camp, is void, but unfortunately the government in turn has appealed and cannot, in our opinion, simply say hundreds of thousands of people to return to the war, hunger and extreme poverty from which they fled. We recall that the UN Refugee Convention prohibits repatriation to areas where their life and freedom are threatened and this is certainly the case in Somalia, which is beset by drought, famine, cholera and violence. As good practices to copy there is the one of Uganda with its "self-reliance" strategy, in which refugees can work freely and move around. These are the good practices to copy, certainly not the indiscriminate closure carried out by the current government.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are often concerned, still in this morning's debate on relocation, about how to deal with and welcome refugees and asylum seekers fleeing their conflict-torn lands and resulting poverty in Europe. In reality, we are only concerned, but we do almost nothing to have a common European immigration policy. Alongside this, at the same time, we find it difficult to see that the humanitarian refugee crisis is not only a phenomenon located at the gates of Europe and in the Mediterranean area, but is a global situation. There are millions of refugees and displaced persons outside the European context that we cannot ignore. The refugee camp of Dadaab is a clear example of what we are talking about and it is also for us, Commissioner, a test case on our ability to intervene and accompany the agreement between Kenya, Somalia and UNHCR. What should guide us in our European action? Two guidelines that I consider fundamental: the first concerns the safeguarding of the principle of international humanitarian law. The second is that we need a different approach to cooperation policy capable of intervening on the conditions of conflict and poverty. Not doing this means paying for our absence with interest.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Dadaab refugee camp, the largest in the world, turns 26 this year. A camp that was supposed to provide temporary shelter mainly to Somali refugees and which, instead, has turned into a permanent ghetto of 260,000 people. At least two generations were born and raised in what is a symbol of the social misery of refugees in Africa, of the failure of the development and pacification policies of that area and of the inability, also, to manage the migratory phenomenon globally. Ethiopians, Eritreans, Sudanese, South Sudanese, Somalis, they are the inhabitants without rights of this metropolis, forced to live a "non-life", because they are deprived of a future and a hope. On their skin, the authorities and the international community make decisions that the Supreme Court itself has defined as an act of mass persecution, illegal and therefore unconstitutional. It is true, the Dadaab camp is a hub of misery, illegality and abuse, especially against women, children and vulnerable groups. However, it is difficult to predict the fate of these refugees should they suddenly find themselves homeless. It is a collective responsibility to put an end to the political instability of the region, finally create the conditions for a sustainable development policy and rethink our migration policies, knowing that by grasping the challenges but also the opportunities, without peace and stability and in the absence of an holistic to the migratory phenomenon, there will be no future for any refugee either within a camp or in their countries of origin.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First and foremost I would like to say thank you to Kenya that - although the camp is of course not ideal, that is clear - it really showed itself with great hospitality. I was there myself six months ago. I visited Dadaab, I had talks with the local officials, the local population, the mayor and also with residents in the camp. On the one hand it was shameful for me to see the situation in the camp, which of course seems very hopeless, but on the other hand it was also shameful to see that people have nothing and still share. The people were really well received in this large camp. I would like to put three thoughts in this room: The help we give must be used more effectively in the future. No longer for short-term camps, but really for long-term integration, for aid, for combating the causes of displacement, for climate protection and so on and so forth. We urgently need help on site now, of course, but financial resources that will be used more effectively in the long term. We urgently need to create perspectives - perspectives for these people. Go there once, take a look! I think the hopelessness and the lack of prospects is worse than the hunger. And we have to learn for Europe. For Europe I learned in Dadaab that temporary solutions from camps or from ghettos are not solutions. In Dadaab it is now being said that we have to somehow integrate people. Yes, you waited 25 years and didn't integrate. Now the problem is pent up like a wave of integration that we can no longer master. That means: we have to help as best we can and we have to learn.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have visited Kenya twice in the past few months, meeting EU officials and the British Embassy, and I know the resolution is right to emphasise the impact of climate change in the East Africa region and the human displacement and famine it has caused, in combination with the enduring conflict and human rights abuses. These large-scale international processes require regional and international responses, and the EU can and must play a role. Kenyan authorities have done much to host these refugees over 25 years, and the international community, including the EU, must step up its efforts. 60% of the camp’s residents are women and children, and we must do more to ensure access to education while they are in the camps and for those who voluntarily return to Somalia or seek asylum. More must be done to provide mental health support, and the needs of women and girls must be taken into account. President Trump’s cuts in US funding to the region will not help, and neither will Brexit, as the UK’s special relationship with Kenya has allowed the country to punch above its weight at EU level, especially helping in the fight against Al-Shabab on the border. Security and a compassionate response must go hand in hand.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, there are currently more than 500,000 refugees in Kenya. Of these, 245,000 refugees are literally stacked in the five zones of the Dadaab refugee camp. They come mainly from Somalia. Dadaab is a camp, a refugee camp, that started in 1991 and the efforts of the jihadist organization al-Sabad to create problems in the area and to effectively dismantle the camp are well known. Today, the situation in Dadaab is desperate. Thousands of appeals are being stacked and measures must be taken to support their existence there, to support this camp, to help Kenya, which is really having problems at this stage as well, as we have a severe drought in the region. At the same time, those who wish to become refugees must be facilitated to return to Somalia. In Somalia, which really needs to be stabilized, at least 25,000 people are now at risk of dying of cholera.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, there is no doubt that we have had a very useful exchange, and I thank all the honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate, I can conclude that we all share a common interest in using EU diplomatic power and EU instruments to their full potential in support of the Somali refugee crisis. We will continue to make the best use of all the instruments available to us in humanitarian relief, stabilisation and development assistance, as well as political dialogue with specific support to human rights and democracy. Personally, as Commissioner for humanitarian aid and crisis management, I must highlight once again the importance of adhering to international law and norms with regard to returns. They must be voluntary, dignified and sustainable. For me it is quite important to be very focused on these three preconditions – voluntary, dignified and sustainable. The vast majority of the crises in Africa are man-made and entirely avoidable. The extreme climate conditions exacerbate the effects of chronic conflict and instability. Uganda and some other countries in the region which have shown openness towards hundreds of thousands of refugees from South Sudan and the DRC, among others, are to be commended. I am intending to attend, as Commissioner, the solidarity conference to be convened in Uganda next month under the auspices of the Secretary—General, Antonio Guterres. I am going there to express the EU’s support and solidarity but, most importantly, to discuss and push for efforts to address the root causes of all those crises – not only the symptoms, because for me it is quite important to focus on the root causes. Otherwise it is quite difficult to find solutions because, if we deal only with the symptoms, unfortunately the situation there continues as business as usual. This is totally unacceptable, especially for vulnerable people. Thank you very much for your attention and for this very good debate, focusing on the Dadaab refugee camp.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have received five motions for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123 (1).2 of the Regulations.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 18 May 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- The Dadaab refugee camp was set up in 1991 as a temporary camp for Somali refugees.Today, there are 260,000 people in the camp, 95% of whom are Somalis.Given the current situation in Somalia, where there are both security problems and deteriorating living conditions due to drought and famine, people should not be sent back from the Dadaab refugee camp.This is especially true in a situation where there are people in the camp who have never been to Somalia but have already been born in that camp.Return to Somalia must be strictly voluntary and in line with international standards.The EU must and can help to resolve this situation by seeking to facilitate the resettlement of refugees and by contributing to a political solution in the region.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on an oral question to the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy by Soraya Post, Tanja Fajon, Elena Valenciano, Knut Fleckenstein, Pier Antonio Panzeri, on behalf of the S&D Group, UlrikaLunacek, Rebecca Harms, Heidi Hautala, on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group, Dennis de Jonga, Malin Björk, Eleonora Forenza, Marisa Matias, Helmut Scholz, Stefan Eck, Cornelia Ernst, Merja Kyllönen, Rina Ronja Kari, Marina Albiolie, Marina Albiolie, On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group, Marietje Schaake, on behalf of the ALDE Group, and Ian Duncan, on behalf of the ECR Group on the implementation of the Council's LGBTI Guidelines, in particular with regard to the persecution of (considered) gay men in Chechnya (Russia) (O-000039/2017 - B8-0219 / 2017) (2017/2688 (RSP)).

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Mr President, since February we have been receiving incredible and terrible reports from the Russian province Chechnya. The reports of the horrible acts towards gay men make devastating reading. Government officials claim there are no homosexuals in Chechnya. But at the same time they round up gay men, real or perceived, and torture them into giving up the names of gay friends or lovers. Families are forced to pay large amounts to get them free – money that is said to ‘trickle up’ in the police and government hierarchy. The Government’s anti-gay campaign cuts into the heart of families. I have received reports about honour killings: families have murdered their own children in shame of their being gay. This is what happens when politicians act as if human rights were only for a few – when they dehumanise whole groups of people. Right now, the European Union is the global stronghold protecting the idea of equality of human rights for all. This demands of us the special duty to protect LGBTI persons, and creates a need for humanitarian protection visas. Our question to the European External Action Service is about how they can ensure implementation of our LGBTI guidelines. Last Thursday, five gay activists were detained in Moscow when they wanted to deliver a petition demanding an investigation into the ongoing crimes in Chechnya. More than two million people have signed it, more people than live in Chechnya. Today we must stand with those two million. We must stand with the LGBTI communities of the world and, right now and most pressingly, with the LGBTI people in Chechnya and Russia. (Applause)

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: author. – Mr President, tomorrow is the International Day Against Homophobia, and that is why I am wearing this rainbow here – to remind everyone who is listening, who is speaking here and who is listening to us – that this is a day where everybody should stand up, like we are doing in this Parliament, against homophobia, transphobia, against all kinds of violence against LGBTI people wherever it occurs, in Europe and on other continents. And as Soraya Post has already explained, this is a specific debate on what has been reported happening in Chechnya, in the Russian Federation, in the last couple of weeks. Arbitrary detentions, torture of hundreds of men, either really gay or perceived to be gay, and three of them at least have also been killed. They have been demanded to disclose the identity of other LGBTI people. This is a life of fear that nobody on this planet should be allowed to live, and nobody who protects the perpetrators should not be brought to justice. It is clear that we demand in this resolution – and I have to say the resolution we prepared is one of six groups in this Parliament, I really appreciate that there is broad support – we demand from the Russian Federation and the Chechnya regime to protect LGBTI people and also to speak out and say this is not against any religious traditions; this is something – being lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans or intersex – that has existed all over the planet in all times and all epochs, in all religions, in all cultures everywhere, and exists and should not be worked against. So now we also ask the External Action Service to see that the guidelines that we have are really implemented all over this planet in order to make sure that LGBTI human rights defenders are helped by the European diplomats, and lots is done in that; we already have many good reports by that. I also appreciate that the EAS is having the building illuminated on tomorrow’s International Day Against Homophobia in the rainbow flags, and this is important to show visibility and to struggle for equal rights for everybody. (Applause)

name: Malin Björk
text: Author. - Mr President! Thanks so much. There were probably many of us who found it difficult to take in the reports of threats and violence, torture and even murder, of gay men in Chechnya. Such an extreme persecution, it is simply difficult to take in. All of us who are LGBTQ people have, of course, experienced homophobia, but such an extreme form of violence that we have seen in these reports, it is fortunately unusual. But homophobia is killing, and it is killing here in Europe as well. It killed everyone in that gay club in Orlando. And we know that homotransphobia oppresses young people and adults in our society. The violence and persecution of gays in Chechnya is the ultimate consequence of what all this homophobia can result in - extreme and deadly violence. When faced with it, we must all act. That is why we demand that the European Union act, that the Member States act, that it act together with the Council of Europe, that it act together with independent experts who should have access to and must investigate exactly what has happened, and those responsible should be brought to justice. Nothing else works. What hurts so much is also that it is precisely the family and the police, where one should be safe - in one's family and in the relationship with the police - who have been exposed and involved in persecuting and harming, and even murdering, gay men . Homophobia - it's so musty, it's so patriarchal, it's such a musty attitude to the nation, to the people, to gender, to love, to women, to men and to gender identities. We have to get rid of it. Homophobia is deeply rooted, not only in Chechnya, but also in our country. We have everything to do, we have everything to gain to build more open societies - more dignified societies that stand up for everyone's human rights. I expect nothing more than that.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: author. – Mr President, colleagues, Mr Commissioner, the brutal anti-gay campaign in the authoritarian Chechnya of Kadyrov is yet another example of how little, if anything, human rights mean in this part of Russia today. The ongoing terror against and prosecution of opposition, human rights activists and journalists has now been extended into targeting the LGBTI minority. Unfortunately, the crimes in Chechnya are not an isolated campaign. It is only a common denominator representing the state of human rights in Russia as a whole. Let us recall that in March this year Russia has adopted a backwards legislation decriminalising domestic violence, and now we are witnessing this. We, the European Union, must make sure that our policy towards Russia reflects seriously the crimes against the LGBTI minority in Chechnya. It should be clear from the very start that it is unacceptable. Homophobia belongs to the shameful past. (Applause)

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. - Tomorrow, 17 May, the rainbow flag will fly in many places in my country, Flanders. Also for example on the facade of my town hall and even that of the Flemish Parliament. I am proud of that. Fortunately, the LGBTI community is liberated with us. But we too remain vigilant against homophobia. There is little to celebrate on the international day against homophobia. Intolerance is growing worldwide, we see prosecutions and even the death penalty for those who want to be “different” and yet be themselves. What has happened in Chechnya in recent days has shocked us. It is still winter in the Caucasus. Maybe literally but certainly figuratively. The persecution of at least a hundred Chechens for being gay, the torture, murder and solitary confinement in torture camps are repugnant and unacceptable and can only be condemned in the harshest terms. President Kadirov's reactions that there are no gays in his country demonstrate the coldness of society and the unwillingness of the regime. No one can feel protected when the government opens a witch hunt. And Kremlin boss Putin? Nothing new under the sun. He denies. He plainly supports the Chechen government and is himself repressive against LGBT sympathizers in Moscow and Saint Petersburg. The Kremlin thus once again plays an extremely dubious role. A recent report from the Council of Europe also points to Russia's reluctance to make any effort to improve the human rights situation in Chechnya. The gruesome facts require an investigation. The perpetrators must be prosecuted and the victims compensated. But no one believes Russia will conduct a serious investigation. An independent international investigation is imperative. And so the question to the Commission is what it will do to implement our own LGBTI guidelines. It will take more than expressing concern. All victims of the persecution, all protesters must be released immediately and the relevant authorities must respect their international obligations.A ruthless regime only understands plain language.I expect that from the supervisory director soon.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, no one should be discriminated against or attacked for who they love. This principle has become an integral part of our concept of equality, human rights and fundamental freedoms. This is obviously a European value and we believe it should be a universal value. Just to remind you, in 2013 the European Union adopted guidelines to promote and protect the enjoyment of full human rights by lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) persons. The EU’s diplomatic efforts in this area revolve around four priorities: first, eliminating discriminatory laws and policies and ensuring decriminalisation, including the death penalty; second, promoting equality and non—discrimination at work, in healthcare and education; third, combating state or individual violence against LGBTI persons; and fourth, supporting and protecting human rights defenders. Depending on the situation, the European Union acts on the issue through quiet diplomacy, public statements and by raising LGBTI rights in the political and human rights dialogues with third countries. The European Union also provides support to civil society via the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. Today, as the authors have already said, we are here to discuss some very serious allegations of crimes against gay men in Chechnya. The persecution of gay men, leading to kidnappings, torture and killings is the latest amongst some very worrying developments in Chechnya. We have seen the Chechen authorities implicitly justifying the violence and the Russian federal authorities downplaying it, dismissing the reports as exaggerations and fake news. Unfortunately, so far the Russian authorities have taken no effective action to stop the violence and protect the victims. The European Union, with its Member States, other like-minded countries and many international human rights organisations, has condemned the brutal campaign against LGBTI individuals and called for a full investigation into these events. Just yesterday the EU Foreign Ministers discussed the situation in the Foreign Affairs Council to evaluate the most effective way to help the victims of the alleged abuse. High Representative Federica Mogherini also raised our serious concerns on this issue directly with Minister Lavrov when she saw him in Moscow on 24 April. She stressed the need to put an immediate stop to the crackdown against gay men in Chechnya and to investigate these horrific reports. Unfortunately, Minister Lavrov’s response – later also repeated in the press conference – was that the Russian authorities so far had no proof that the alleged persecutions had actually happened. While in Moscow, the High Representative also had the opportunity to discuss the issue with civil society representatives and journalists. It is indeed alarming that the journalists who uncovered the violence have in turn become the target of direct threats from the leadership in Chechnya and have been forced to flee Chechnya. This is, unfortunately, the situation on the ground. We have asked EU ambassadors in Moscow to do their utmost to help the men who have been a target, particularly those who currently still fear for their own safety and security. Some Member States are willing to help. Whatever they do will be done quietly and without fanfare in order to protect the victims. In any case, we will continue to call on the international authorities for an effective and thorough investigation into the reports of abductions and killing of gay men in Chechnya. This is indispensable so that anyone found guilty of complicity in such crimes is brought to justice. This is our strong conviction.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I really want to join my colleagues in sharing the outrage for the real emergency that we are witnessing with – you said it, Ulrike – hundreds of men that have been arrested and detained in Chechnya just because they are perceived to be gay, and tortured to disclose their alleged gay friends. The systematic witch-hunt of human beings just because of their sexual orientation goes beyond discrimination: it is persecution, it is terrifying and unacceptable, and we cannot be silent and turn our eyes.  In the EU we should stand united and act together, and I welcome that our President has immediately taken action and a firm stand against those crimes, and I support further action by the European Commission. All Member States should call for the immediate release of those that are still detained illegally and to assist the victims. The Russian Federation should openly denounce those crimes and thoroughly investigate them in respect of international law.  There must be zero-tolerance against impunity, and all perpetrators should be brought to justice. The EU should condemn any intimidation towards human rights defenders who reported the violence against LGBTI in Russia. As a member of the United Nations and the Council of Europe, Russia should respect that all human beings are equal and no one has the right to persecute an individual or a group just because they are different or are perceived to be different.  In our times, hate, homophobia, violence, discrimination, can never be justified in the name of religious values. We have to continue – Mr President, I will conclude – to join forces to build a culture of tolerance, and I have co-signed this resolution wholeheartedly.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. president. You wanted to be unconscious so that they would leave you alone, but no. They electrocuted you for twenty or thirty seconds; you faded, they stopped. You recovered and started again. After days with open wounds, people began to smell like rotten meat. This is the terrifying testimony of a young Chechen man who managed to escape from one of the concentration camps for gays that exist in Chechnya. Being homosexual in Chechnya, as in other parts of the world, by the way, means, in the worst case, your death, and in the best, living in fear, clandestinely and persecuted. What can you expect from a Chechen government that says there are no problems with homosexuality in Chechnya, because there are no homosexuals in Chechnya? Formally, Chechnya is part of the Russian Federation, but the Kremlin looks the other way and lets go. Formally, Russia is a party to the European Convention on Human Rights, which prohibits torture and discrimination on any grounds. Formally and morally, the European Union must be active in the defense and protection of LGTBI rights in its relations with third countries. Defending these people, Commissioner, must be on the table in our relations with Russia. We cannot allow ourselves to also look the other way, because these people, these people who suffer persecution, have nothing but our voice, in many cases, to be defended.

name: Fredrick Federley
text: for the ALDE Group. - Mr President! I would like to begin by thanking the Commission for a clear statement that is very firmly in line with European values. I would also like to thank my colleagues here for a very clear mark. That we can bring about such a broad and strong resolution is extremely important when we are now going to vote on it, to show to Russia and to Chechnya that we do not accept this behavior. Just as my colleague Corazza Bildt now said, we must ensure that the people held captive must be released as soon as possible. The people who have been expelled from Chechnya must be given an opportunity to return to their families. We must ensure that the call that has gone through Chechnya to clear Chechnya of homosexuals before Ramadan begins must be lifted. They have been asked to either take the lives of their own sons, or they will do so within the framework of Chechnya. At the same time, we must remember that this is connected with the policy that Putin has pursued towards LGBTQ people for a very, very long time. Now he is letting Chechnya become an experimental workshop against and attacking human rights. We must make sure to mark this as clearly as we can. Thanks!

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! If Kadyrov claims that there are no homosexuals in Chechnya, then that is as true as the claim that the earth is flat, or that Eve came from Adam's rib. But life is different: the earth is round, and there is not just Adam and Eve, but much more - whether gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender or intersexual. This is neither a deficit nor a flaw, but a wonderful gift from human nature that we must defend. That is why we demand first and foremost that hate speech against homosexuals must stop - first of all when it comes from governments. And anyone who, as in Chechnya, arrests, tortures and drives people to death for being homosexual is guilty of the most serious crimes. And who looks on idly, likewise. Our request is that all prisoners who have been detained for sexual orientation must therefore be released. Forced sterilization and sex-assigned operations must be abolished everywhere, including in our Member States. Incidentally, such people must also be granted asylum if they are persecuted in their countries. That is part of protecting human rights here in the EU.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. -  Mister President! The first news I read about the pogrom on the net was: They threw him outside and said he should be killed. That was the sentence that many read. It was first published on VKontakte. I think that we have dealt with this pogrom, that we have been roused by the news from Chechnya, that is very good. At the same time, I'm also very pessimistic. On the one hand, I believe that it is correct that Angela Merkel or Federica Mogherini also publicly addressed this pogrom. It is good that President Putin has come under pressure and has announced an investigation. We can probably avert another pogrom for the moment, but we do not end the systematic oppression, persecution, violence against gays and other sexual minorities in these countries. That is why I would like to say at this point: it is right to pay attention to the situation, but what the Scandinavian countries have done, namely to create easy entry options for gays from Russia and to facilitate asylum procedures, the European Union must push forward very quickly.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, reports emerging from Chechnya are extremely worrying. It is incomprehensible that in a modern civilised state, anyone’s liberty – and indeed their health and life – would be under threat based on their sexuality. It would appear that the Chechnya government has slipped back towards barbarism, and my thoughts are with the families of those who have lost loved ones in this awful persecution. Russia has in recent years been under much criticism and scrutiny for their attitudes towards homosexuality, but the Republic of Chechnya has gone to new extremes. The federal government must show the world that this will not be tolerated and do more to investigate and stamp out any and all of those persecutions in Chechnya.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - On Thursday, we will vote on a joint resolution on gross human rights violations by the regime of Chechen President Ramzan Kadirov against homosexuals in Chechnya. It is a useful resolution condemning the Stalinist methods used by today's regime, including building detention facilities for uncomfortable minorities. However, I ask, ladies and gentlemen, why have we not paid attention in the long term to the situation in Chechnya after the Russian army brutally suppressed the Chechens' quest for independence? On Sunday, the government of the Chechen Republic of Ichkeria in exile prepared a conference in Brussels to mark the 20th anniversary of the signing of the May 1997 peace treaty. The Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Chechen Republic, Ichkeria Aminat Sajeva, called this undeclared war against Chechnya brutal and shameful. This war killed more than a hundred thousand people. Russia has destroyed the Chechen economy and infrastructure. The Russian army, through bombing and artillery, caused the total destruction of Chechen towns and villages. Russia has violated all principles of international law, including the use of chemical weapons. And I ask again, ladies and gentlemen, why do we not reflect all these facts?

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Yuri Guaiana, an Italian human rights defender arrested the day before by the Russian authorities, was released on Thursday when he was delivering a petition against the treatment of homosexuals in Chechnya. What is happening in this Russian region, namely the forced arrest, imprisonment and torture of homosexuals is an unacceptable violation of multiple human rights. Not only are the people involved not guaranteed equal treatment compared to any other citizen, but we are also witnessing an emergency that violates the freedom of these people, subjecting them to violence and torture just for their sexual orientation. In Chechnya, the situation is made even more worrying by the fact that there is a real organizational and repressive apparatus, including infrastructure and personnel, aimed at the identification, capture and torture of people suspected of being homosexuals. The ultimate goal of this apparatus is the conversion of prisoners. I don't know if there is full awareness, but there is no doubt that the reaction of the international community has not been adequate. The actor involved is certainly not an easy interlocutor, but we must absolutely denounce all this to avoid future degeneration. In conclusion, however, I would also like to draw attention to the guidelines proposed by the Council. I believe that the document calls us to an examination of conscience, an action also and above all within the European Union. We are denouncing an extreme case like that of Chechnya, which it is right and proper to denounce, but even within our borders the people of the LGBTI community are subject to discrimination that too often does not find justifications related to culture, tradition and religion . On this too, we must be consistent.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: - Mr President!For the past two months, we have witnessed horrific crimes against gay men in increasingly Islamist Chechnya.Last week, a 17-year-old boy was thrown from a balcony to die after his family discovered he was gay.These honor killings, Mr President, often take place at the direct urging of the authorities, and what we are witnessing in Chechnya is a systematic purge of people based on sexual orientation, which is completely contrary to fundamental humanistic principles.Now, in this Union of the European Union, we must stand up for and be a refuge for these vulnerable people.Together in the EU, we must put pressure on Putin to act against the Chechen regime's terrible calls for honor killings.Because that's what it's about.We cannot continue to turn a blind eye to the horrific crimes that are taking place in our immediate area.We own the issue and we must take responsibility now.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that one of the most serious aspects of this affair are the declarations of the Chechen government about the non-existence of homosexuals, of gay people, on its territory.I believe that this statement alone, beyond the need to investigate exactly what the extent of discrimination is, if not the torture that has been reported, speaks for itself of a culture founded on the denial of recognition of LGBTQI people.I think it is absolutely right for us not only to take the floor, as we will do tomorrow through the approval of a resolution, but also by working within the European Union so that no political, cultural, material and symbolic denial of the rights of women is possible.LGBTQI people.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I want to join the thanks to the Commissioner for a very powerful intervention on how the European Union is using all its possibilities to condemn these atrocities that we have been hearing about during the last two months.  This horrible persecution is, on one hand, linked to the emphasis on what they call traditional values – and believe me, according to traditional values, homosexuality is something that should not exist. This is also linked, indirectly at least, to the decriminalisation of domestic violence in Russia some time ago, because ‘family’ means the ‘traditional family’ and what happens inside the family is something that should not be touched. In this extreme way, we have seen honour killings which are tolerated by the state, even induced by the state, and we have to be very strong.  In Chechnya the situation overall is very bad. Human rights defenders are persecuted against, and the Committee Against Torture saw their offices burnt down by security forces not long ago.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: - In ten days, the Muslim month of Ramadan will begin. For most Muslims around the world, it is a holiday, a time to think about life. For homosexuals in Chechnya, however, it is a month of horror and reflection on death. Because Chechen President Kadyrov actually wants to end the purge by Ramadan. If the gays are not removed by the Chechen government, they will be removed by their relatives. The confessions of gay fugitives from a so-called concentration camp are appalling. I do not want to imagine what these men are really going through, and I do not want to imagine what it will be like if the Chechen authorities introduce this method of rejection for lesbians, the disabled or other members of minorities. However, I demand that the High Representative, as you said, immediately request information and the results of the investigation from the Russian authorities. Russia has not done anything yet. I also expect to make it clear to Kadyrov that gays in Chechnya have been, are and will be. By declaring their absence, however, the president is actually embarrassing the international community and pushing his compatriots into the Middle Ages. The measures are written down, now the results will be important and if they are not, the stories of World War II exterminations can start to grow. The spread of Nazism and other ideologies is not conditioned by state borders.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: - Chairman, Commissioner, colleagues. Like probably all of you, I was deeply shocked when I saw the images from Chechnya. Immediately when I heard the news, the images from World War II came to my mind. Keep men suspected of being homosexual in camps. They try to improve. And then when they are released - if they are released at all - they are in danger of being killed by their own families. This happens a stone's throw from Europe, in 2017, on the eve of the international day against homophobia and on the eve of the Gay Pride in Brussels. After all, the international community will celebrate in Brussels on Saturday, although there is actually no reason to party. Commissioner, I welcome your strong statement. We need to increase the pressure. That's really important. We must punish the guilty. That is also important. Finally, we must ensure the protection of homosexuals. That means thinking about visas and how we can protect them. That is now a priority on our program. Thank you.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I am glad, colleagues, that we have been able to achieve such a degree of cross-party unity across this House on this really crucial issue. But remember, we have got the easy job. We have a massive debt of gratitude to civil society and the NGOs and journalists who brought this to our attention at all – people who are really struggling in their daily lives against shocking persecution. Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, the International Crisis Group, vital NGOs who do vital work need further support; journalists at Novaya Gazeta; and indeed the brave citizens who are struggling on a daily basis. The situation in Chechnya is the subject of this motion, but it is an example of a growing trend, and it is something I have been reflecting on a great deal in the light of the Brexit vote in the UK. There is a trend in politics to create scapegoats – to ‘other’ – to store up hate, and it is a growing trend in politics – and progress is reversible. It is one thing that we must always be on our guard against. There are powerful forces who, with some success in many cases, are undermining and misrepresenting human rights at a time when the EU must be the voice – the antidote – to promote those values and to be the voice for minorities within the wider world. We have a job to do, and many people are relying upon us. I endorse the motion and thank everyone for their support.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Mister President! The situation in Chechnya has been worrying for many years. Like no other region in the Russian Federation, Chechnya ensures a steady influx of asylum seekers. This is a sign that human rights are being violated continuously, systematically and in a provocative manner. The news of how the security apparatus is criminally dealing with gays or men who are perceived as gay was shocking even to die-hard observers of the situation in Chechnya. It is important that our House deal with these matters as soon as possible, and the Commission's clear position should be emphasized. It is a clear and clear sign that we are not going to tolerate such a thing, and it is an expression of our concern that discrimination against LGBTI people and latent homophobia always end up as it happened to Chechnya. It is positive that the Russian Federation Government has promised to clarify the situation. But what is done is in no way sufficient. We need real education.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we are celebrating World Day Against Homophobia and, at the same time, Chechnya is on a hunt for homosexuals. To be homosexual there is to risk death or exile. It is unacceptable to remain silent in the face of this situation, of those who obstruct the values ​​of human rights. We are the spokespersons for the victims of persecution. We call for the immediate release of the prisoners, for real protection of all those who have denounced these heinous acts and for a serious investigation by international human rights organizations. Europe must show courage in the face of what is happening in Chechnya, a member country of Mr Putin's Russian Federation. Next year, the same federation is due to host the FIFA World Cup. While some will play football, others will be slaughtered. Tonight, therefore, I call for a boycott of this World Cup as long as fundamental rights are not respected in Russia and its satellite states.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: - Mr President, in 2013 - you reminded the Commissioner - we welcomed the adoption by the Council of the guidelines on LGBTI people. Thanks to them, we thought we had the necessary tools to fight homophobia and yet, four years later - it must be admitted - LGBTI people in Europe continue to be victims of discrimination, violence and humiliation. The situation is also bad outside the Union since a homophobic law was passed in Russia four years ago and the already deleterious climate has deteriorated even further for LGBTI people in this country. This law is the negation of the other, of his or her difference, and it is this climate of hatred that led to the arrest of a hundred people in April in Chechnya and their detention in absolutely conditions. monstrous. We must take action, human lives are at stake. All Member States must offer a sanctuary to these people who are not safe in Russia and European embassies must issue them visas so that they can come and apply. asylum within the European Union. In addition, the Russian authorities must shed full light on these April events and thus attempt to honor their human rights commitments.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, dear Commissioner, what is happening in Chechnya right now is the extremest form of escalation of a backlash that we are actually seeing all over Europe and all over the world right now. The reports of torture, of persecution, of imprisonment and even of killings are absolutely shocking, but the precondition for these kinds of dehumanisation are one thing, and that is denial – denial that we even exist, that gay men, lesbian women, bi-trans and inter people exist, and when the Chechnyan President declares that there are no gay men in Chechnya, he does exactly that. He denies our existence and he erases our existence, and this is why we cannot just stand aside; we will have to speak up.  The European Union will have to speak up and defend the rights of those that are being denied their existence in Chechnya, and not only tomorrow but all the time, because we exist and we can be proud to exist.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, "... you can resist beating with rubber hoses, you bite your hands until you bleed but then you can do it. Electricity is another thing, you see that the You crank it and you know it will come, and when it comes your body starts shaking. You know what it is because you've been through it before, but you don't understand what's going on anymore, you scream in pain your throat bursts, you feel yourself falling. " This is the testimony of Andrei, a Chechen boy, arrested and tortured in Chechnya like hundreds of others. Chechnya is a free port in which Ramzan Kadyrov's regime of terror is in force, untouchable because it is useful to Putin and Putin's Russia, where four militants were arrested a few days ago, including one European. Kadyrov is untouchable and therefore with the power of life and death over the inhabitants of Chechnya, especially, apparently, over the gay inhabitants, tortured, tortured, threatened and then left to their families to finish the job; an honor killing, they say, that's what they call it, we are in 2017. Mr President, I think these facts ask us some questions about what we are and what we want to do. What is Europe if it is not indignant about what is happening a few kilometers away from us? What is Europe if it does not mobilize for all people, especially those discriminated against, who must still feel their lives are in danger? What is Europe if it does not defend life? I believe that Europe is today at a crossroads, to turn its head the other way or to use all of its power to put Russia and Chechnya before their responsibilities. We can no longer have anything to do with countries that do not respect human rights. You see, President, I believe that enduring violence against religious minorities, enduring violations that women suffer in many parts of the world, enduring migrants dying at sea and tortured gays in Chechnya, enduring all this is an attack on the very idea. of Europe and attacks must be answered firmly and decisively.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am very grateful to the Commissioner for his explanation of the work that has been done on behalf of the European Union. Of course, we are only here, as colleagues have pointed out, because of the hard work of civil society in highlighting this.  The appalling examples of denial that we have seen from the Chechen and Russian authorities do no justice to the people who are suffering, but we do know now, because of the hard work of NGOs, because of the hard work of organisations like Novaya Gazeta and the journalists who face recrimination and death, that this is occurring. I am a gay man and I am able to be here with other gay men, other lesbians, other LGBTI people and do the work that we do, because I know I am not going to be dragged from my seat by the authorities. I know I am not going to be beaten up by the canal and left for dead and then that be denied by the police and indeed by my own government – they are here to protect me.  I do not know if there is anybody here watching in Chechnya or in Russia, but you are not the problem if you are LGBTI; you are not the illness. It is the people who are doing this to you that are the problem and it is this organisation, the international community, who will stand to defend you. (Applause)

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ‘I will never allow the tyranny of a majority to oppress a minority’, said MEP Michael Cashman as he cut up his Visa card in this very Chamber in the lead up to the Sochi 2014 Olympics, when Putin was making anti-LGBTI laws. And three years on, we can see that we must never be complacent. The reported persecution of gay, or allegedly gay, men in Chechnya is shocking, and the international community must act resolutely to end it. Mr Putin apparently said that he would support an investigation after Angela Merkel pressed him on it. But Russian authorities still continue to dismiss reports as rumours. So the EU must increase the pressure. The human rights defender Yuri Guaiana was arrested trying to deliver a petition with two million signatures, demanding justice for LGBTI people in Chechnya. He was later released because of international pressure.  All too often in this Chamber we find ourselves defending human rights defenders. Yes, the EU is a key protector of human rights in the world, and all of us, as parliamentarians and citizens, must join in support of the effort to ensure those who fight for human rights have the support they need.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the human rights situation in Russia is more and more worrying. It seems that at least 100 men have been detained in Chechnya, Russia, on suspicion of being gay and have suffered severe torture and humiliation in unofficial prisons. At least three men have been reported killed. Many remain detained in prisons where they face torture and inhumane treatment in horrific conditions. Regional authorities have denied the allegations and are responding by inciting further hatred against perceived homosexuals. National Russian authorities continue to ignore this fact. The EU must act now. I support the question, as I believe the European External Action Service should inform us of the type of action they have taken in the specific case of Chechnya. It is vital to raise this matter with the relevant Russian authorities to ensure legal and physical protection for the victims and full respect for citizens’ human rights.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the freedom to be homosexual is a right, but not in Chechnya. President Kadyrov has decided to exterminate all homosexuals from his territory by May 26 and, by the way, some political opponents who have dared to challenge his power. Several reliable sources have demonstrated the existence of a camp similar to a concentration camp, where dozens of gays are taken, locked up, tortured and, for some, killed. Parents are forced by police to kill their gay children to avoid incarceration of the whole family. The authorities call it "washing honor with blood." When high-ranking Chechen officials are asked for information on this bloody purge, they reply that it is totally impossible because homosexuality does not exist in Chechnya. An answer that might make you smile if it didn't make you want to throw up so much. All these potential or actual victims have only us to hope for survival. Our European values ​​forbid us to remain blind and deaf to such a tragedy. We need to offer emergency visas, as Canada is proposing. The time is no longer for words, it is for actions.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I would like to thank all those who have spoken in this debate, because there was one clear voice that condemns the situation in Chechnya, condemns the situation of sexual minorities, people who are not only discriminated against but are at risk of life and health at the moment.I am also glad that the Commissioner has talked about this.We should address specific things.It is good that there is a diplomatic offensive by the EU, and I am very skeptical that Putin's cynical regime will really investigate something and really change the situation of homosexuals in Russia and, in particular, Chechnya.I therefore think it is right that it has been said here that these people need to be given visas, to open their arms, to enable them to obtain asylum, because it is clear that they meet the international legal conditions for asylum in EU countries, and also to supportindependent journalists who report on these matters in Russia.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the news from Chechnya and Russia is very serious. There is talk of torture and systematic violence, illegal detention of hundreds of gay or presumed gay men, there is talk of real executions, of reeducation camps. All this is medieval, it takes us back to the darkest stages of human history and, most recently, the arrest of several activists in Moscow, including Yuri Guaiana. The European institutions and the Member States intervene to protect the LGBTI community with all the tools at their disposal, visas and even those of inquiry, pressure on the Russian authorities to stop this horror. Tomorrow is International Day against Homotransphobia, things like this show how much it is needed. We have learned that even in Italy someone, on the occasion of the Reggio Emilia pride, will organize a "repair" procession. It is this hatred that we must make amends for, certainly not free and equal love. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this is everyone's battle because it concerns the fundamental rights of the people that we have put at the foundation of our Union.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Putin's 2013 gay anti-propaganda law has led to the hunt for gay men from Kadirov today.Mr Stylianides, we agree: it is not enough to adopt another resolution condemning abuses and human rights violations in Russia.On the eve of the International Day Against Homophobia, I ask you to support the lawsuit just filed by LGBTI organizations before the International Criminal Court.Let this court try the President of Chechnya for genocide against homosexuals.There can be no impunity for those who persecute and torture human beings, nor for their accomplices, however powerful they may be.On July 1 in Madrid, at World Pride, there will be millions of us who will demand effective equality and decriminalization of homosexuality in the world.Everyone is invited.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation reported to us from Chechnya is an extremely serious and worrying situation.
