The investigation born from the complaints of the Novaya Gazeta has brought out very heavy accusations, which also concern the terrible conditions of detention of homosexuals, torture, humiliation, generic beatings, repeatedly perpetrated, and there is even talk of real cases of murder, not to mention persecution and pressure also against their families, who are equally in danger if they do not act to protect "honor". The sentences of the spokesman of Ramzan Kadyrov, president of Chechnya, as well as those of Kheda Saratova, a member of the Chechen Human Rights Council, are unacceptable from every point of view, they are unworthy of anyone holding an elective office, of anyone holding an office of government. We demand the full and total commitment of the Russian authorities to shed light on what is happening and full and convinced action to support and protect the victims, as well as their family members who must be transferred and placed in safe conditions. This is what, at the very least, we as the European Union must expect.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, dear colleagues, thank you so much for your intervention and thank you so much by showing this unity for this very important issue. We all share the concern about what is happening in Chechnya. We all agree that this issue is completely unacceptable, and I personally believe that it is a shame, because we have to discuss this issue in the 21st century. The violence against the LGTBI community has given visibility to the disastrous situation of human rights in this Russian republic. We will keep working with Member States to support the victims and put pressure on the Russian authorities to stop the violence and ensure justice for the victims. Please be aware that some of our common efforts will require patience and confidentiality. We are all trying to help, definitely, but we cannot go public about everything that is being done. In some cases being effective is more important than being outspoken, for the sake of the people involved. I would like to say this because I know some cases on the ground. May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this issue on the agenda. We have to continue the struggle in order to show our willingness, our strong conviction about the rights of the LGTBI community.

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner, especially for your words about our duty and our role as the European Parliament.

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: written.- Authorities in the South Russian republic of Chechnya have started a witch hunt for gay men, with more than 100 men imprisoned for their sexual orientation.Once in detention they have been mistreated.According to various reports from Human Rights Watch, among others, four people have now died.The fact that the leader of the republic, Ramzan Kadirov, denies that homosexuality exists in that region is sad and at the same time very reprehensible.It is therefore important that an independent investigation into such malpractices is initiated as soon as possible.Should Kadirov and Putin take no or insufficient action, it is up to the international community to increase the political pressure.Every person must be able to admit who he / she is and who he / she loves.That is at the heart of our values.It is up to us to keep fighting for that, wherever in the world.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: in writing. - We have all understood the horror of the situation in Chechnya where LGBT people are victims of torture, violence, inhuman and cruel treatment. Under international pressure, Mr. Putin supported an investigation opened by the Russian public prosecutor's office, but do not congratulate ourselves too quickly. The prosecution has not yet received any victim complaints, and for good reason! The safety of LGBT people, who are in a situation of extreme vulnerability, and who cannot testify for fear of revealing their identity, should be guaranteed. They are afraid of the state, but also of their families, because the Chechen authorities have stopped at nothing; even calling on residents to kill homosexuals in their families in order to wash their honor. I salute the courage of local NGOs who have set up an emergency telephone line and organized evacuations to other Russian provinces or abroad. It's our turn to be up to the task. The Union must put pressure on Vladimir Putin and Ramzan Kadyrov to bring this situation, an extreme human rights violation, to an end. As for the states, they must issue emergency visas to those fleeing Chechnya.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the situation in Moldova (2017/2689 (RSP)).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of my dear colleague, Commissioner Hahn, thank you for this opportunity to exchange views on the situation in Moldova. Both Federica Mogherini and Johannes Hahn are very closely monitoring the situation, with particular focus on the reforms and political developments. In our partnership with Moldova, we have always tried to support change when it could bring tangible benefits to the people of Moldova. Let me recall that in the very first lines of our Association Agreement, the European Union and Moldova commit to some common principles. Among them are the rule of law, good governance and cooperation between neighbours.  These are not only EU values, they are European values that are part of our common heritage and are shared by all Members of the Council of Europe. The Council conclusions of 15 February 2016 already include a broad set of reforms that we believe will help Moldova meet its full potential, making both its democracy and its economy stronger. On 13 March, we published our first association implementation report, which has identified issues to be addressed as a matter of priority. On 31 March, the Association Council was the opportunity to discuss progress in reforms in all fields. We have to acknowledge that the government and the parliament have taken many legislative steps, particularly last year. The reform process has finally been restarted after political instability had brought it to a deadlock. Some efforts have been made in the banking sector and have contributed to restoring macro—financial stability and donors’ assistance. An agreement with the International Monetary Fund was reached in November 2016, thanks to which we could resume our budget support based on a thorough assessment of whether the conditions foreseen by the existing assistance programmes to Moldova had been fulfilled. It also allowed us to propose a macro—financial assistance operation for Moldova.  In the justice and energy sectors, in the fight against corruption, as well as the public administration reforms, some legislative and regulatory steps have been already taken. However, many of the country’s key problems still persist: the politicisation of state institutions, corruption, lack of independence of the judiciary, much—delayed investigations on banking fraud.  As you all know, on 5 May, the parliament adopted two draft laws at first reading that might lead to important changes in the Moldovan political system. One, as tabled by the Democratic Party, would change the electoral system from proportional to uninominal, and a second, as proposed by President Dodon, in favour of a mixed electoral system, half proportional and half uninominal. These two proposals have now been merged. A new draft was produced on the basis of President Dodon’s proposals for review by the Venice Commission. It is expected that the Venice Commission, which has just visited Moldova, will give its opinion by mid-June. Let us be very clear on this proposed reform. It is not up to the European Union to decide upon an independent country’s voting system. This should be up to the people of Moldova – and we mean all of them, not only the parties in power. Any change to the electoral system should be based on a broad consensus amongst political forces, on the broadest consensus among all political forces and within society. A new electoral law can have a significant impact on the quality of a country’s democracy, for better or worse. The Council of Europe has an important advisory role when it comes to democratic reforms, so we can only hope that Moldova will listen carefully to the opinion of the Venice Commission. On our side, our economic support is aimed at accompanying reforms that can benefit the citizens of Moldova. With the Association Agreement, we have set out together with our Moldovan friends, the goals of our partnership. Our financial support is intended precisely to favour the implementation of the Association Agreement. As far as the macro—financial assistance is concerned, the adoption of the decision does not mean its immediate implementation. Each disbursement, including the first one, is conditional on the implementation of policy measures set out in the related memorandum of understanding. Real accountability for elected officials is essential to the credibility of all democratic institutions. Moldova has so far taken some steps towards a stronger democracy. The European Union will work to help Moldova stay on the path of a democracy that truly delivers on its citizens’ needs. Thank you so much for your attention, and I look forward to hearing your interventions and your suggestions about the situation in Moldova.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Thank you, Mr President, I am against granting financial aid to Moldova because we do not know where this money would go. In Chisinau, everyone knows that a billion has been stolen, but no one is responsible because justice does not work. In fact, it would not be the citizens who would benefit from European aid, but the kleptocratic elites. The only argument presented by Chisinau in favor of granting this aid is that the government would be pro-European. Fake. The government is not controlled by the Parliament, but by an oligarch, Mr. Plahotniuc, who buys deputies in pieces, first of all communists. Mr. Plahotniuc recently agreed with the country's president, Dodon, who is a special character. He is the only socialist in the world on the left of the communists and completely enslaved to Moscow's interests. They want to introduce an electoral system that leads to a bipartisan system so that Mr. Plahotniuc's party and Mr. Dodon's party control the game. An oligarch cooperating with a Putin servant remains from the pro-European coalition in Chisinau. That's the reality on the ground. In these conditions and as the freedom of the press is trampled on, as the rule of law is an empty word, we cannot send money to be chopped by these kleptocratic elites. There is a Romanian word: if you burned yourself with soup, blow in yogurt. That's what we need to do right now.

name: Andi Cristea
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, if the Republic of Moldova is on the agenda of our plenary session today it is because this country is at the top of the European Parliament’s priorities and Moldova has the support and commitment of all political groups across this Parliament on its European path.   I want to acknowledge the reform efforts and ambitions of the Moldovan people and the authorities and to convey a strong signal of support and encouragement at this important time, especially in relation to the positive impact of the current process of political association and economic integration. It is clear that, although some areas require additional efforts, overall there has been substantial progress since the start of the executive mandate.   This week, this House will approve its mandate for the start of negotiations with the Council and the Commission for EU macro-financial assistance to the Republic of Moldova. This assistance will be a sign of recognition of the renewed commitment to moving forward with necessary reforms and to addressing the country’s challenges by the current executive. In this regard I wish to underline that we will be applying rigorous, clear and strict conditionality criteria on disbursement, and this conditionality will be attached to the disbursement of each tranche, including the first one.   This Parliament has been most effective and successful when it has acted with full consensus on its line vis-à-vis the Republic of Moldova. The divisions and tensions amongst political parties in Chişinau are more and more reflected within the European Parliament and its political groups. I want to be very clear. I want to be crystal clear. This is not a positive development. As the European Parliament we can only be effective if we are united and not politicised, if we have a strong, objective and institutional line instead of expressing our positions through the prism of our respective political partners in Chişinau. And I want to personally thank all colleagues for their fair and constructive approach in this crucial period. I would like in particular to mention Cristian Preda and Petrus Auštrevičius.  We are, of course, following closely the ongoing process of electoral reform. Next week the EU-Moldova Parliamentary Committee and the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly will meet in Chişinau. This will be an opportunity for the European Parliament to meet its Moldovan counterpart while we await the opinion of the Venice Commission on the draft law.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, media and political pluralism, quality journalism, combating corruption and Russian propaganda are the best ways to ensure the European direction of Moldova. A clear signal should be sent by us to Chişinau, and as soon as possible, that urgent action in all these areas is needed and is a prerequisite for our further financial support to that country. Unfortunately, the situation is very grave and there is much disinformation in that country, taking into account the fatigue of society, and its disbelief in the authorities. We have to take our responsibility to really enhance the democratic consolidation of Moldova.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, as a standing co-rapporteur on implementation of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement, I will speak in a very frank and sincere way. I do so, as I feel very high responsibility for where Moldova is heading to, as it soon might become crucial and hardly reversible. Today, it is time to pronounce: quo vadis Moldova? Being a rapporteur, I must admit I am lately not that sure of how seriously a status of EU associated partner is perceived by the Moldovan authorities. This partnership is not at all abstract. It means certain obligations and deliverables, not only yet another credit line being opened. By partnership we expect first and foremost that a certain European-style political culture is to prevail in Moldova.  In Europe, free and independent media is in the interest of everyone, as openness and difference of opinions is a catalyst of change and public discourse. In Europe the election laws are designed to ensure fair competition of people’s minds, and not to create privileges for some and eliminate others. In Europe, justice is what everyone has the right to; there must be no place for selective trials behind the closed doors.  I therefore want to appeal to the Moldovan Government as follows: do not be misled with the wrong assumption that Brussels is big, blind, far away and always ready to sign another cheque. Instead of calling yourself a European coalition name, come up with the real deeds, real change handled in a European way. We expect from you, Moldova.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! Commissioner, unfortunately, regardless of what you said today, you still owe the European Parliament the resolution of an objection. They want to give Moldova access to EU funds again, but neither the “banking scandal” nor the statements of the president about the seeping of money into the pockets of corrupt elites have been clarified, and so far the corruption, abuse of office and arbitrary justice have also emerged nothing changed. I have been to Moldova again and again and have long been calling for the European Parliament to begin to discuss the realities and their roots that we are confronted with in our eastern neighborhood. Moldova is the result of a transformation process in which adaptable oligarchs like Plahotniuc followed the key words from member states of the EU or the Russian Federation, studied and at the same time further developed what can be said of parties such as B. Popolo della Libertà can learn about maintaining power. The problem also begins in EU capitals and has only ended in Chişinău so far. Incidentally, we are in the middle of a lesson for these Plahotniucs, because our discussion takes place in the context of the cancellation of the trialogue on macro-financial aid for Moldova. As if we were in Chişinău, institutional processes were simply intervened from outside. EPP and S&D are not alternatives with regard to Moldova, as both have their stakes in the Moldovan government. The European Parliament must free itself from this entanglement of interests. That is why we have made clear demands in the direction of Moldova: precise and implementable conditionalities for EU funds, precise naming of the services to be provided by Moldova and no hiding of the European Parliament behind large worlds of terminology, immediate termination of the trials against any political opponents.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! I want to start by saying that I think it is very good that we can continue this debate that we are having here today in Chișinău in a week, since we are both there with the delegation and we are also having a board meeting of the parliamentary assembly [EURONEST] . That really gives us an opportunity to discuss further. First of all I would like to go into what has made waves in Germany and has also reached other EU countries and Brussels, namely a quote from President Dodon, who said that half of the money will be raised over a period of seven Years from Brussels to Moldova, seeped into dark channels and not used as intended. It struck me that while President Dodon was also part of the government in those years, he has not yet been able to put on the table any details about the leakage of this money in Brussels. That is why I think we really have to think about whether we should continue to give money to a country whose president tells us that money is trickling away into dark channels there, and whose president was also partly responsible for the seeping away of this money. I believe that the European Union in these transition countries, in the countries that have headed west as part of our partnership, is actually held very much responsible by the citizens for fighting corruption. Mr. Dodon has now actually invited us to proceed more strictly. He actually comes to meet us in this dispute, and maybe we can deepen it in Chișinău. I would agree with all speakers who say that there has been progress on legislation in Chișinău. But between legislation and implementation in a judicial reform, there are Worlds.The same applies to the administrative reform.The same goes for all structures that have been created to fight corruption.But as I said: in Chișinău then more.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Moldova remains one of the poorest and most corrupt European countries. Between 2000 and 2015 you are all familiar with the famous anti-government protests following the banking scandal, which saw the loss of one billion dollars by the three most important Moldovan banks, defined by some as the "theft of the century". This very strong discontent with the government has led to a disordered reaction, with a reduction in freedom of expression, an attack on the opposition and, in some way, a suppression of those voices that instead demand greater transparency and freedom. Even in April 2017, the government adopted a new law at first reading that would allow the use of the armed forces to counter public protests when deemed necessary. Pending the opinion of the Venice commission on the future electoral law, we must once again denounce the great power in the hands of the oligarch Plahotniuc, who in fact manages to direct, some say to control, the government, the judicial system, the anti-corruption bodies and average. A country almost hostage. We, as Moldova's first and main partner, must use the tools in our power to react. The one hundred million euros of aid must be a political lever that cannot be disbursed until there is a serious commitment against corruption and until there is a change of pace against corruption. We cannot pay on trust.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Mr Chairman!Not only have I been to Moldova recently, I have been there several times.I had relatives in the upper Moldovan circles and I can say that the Romanian mentality is such that they simply deserve money.When I was Moldova now, people believed that Putin was the only salvation, he would bring some order.On the other hand, any money given by the Union melts away and doesn't go where it should be.An attempt to bribe people with money usually ends up sad, because people are first bribed, then they are threatened that they will not be given the money, which means that people stop liking the European Union and are hardly surprised.Basically it is morality.What needs to be done is not to give money, but to give money to those who contribute to Moldova's economic prosperity, not to politicians.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Moldova is a European state. It is very important from a geopolitical point of view and this can be seen in the efforts of the Russian Federation to impose its point of view there. Recently, Moldovan governments have made efforts to move closer to the Union. Politicians have different opinions, towards the Union or towards the Russian Federation. It is our duty to encourage pro-European voices. We must continue to implement the Agreement, we must continue to monitor it at the same time. The electoral law must be in line with the social realities of Moldova. It is true that there are important risks when granting financial aid to a state that has problems with the legal system, the judiciary, corruption, and the rule of law in general. At the same time, European voices must be encouraged. Failure to grant this aid would encourage voices to Russia. I believe that this aid must be granted, but its use must be monitored very carefully.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, unfortunately, we have found that, in some Eastern European countries, the tragedy that communism unquestionably constituted has resulted in another type of tragedy and that is the case in Moldova. But I make my own the words of the speaker who preceded me: Moldova is a European country, it is the poorest country in Europe. Since the beginning of the 21st century, however, the Moldovan economy has grown significantly and the World Bank itself predicts that, after a slight interregnum, this growth will occur again. Moldova signed an association and free trade agreement with the European Union that opens the door to a market of five hundred million people and subsequently agreed to exempt visas for the movement of its population in the Schengen area. Three and a half million Moldovans are now able to move freely across Europe and are able to establish trade relations with the countries of the European Union in an easier way. In spite of all this, political positions have prevailed in recent times that call into question this approach to the European Union and go in the direction of favoring a connection with Russia again. This, of course, is not unrelated to the fact that the Russians put heavy pressure on the Moldovan population. In recent years and as relations with the European Union have strengthened, Russia has alarmed this population, which, despite everything, depends considerably on that country, not only in economic but also in social terms. It embargoed imports of Moldovan wine, meat, fruit and vegetables and threatened to extend the ban to other products, increased prices for energy supplies, threatened to place visa restrictions on the thousands of Moldovans working in Russia. We are, therefore, today at a decisive moment for the future of this country, which, I repeat, is the poorest in Europe, while still being a country that is part of our European civilization and, therefore, despite all the problems, despite all the mistakes made, I do not believe that the Union European Union must give up on continuing to encourage Moldova to promote the consolidation of democracy, to resolve the serious problems that have already been raised here and to carry out the reforms essential to its economic and social development.The worst that could happen to a country like this would undoubtedly be that the European Union gave up on it.I am sure that will not happen.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Thank you, in countries with solid democracies, the mixed uninominal voting system works. But in Moldova, where 5% are very rich and the rest of the population is poor, even very poor, based on this system the rich will buy their country and parliament or parliament and country. To this are added the daily propaganda and the decriminalization and misinformation of the propaganda made by the Russian propaganda and also by the press belonging to the oligarch Plahotniuc, which leads to the misinformation and manipulation of the electorate or many of the voters. The Union has invested heavily in Moldova. We have been traveling without visas since 2014, we have built streets, schools, kindergartens, we have financed and continue to finance the public administration system, the reform of the administration and many other areas and we are happy to continue to do so. Funding must, however, be conditioned by real reforms because this is what the population wants, it wants to continue and we want to continue the reforms in the sense of independence of justice, the fight against corruption, but really, not in words, but in deeds, independence the Attorney General, the fight against money laundering or, in the end, finding and recovering that stolen billion. All this must happen, but, I repeat, Moldova is a European country and we have a duty to get it with us and not to let it go to the Russian Federation ... (The President interrupted the speaker's speech.)

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, today's debate is one that raises a lot of questions for us, the European Union, if we want to continue to support the European path of the Republic of Moldova. It is not about the Government, it can be criticized, it deserves to be criticized, the reforms are sometimes timed, sometimes ambiguous, but it is certain that the government in Chisinau has shown a very clear will in its European aspiration. I will not talk about oligarchs or the political class, I do not think we should have a black and white debate because the European Union must essentially give a chance to the citizens of the Republic of Moldova and not to the political class. If we want this people to have a European chance, we must support them, be rigorous in controlling money management. These amounts should not be suspended because they are urgently needed. I believe that Moldovans and the people of Moldova, no matter how simple, no matter how easily manipulated, deserve this chance because they are all European citizens and we, when we decided that they must be with us, understood and respected the work. this.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - Of course, we can look at Moldova with different glasses, depending on whether through the glasses of the opposition or by non-governmental organizations. In recent days, of course, we have also received very serious and worrying reports from the non-governmental sector on the situation in Moldova, especially with regard to the planned reforms. which, of course, can significantly change the picture and also the political structure of Moldova in the future. I agree with my predecessors, who point out that, of course, Moldova also needs financial assistance and support in its financial and economic reforms. At the same time, of course, we must express serious, serious concerns and control over the situation in the judiciary, in the field of media freedom, and also, of course, in some way control over media ownership and the electoral system. The last presidential election also showed quite a few deviations from the standards we advocate in the European Union. Therefore, I am convinced that there is still room for improvement, and I think that Moldova also deserves our help, our cooperation, and of course we must be very strict and determined in requesting control and identifying where the money has disappeared from European countries. and also from their own funds.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: - A few years ago, Moldova seemed to be a leader in the region, open to reforms, the road to the EU, and efficiently introducing visa liberalization, which brought mutual benefits. Like every young democracy, Moldova is going through good and great moments, as well as experiencing threats, making mistakes. The essence of responsible policy is to increase development opportunities and reduce threats. Today, unfortunately, we can see a cloud of threats to the freedom of operation of non-governmental organizations and the independence of the media, to the government's efficiency in achieving reform goals, to transparency and determination in the fight against corruption and the threat of oligarchization, to the independence of the judiciary, to the model of electoral law, its clarity and honesty. With concern for Moldova, I would like to say: fully return to the road that leads to the European Union and to values. I hope that the latest dispute over the electoral law will be resolved not authoritarian but in accordance with the values. I believe that before the second reading of the electoral law, the comments of the Venice Commission will be carefully analyzed and implemented, and that this second reading will be by public consensus with all forces. I keep my fingers crossed for a strong, wise and European Moldova.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, dear colleagues, a colleague of ours, Mr Auštrevičius, was wondering quo vadis, where is the Republic of Moldova? We should tell Mr. Auštrevičius, with all due respect for him, that we, the European Union and the European Parliament must support this country to move towards the European Union, towards European values ​​and not towards the East, towards the Eurasian Economic Union where it wants to take it. Mr. Dodon, a country president who might go down in history on the gray side, in the dark side of that country's history, as a head of state who generally supports things against his own people, against his own citizens. The place of the Republic of Moldova is next to the countries of the European Union. We cannot stop the financing addressed to the Republic of Moldova, of the financial assistance addressed to the Republic of Moldova, because in this way the European Union loses its only way in which it can influence the way ... (The President interrupted the speaker's speech.)

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Moldova is part of the Eastern Partnership and, as such, aims to strengthen its political association and economic integration with the European Union. Unfortunately, however, the country continues to face serious problems on its way to the European Union. The various political formations in the country continue to find no workable and long-term solutions to important problems, and widespread corruption and restrictions on media freedom are eroding the state. Growing civil discontent and confrontations between pro-Russian and pro-European political forces raise serious concerns about the country's security. I therefore call on the Moldovan authorities to focus on the significant and urgent reforms set out in the 2014 Association Agreement. The European Union can continue to provide financial and political assistance to Moldova, but only if the country's authorities are firmly committed to democratic values. Moldova is an important factor in the stability and prosperity of the Black Sea region, and we must promote and protect democratic reforms, the fundamental rights and freedoms of the country's citizens and the country's European future.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Moldova is a European country and in recent years has taken important steps towards rapprochement with the European Union, expressed in the signing of association agreements and visa-free travel with the countries of the Union. But at the same time, processes have begun in the country that are moving it away from democratic practices, not without Russia's strong influence. Freedom of the media began to be restricted through the concentration of property, and as a result, political pluralism declined. I rightly call for the reform of electoral legislation to be based on the necessary public debate, together with all political parties and civil society, and for the word of the Venice Commission and the Council of Europe to be heard. As rapporteur for the EPP group on macro-financial assistance to Moldova, I do not think it is appropriate to grant aid without any conditions for reform and strengthening the country's democratic capacity. Moldova needs to depoliticize public administration appointments, fight corruption effectively and investigate banking fraud, where many public funds have disappeared, provide guarantees of respect for human rights and freedoms, and guarantees for independent and pluralistic media. I want to call on the European Commission to help even more strongly all Moldovan regions, and especially those in southern Moldova, such as Gagauzia and Taraclia, where anti-EU and pro-Russian sentiment is still very strong, but they are based simply on ignorance and the creation of an alternative reality through propaganda. So, Commissioner, please strengthen our communication positive strategy for the European Union in all regions of Moldova, especially in southern Moldova.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: - Thank you, Mr President, the European Union wants to help the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. For this, we have allocated EUR 746 million in European funds, money from the European Union budget for the seven years, 2014-2020. Moreover, in the European Union budget for next year, as general rapporteur for the budget, I said: the three states in the eastern neighborhood of the European Union that have signed association agreements with the European Union must be a priority for the European Union budget. In addition, we are ready to give another 100 million EUR to the Republic of Moldova this year, but we can only do so with extremely clear conditions: the fight against corruption, the fight against money laundering, the strengthening of justice and the proper functioning of the rule of law. These are reforms that the citizens of the Republic of Moldova are waiting for. More than 65% of the citizens of the Republic of Moldova consider that, unfortunately, their country is going in the wrong direction. Therefore, while we provide funds to the Republic of Moldova, we must ensure that the state is reformed, that it is modernized, that it meets the expectations of the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. There are also reports from the Court of Auditors of the European Union that say that European funds allocated to the Republic of Moldova can be better used. Commissioner Stylianides, regarding the reform of the electoral system in the Republic of Moldova, you said very clearly: the Venice Commission is the supreme authority to evaluate the reform proposals. I say the following: the Chisinau authorities must respect and implement the opinion of the Venice Commission. If we don't, we won't be able to ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I listened very carefully to the debate that took place here. Commissioner, on the one hand, I like you want to support Moldova's rapprochement with the EU. It is our political interest, it must be said openly. Ties to Europe need to be encouraged, thereby weakening Russia's influence in the country. On the other hand, during that debate, some facts that concern me have clearly fallen here. The behavior of President Igor Dodon, who is significantly pro-Russian, who is pushing for some reforms and, for example, also wants to change the flag of Moldova. There are things like the government itself, which is strongly in the hands of the oligarchs. There is one billion euros that have been lost. So I'm for support, I'm for financial support, but please be very careful. We need to be sure that the government there is really implementing specific reforms, evaluating those reforms, and then we can release some money. I am in favor of supporting the pro-European opposition, led by Mrs Maja Sandu, which I believe is a guarantee. These people could return Moldova on its way to Europe.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you, dear colleagues, for a stimulating debate. I think that we all agree Moldova has made a courageous choice to undertake an ambitious and far-reaching reform agenda. Unfortunately the reform efforts have not yet led to comprehensive implementation, to the tangible results Moldovan citizens have the right to expect. These efforts have to be continuously sustained, and I can assure you that the EU stands ready to continue providing its support to the Moldovan reform path. That is the reason why we have been preparing an annual action plan for 2017 as well as a new EU multiannual programme 2017-2020 – the so-called single support framework – that will focus on jointly-agreed priorities with a view to strengthening the European visibility and leveraging the impact on the citizens. We have every interest in supporting Moldova in its reform efforts, but ultimately it is above all up to the Moldovan authorities and citizens to own the reform process and to carry out the reforms they deem necessary. Federica Mogherini and Johannes Hahn will continue to keep you fully apprised of developments in Moldova, and of course we count on your support to our efforts towards Moldova a success story. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - On May 4, 2017, the European Parliament’s Committee on International Trade (INTA) supported the European Commission’s proposal to grant 100 million euros to Moldova. This sum is in addition to the 561 million euros already paid for the period 2007-2013 and which, however, did not have the desired effect: a bank fraud revealed in 2014 involved several Moldovan leaders, including the former Prime Minister Vlad Filat, who allegedly received € 1 billion from three banks (Savings Bank, Unibank and Banca Sociala). Obviously, the responsible Commission services have not been able to prevent this fraud. While these funds could be useful elsewhere in Europe, we are concerned that European funds are channeled through the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank, which also define the action program. Concerned about the independence of Europe, we call on the Commission to refuse any interference from global organizations based in the United States.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The provision of financial assistance for the Republic of Moldova should not be blocked! These funds are not for politicians, they are for people. We need to get out of political logic and start understanding the stakes of this aid. We are talking about the European Union's ability to understand that it is time to be pragmatic in its relationship with the Republic of Moldova and to show that we are here to support this country's path to development, democracy and a European future. Without such help, supporters of a move away from the Republic of Moldova from the European course will benefit and use this opportunity to criticize the European Union again. Obviously, the assistance must be accompanied by important and structural reforms that will improve the daily life of the citizens of the Republic of Moldova, but we cannot introduce political criteria in this regard. The European Union must become pro-active again in its relations with the Republic of Moldova, must be directly involved on the ground, show the benefits of the European future, be available to guide pro-European policy makers in the right direction for the citizens they represent, but above all, we must not forget that this effort is primarily for people, regardless of their political choice.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. - Moldova has been taking steps towards European integration for many years. The citizens of Moldova, one of the poorest countries in Europe, are demanding an improvement in the quality of life and an acceleration of the pace of political change in the country. Although Moldova was included in the European Neighborhood Policy as early as 2004, and 10 years later, in 2014, it signed an association agreement with the European Union, many key problems in Moldova remain unresolved. There are serious signals from opposition politicians and representatives of independent media that the principles of democracy are not respected in Moldova. The country has a problem with maintaining territorial integrity in connection with the ongoing disputes over the territory of Transnistria. Due to the need to import electricity by Moldova from Transnistria or Donbas, this results in dependence on energy supplies from unpredictable, uncontrolled sources. In conjunction with the almost complete domination of the Moldovan gas supply system by Russian Gazprom, there is a fear that Moldova is exposed to energy blackmail from Russia. Russian influence is also revealed in the media sector, where most programs come from Russian stations and broadcast anti-European material. For Moldova to take a decisive step towards Europe, it is imperative to stop corruption blocking the country's economic development. First, however, citizens and the government must clearly declare their full support for European democratic values ​​and apply them in Moldova's public life.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Sajjad Karim, on behalf of the Legal Affairs Committee, on the 2014 annual report on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality (2015/2283 (INI)) (A8-0114 / 2017).

name: Sajjad Karim
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, may I start first of all by recognising the tremendous confidence that colleagues have placed in me by supporting my rapporteurship on a continued basis for this file. It is greatly appreciated, bearing in mind the changing political dynamics within the European Union. May I also give due recognition to Commissioner Frans Timmermans for his attitude towards this file and, in particular, for taking on the mantle of ‘Europe only where necessary’. I would like to start by thanking all of my shadow rapporteurs involved in this report who have contributed to the final text, and for allowing it to reach this particular stage with relative ease. It was adopted with a large majority in committee. I will try to summarise the key points within the report as quickly and efficiently as possible. As is always the case with this annual report, which I have taken the lead on for some years now, it aims to strengthen the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. As laid out in the Treaty of Lisbon, they are guiding principles of the European Union and should always be respected fully. 2014 saw a decrease in the number of reasoned opinions issued by national parliaments, but my report notes that this could be put down to a significant decline in the number of proposals from the Commission. It also draws attention to the fact that justifications of subsidiarity and proportionality by the Commission have, on many occasions, been deemed incomplete or non—existent by some national parliaments. As a result, I have asked the Commission in my report to improve its explanatory statements with a factually-substantiated analysis of its proposals on subsidiarity and proportionality grounds. The report refers to the Impact Assessment Board too, as it considered just 32% of impact assessments in 2015 unsatisfactory in relation to analysis of subsidiarity and proportionality. This is the same figure as the year before, which to me shows that in this area there is a need for improvement. The key change in this year’s report is that it calls for reasoned opinions to also consider proportionality and not just subsidiarity. I am passionate about that, as determining whether or not legislation is proportionate is often neglected, but it is equally important. This would require a revision of the Treaties, but in my opinion it is a necessity and a greater step towards reducing the democratic deficit. I am pleased that groups supported my recommendation for an evaluation of the number of national parliaments required for a yellow card to be triggered. I think it is a good idea for the status quo to be questioned once in a while, and for us to step back and consider whether the thresholds are appropriate. Furthermore, I have called for proportionality tests to be able to discard proposals with disproportionate burdens on competitiveness and SMEs. This is crucial for business back home, regardless of the Member State, if they are to remain competitive. There are also proposals for an extension of the time limit for national parliaments to submit opinions which could be carried out by secondary legislation and subsequently incorporated into the next treaty revision. I think it is important to take into account the fact that there are instances where national parliaments simply cannot present a reasoned opinion in the timeframe – in cases of a natural disaster, for example.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am here in this debate on behalf of my dear colleague First Vice-President Frans Timmermans. First of all, and on behalf of the Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Karim, for his excellent report on the Commission’s report for 2014 on subsidiarity and proportionality.  Subsidiarity and proportionality must be at the heart of the European democratic process. They are key to our objective of being big on the big things and small on the small things. The Commission has committed itself to give real effect to the principle of subsidiarity. We want to work with the national parliaments and EU institutions to ensure that every proposal complies with that principle. Last year Parliament, the Council and the Commission signed the interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking. The Commission is pleased that all the institutions have committed to ensuring that subsidiarity must remain a key element throughout the legislative procedure.  Turning to some of the suggestions in the Karim report, the report calls on the Commission to reflect on its relations with national parliaments in general and specifically as regards subsidiarity scrutiny. The Juncker Commission pledged to forge a new partnership with national parliaments. Halfway through the Commission mandate, Members of the Commission have had more than 550 meetings with national parliaments – 550 meetings. These meetings give members of the Commission a possibility to explain what we do and why we do it. They also allow us to listen to the concerns of national parliaments and their citizens. The Commission will continue engaging with national parliaments for the rest of its mandate, for our mandate.  The report also calls on the Commission to reflect on possible changes to the subsidiarity control mechanisms, for instance through a political agreement between the institutions. The Commission is always open to discussing new ways of working together, but we must do it while respecting the existing treaties and the institutional balance which is laid down therein. I am much more in favour of pragmatic workable approaches where possible and where they respect the treaties. An example of a pragmatic approach also supported in the report is the idea that national parliaments should be able to invite the Commission to table a proposal for new or attendant legislation, the so-called ‘green card mechanism’. The Commission supports this initiative, and is pleased it has already become the practice without setting up new institutional and administrative structures. For instance, 18 parliamentary chambers in 2015 submitted an initiative on food waste to the Commission. Some of the suggestions in the initiative on Food donation, data collection and monitoring were reflected in the Circular Economy package adopted in December 2015. This example shows that national parliaments can play a constructive role and that the Commission is ready to discuss constructive suggestions from national parliaments. Let me conclude by reassuring all Members that the Commission will make sure that subsidiarity and proportionality remain at the heart of the European democratic process.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. - Mr Chairman! Colleagues! I am very grateful to Mr Karim for his rich and highly recommendable report. The Committee on Constitutional Affairs shares most of his diagnoses and recommendations. Indeed, the point is that we should make the subsidiarity principle and the proportionality principle linked to it more effective than before. It is therefore necessary to adopt a recommendation, extend the eight-week deadline for national parliaments to express their opinion, consider a green and a red card, because the yellow card is in crisis, is rarely used, and even when it is applied, the Commission does not always respond to the arguments national parliaments. Real political dialogue is key, and the Commissioner is right to declare that this initiative will be used effectively, but that also means being ready for the Commission to actually pull back when national parliaments are right in dialogue with it.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Karim once again. This is an example of always perfect cooperation, showing that we can calmly and without special emotions, but very concretely, we can obtain the final product, which is indeed a step forward in the difficult issue of cooperation between the European Parliament and national parliaments. We are always eager to emphasize that this cooperation is necessary, that we should deepen it, and that national parliaments should be more involved in the legislative process. These are good commitments. Unfortunately, the practice is somewhat different, and this is what my colleague Karim's report, adopted by a very large majority in the Committee on Legal Affairs, suggests. I am pleased with the information provided by the Commissioner regarding consultations by members of the college with national parliaments and the announcement of further consultations, because the results of these consultations should find expression in a real change in the relationship between what we do at Community level and what we do as a result it is implemented in the Member States, because it is the Member States who implement the law we enact. And the faster and deeper parliaments are involved, the faster and more efficiently they will translate (at least as far as directives are concerned) the provisions that we are creating here into national forums. Therefore, I would like to thank you very much for these announcements and for the speeches so far, because they go in a direction that is very much desired by my political group.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, I would first like to thank Mr Karim - our rapporteur on the 2014 report on subsidiarity and proportionality - not only for the quality of his report, but also for his availability and openness which made it possible to find a broad agreement between political parties. Subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental principles of the European Union - everyone agrees. But sometimes, on certain topics, it can be difficult to define the appropriate level of action between the Union and the Member States. This is why we welcome the measures of the Better Regulation Agreement adopted in May 2015, which provides for more detailed explanations on subsidiarity and proportionality, which should improve the quality of trade. However, the two principles must be applied in a balanced way. A balance needs to be struck between the effectiveness of Union action, on the one hand, and national sensitivities, on the other. Subsidiarity must not be used as a pretext to prevent progress by the European Union; it must also respect the particularities of the Member States. It is also important to find a balance between a top-down approach and a bottom-up approach. It is not a question of calling into question the right of initiative of the European Commission, nor the prerogatives of the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament as co-legislators, but it is important to involve the national parliaments, as emanation of public opinion in their Member State, in the development of common policies. In fact, national parliaments already have many possibilities to make their voices heard. At national level, by giving their point of view to their ministers, who sit on the Council of Ministers, but also by responding to public consultations opened by the European institutions or by giving their opinion on the books white papers and green papers, either individually or during interparliamentary meetings.We can go further and consider introducing a green card.Today, national parliaments have the possibility to oppose a legislative measure by means of the yellow card, which often suggests that the European Union is a threat to the Member States.The green card, on the other hand, would allow national parliaments to suggest initiatives to the Commission, which would make them committed and proactive players in the construction of Europe and the improvement of its functioning.In conclusion, this report is positive and I am delighted to be able to support it.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mr Chairman!Ladies and Gentlemen!Of course, I would like to express my thanks to Mr Karim, because the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are two principles that effectively defend the European Union against the omnipotent administration of the Brussels administration.I am very pleased with what the Commissioner said that he would do everything to ensure that these rules are respected in the Union.Unfortunately, in practice, the voice of national parliaments is often ignored.This was the case, inter alia, with the yellow card, when eleven countries raised their doubts about the Posting of Workers Directive and the Commission's response to doubts as to the compliance of these proposals with the subsidiarity principle was decidedly superficial and inadequate to the scale of the reservations.Stronger inclusion of national parliaments will make what we are adopting here better, more understandable and faster implemented in individual EU countries.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I must say that as a fan of better regulation I read the report with some interest. While I am not an ALDE shadow, I can fully subscribe to it. I also endorse the recommendations that my distinguished colleague, Karim, has put forward. To be honest, I do have doubts about the last one, which is to say the extension of the consultation period. It has pros and cons, and it is a question of personal preferences, but I would say that while one can envisage it, I can also see certain downsides.  What I would like to underline is that in the report – and this is a well—known fact and I will be concrete by referring to paragraphs 7 and 8 – we talk about the justification of subsidiarity and proportionality being incomplete or, indeed, non—existent. At least that is the complaint of the Member States. But there is also the well-known figure that the Impact Assessment Board considers 32% of the impact assessments reviewed in 2014 on these issues to be unsatisfactory, and our rapporteur says that these rates have not improved. Well, I must say that not only have they not improved, but down the line there has been no progress, and I think that every single impact assessment has to be thorough on this. We cannot speak of better regulation unless this figure is zero or close to zero. So this is one point I would like to underline. The second point is – and this is also mentioned in the report – that we rightly want to have greater involvement of the national parliaments. But, at the same time, I think that in 2014 only 15 chambers had utilised the potential. The rapporteur’s explanation is that this is maybe because of mandates reaching their end, but the fact is that we need also to place more emphasis and – let us say – pressure on the national parliaments. Final remark: I agree with the green card, but I would love the European Parliament also to have a green card in the future.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the report on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in 2014 comes with a long delay and is limited to formalities related to the involvement of national parliaments in European Union legislation. However, these basic principles of Union law are being violated through austerity programs imposed on heavily indebted Member States such as Greece. Subsidiarity is violated because these programs do not suffice to formulate budgetary targets, leaving the way to achieve them in the Member State concerned, but also dictate the means of achieving the targets, even in areas outside financial management, such as labor market deregulation. Proportionality is also violated because an overdose of austerity is imposed, causing recession and unemployment with devastating social consequences. The Union must change course and put its principles into practice.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, my colleague Karim's report contains the following observations: "some parliaments have pointed out that, in certain legislative proposals from the Commission, the justification for subsidiarity and proportionality is incomplete or even non-existent". This finding is the same as in the 20th, 19th and 18th reports. In this one, only one difference: no more worry, no more concern, just an observation. Since 2010, absolutely nothing has changed. Despite interpellations from national parliaments, the Commission, with the consent of this Parliament, continues to treat with indifference and contempt this principle, which was recognized as fundamental by the European Council in its Edinburgh declaration of 1992. This type of report does not present therefore no interest, except that of giving purely fictitious pledges of improvement of this principle. There is further proof that this Parliament has little interest in respecting the competences of the Member States and, therefore, of the peoples of Europe and of democracy. I therefore call on national parliaments to make full use of the means made available to them by Protocol 2, to invest more in COSAC and to use all appropriate political means in order to ensure that this principle of subsidiarity is respected. Finally, national citizens must challenge their parliamentarians on this fundamental subject. They must not forget that the European Union belongs to the Member States and national parliaments, and is therefore their property.

name: Der Präsident.
text: - Dear Colleagues!I would like to take this opportunity briefly: We are very late in time.In the catch-the-eye procedure, however, we do not have as many requests to speak later.I want to say expressly, however, that the catch-the-eye procedure is not there to be a precautionary measure for everyone catch-the-eye and then cheerfully arrive at the debate, as it is.So the catch-the-eye procedure is mainly for those who do not have speaking time and are following the debate.I'll take this into account below.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - I consider the final version of the report to be a good outcome of the debate in the Committee on Legal Affairs and I will be voting in favor of it.I believe that the principle of subsidiarity and the principle of proportionality should, above all, ensure effective governance in the EU.This role is irreplaceable, but at the same time I believe that they are not the fundamental tool through which we can increase citizens' confidence in European integration.Subsidiarity is also associated with calls for the role of national parliaments to be strengthened.However, this must not happen at the cost of weakening the role of the EP.If we call for subsidiarity, we could also start with ourselves.The EP is also bound by the division of powers between the EU and the Member States, but even here there are sometimes discussions on topics that do not belong to the EU.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman! The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are an integral part of shaping the policy of the European Union. They make it possible to determine when the Union is competent to legislate and contribute to decision-making according to the principle "as close to the citizens as possible". In other words, they show when real progress can only be made at European level and when the country will deal with the problem on its own. This year's subsidiarity and proportionality report showed that in 2014 the Commission received 21 reasoned opinions from the parliaments of the Member States on 15 proposals, a decrease of 76% compared to the number of documents received in 2013. In previous years, we have therefore noted a much greater involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process. However, this significantly lower number of reasoned opinions does not indicate a loss of interest in the subsidiarity principle by national parliaments, but a decrease in the total number of proposals submitted by the European Commission at the end of its mandate. In 2012 and 2013, the threshold required to initiate the so-called yellow cards were obtained every year, while in 2014 no yellow or orange card procedures were initiated. However, we will not evaluate the package of measures for better lawmaking to make European Union law better for its citizens on 19 May 2015, but we will only evaluate it in next year's report. The subsidiarity control mechanism is crucial for cooperation between European and national institutions. Finally, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on a very well prepared and very balanced document.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: Thank you, chairman.Subsidiarity and proportionality are two important principles in the European Union that must be guaranteed at all times.The report contains a number of very good elements for this, such as the demand for more extensive and factually substantiated analyzes of legislative proposals in terms of subsidiarity and proportionality.What I do have a problem with is the plea for - I quote - “more and not less Europe to be able to meet the internal and external challenges”.I think that Brexit and the rise of extreme parties show that Europe needs to move more in a different direction, that we need to move towards a Europe with public support.That is why I think it is a pity that the way is not being paved for a red card that should give national and regional parliaments the opportunity to definitively reverse legislative proposals.Thank you.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Mr President, the 2014 annual report on subsidiarity and proportionality is a model of tongue in cheek. He welcomes, for example, from his point number 1, “the permanent concern to respect these two principles” whereas in fact, they are constantly violated. This sad reality is reflected in point number 8, which pitifully admits that in 32% of cases the Commission's analysis of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality is insufficient. Other passages indicate that the yellow card procedure, which allows national parliaments to protest against a Commission initiative, is almost entirely ineffective. The report does not propose any real solution to improve respect for the will of national parliaments. The green card mechanism, the creation of which he suggests, will not solve anything because it fully preserves the discretionary power of the Commission. Only the consecration of a veto power, recognized in each member state, would be such as to respect national sovereignty, but the report does not really consider it, because the European Union is a hundred leagues from the Europe of nations. , which I wish for.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the principle of subsidiarity aims to bring the European Union closer to its citizens by ensuring that action is taken at local level when necessary. This applies to all the institutions of the Union and is of particular practical importance in the context of legislative procedures. It is today that it is particularly important to create solid European legislation on issues on which the European Union can make real progress and add value. In this regard, the European Commission must improve the explanatory memoranda of its legislative proposals, always presenting a detailed, comprehensive and factually sound analysis of its proposals in terms of subsidiarity and proportionality, which would assist national parliaments in considering these proposals. National parliaments, in their role as representatives of European citizens at national level, must also strengthen their important role in bridging the gap between the European institutions and the public. National parliaments can look for ways to play a more positive and proactive role in European affairs. Therefore, the idea of ​​using the 'green card' procedure, according to which national parliaments could trigger European legislative processes and thus play a constructive role in European law-making, is a good solution. In conclusion, I would like to emphasize that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are an integral part of policy-making and of determining whether European Union action can achieve policy objectives better than national or regional initiatives.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - I have studied this report in detail, because in the Czech Republic I was responsible for legislation at the national level, so of course I am interested in the professional interest of what this report contains. I want to say that this is an important message for me. Subsidiarity and proportionality are not just some technical terms, but these terms clearly show what the scope of the EU should be, its legislation, what we are supposed to regulate by European legislation. In my constituency in the Czech Republic, I have to explain to the citizens why a certain thing is regulated by European law, why it is more appropriate for it to be regulated by European law, and not, for example, only by national law. That is why I am sorry that these very important reports are coming to Parliament's table relatively late. We are discussing the 2014 report, and it is difficult to apply the consequences that the report brings to practice. Otherwise, like my colleagues, I must say that I have seen a reduction in the reasoned opinions of the individual national parliaments. I will hope that this is due to the fact that we had less legislation in 2014 and that, therefore, the interest of national parliaments in interfering in the adoption of European law, European legislation, is not diminishing. What is important, and please note, is that national parliaments often argue that the justification for individual directives is not sufficient, that the justification for whether subsidiarity and proportionality is met is not enough. The Commission should learn from this.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: In the catch-the-eye procedure that follows, the only point I shall take into account is that of Mr Hayes.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I want to congratulate Mr Karim for his report. I think how we address the question of subsidiarity and proportionality is a really important issue. This Commission has done an awful lot more than previous Commissions in addressing the question of better regulation.  I think the inclusion of impact assessments is absolutely essential. I would like to see more impact assessments done on a Member State by Member State level and that requires, of course, the Commission to work with the authorities in those Member States to produce the evidence.  I think we would have a much greater involvement of national parliaments if we saw a specific impact assessment Member State by Member State, rather than a generic impact assessment across the 28 Member States of the European Union.  I also think the idea of a green card is a good idea. I think it sends a very positive signal towards the institutions to do much more, and I would agree with other colleagues that we, in this Parliament, should adopt that procedure. We cannot criticise other Member State parliaments when we ourselves encroach on their space, and I think we regularly do that in reports and initiatives which have nothing to do with EU law and everything to do with national law.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I have asked in the catch-the-eye procedure to speak on this issue.I have already given a relevant note to the secretariat for four hours.A while ago, when I arrived, I signaled to the secretariat and reaffirmed that I wanted to speak.I do not understand why I do not take the floor in the catch-the-eye on this issue.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Marias!I indicated that we are very late in time.I am under no obligation to take full advantage of the original slot, and that is exactly what you say is the problem.You registered four hours ago - the catch-the-eye procedure is actually there to enable you to speak up during the debate, and I personally have the practice that I am the colleagues who are there during the entire debate, considered.I saw when you came in.Mr Hayes was there at the beginning of the debate and spoke up.You were not there at the beginning of the debate - the three of us saw that - and therefore you are not taken into account.Commissioner Stylianides is now speaking.I am not taking another point of order.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you so much for this interesting debate and, of course, for your comments, for you suggestions and for your questions on this very important topic. As I already said, I am here on behalf of Vice-President Frans Timmermans, my dear colleague, and I would like you to know that all Commissioners remain at your service to discuss the subsidiarity and proportionality aspects of proposals tabled by the Commission. Once again I wish to thank the rapporteur, and all the Members involved, for this excellent report. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Sajjad Karim
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I will indeed be brief: you have indulged me more than enough earlier in proceedings today and I am obliged to you for that. I wish merely to finish off by saying the following: that this is not, and never was intended to be, a navel-gazing exercise. This is about the future of democracy in Europe, throughout Europe, for each and every one of our citizens. I only wish that we had had proper procedures in place many, many years before. It is quite clear that our national governments cherry-pick when it comes to Europe. When we provide something good and positive, they claim it for themselves and they say they have delivered this. When we deal with something that is a tricky proposition to sell before constituents, they automatically say: ‘this is from Europe and nothing to do with us’. And when you have that level of verging-on-almost-dishonesty in our political system, is it any wonder that today we find ourselves where we are?  Just on a personal basis, I have led on this file with the confidence of colleagues now for many, many years here in this House. I rather suspect this will be the last time that I do so, because of the particular dynamics in terms of the UK situation, and it is a matter of great personal regret for me that, based upon the lack of truly democratic transparency for our citizens, my country finds itself in this particular situation today. But of course, I wish all of my colleagues well. I will watch from afar as this Union deepens and strengthens, I hope, always remembering that at some stage I tried to play a constructive role whilst I was here.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Karim, for your words.I am sure it will not be the last time you spoke here.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday 17 May 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are at the basis of European construction. Article 5 (2) of the TEU and Protocol 2 on the application of these principles provide for a number of control mechanisms. The initial report proposed the establishment of a new red card mechanism for national parliaments. It was defended by my colleague Marie-Christine Boutonnet during the debates in the JURI committee. A green card would allow national parliaments to propose the rejection or modification of a legislative text. For my part, I defended the green card in my titular report for opinion, in the ENVI committee, on proportionality and subsidiarity. This green card would allow constructive participation of national parliaments. Unfortunately, my report was rejected by most of the members of the ENVI committee on partisan grounds. I regret this attitude, a fortiori on such a serious institutional question. The situation has not changed, since this report states that 32% of impact analyzes reveal insufficient application of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: written. - The report to be approved is an own initiative report (INI) carried out by the JURI committee to assess the report launched by the European Commission on the application of the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality in 2014. This report shows that in 2014 the Commission recorded a notable decrease in the number of opinions. However, this reduction should be seen in the context of a decrease in the total number of proposals submitted by the Commission at the end of its mandate and not as an indication of a diminishing interest of national parliaments in matters of subsidiarity. The report approved in the JURI committee is a good agreement. It is a balanced text that emphasizes the importance of ensuring the correct application of these principles, which are essential for the proper functioning of the EU and should be the starting point for the elaboration of European policies. Both principles are included in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union, establishing themselves as essential principles within the framework of the European decision-making process. These principles are an instrument that makes it possible to provide democratic legitimacy and efficiency to the actions developed by the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - We consider the debate on the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality very important. In relation to the principle of subsidiarity, we point out that it is an important principle that contributes to making EU decisions closer to the people. In this way, local and regional authorities as well as national parliaments must play an important role in the functioning of the EU itself. This strengthens the democratic functioning of the European project and strengthens the tendency to decentralize power. The national parliaments with the relevant protocol of the Treaty of Lisbon acquire the well-known yellow and orange card rights which, although they do not exercise them often, nevertheless are rights that turn national parliaments into important players in the field of EU membership. In addition, with the so-called Green Card proposal, national parliaments could be involved in the legislative initiative, thus asking the Commission to take specific legislative action in the areas for which national parliaments will decide each time. how much involvement of the Union itself is needed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Cora van Nieuwenhuizen, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on financial technology: the impact of technology on the future of the financial sector (2016/2243 (INI)) (A8-0176 / 2017).

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, new technologies are rapidly changing the nature of the financial infrastructure around the globe. This presents massive opportunities for Europe and it is now up to us, the policymakers, to make the right choices and create a conducive environment so that Europe can benefit to the full extent.  FinTech is often used to refer to a specific scenario of start—ups disrupting finance with innovation. This definition is not the one used in our report because it would exclude a large number of relevant actors. Instead FinTech may be understood as finance enabled by new technologies covering the whole range of financial services, products and infrastructure. It also includes InsureTech, the use of new technologies in insurance, and RegTech, the application of new technologies for regulatory compliance. The current rise of FinTech comes after the origination of a number of different technological developments within a short time span, namely artificial intelligence, cloud computing and distributed ledger technology. These provide new opportunities for disruptions like mobile payments, open banking, crowdfunding, crypto currencies and robo advice. FinTech can lead to significant benefits such as cost reductions, efficiency gains, and more transparency. It can also be an effective tool for financial inclusion, opening up high—level services for those who could not afford them before. Furthermore, FinTech can enable cross—border financial flows and infrastructure through alternative lending and investment channels.
